summary: Paul Merson has reignited his dispute with Andros Townsend following Townsend's late substitution in Tottenham's 0-0 draw with Burnley. Merson previously criticized Townsend's inclusion in the England squad, but admitted he was wrong when Townsend scored a crucial equalizer against Italy. Despite this, Merson continued to express his opinion on Townsend's abilities, even after Townsend's comeback on Twitter.

Chelsea has made a formal offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward Yoshinori Muto, with the potential for him to join their partner club Vitesse Arnhem on loan if the move to Stamford Bridge is completed. FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane confirmed the offer, stating it is a formal offer with conditions for a summer acquisition. Muto, who has 11 international caps for Japan and scored once, recently graduated from Keio University with an economics degree. A £4 million deal has been suggested, but Muto has not yet decided on the move, calling it an honor to receive the offer from Chelsea.

A large-scale study found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be fat as toddlers, with researchers suggesting this could contribute to the obesity epidemic. Finnish researchers compared over 12,000 two-year-olds and found that children who had taken antibiotics as babies were particularly likely to be overweight, with repeated prescriptions before age two increasing the odds. While the study did not prove causation, it suggested antibiotics might kill gut bugs that normally feed on food, freeing up more for the body, or increase appetite. Lead author Dr. Antti Saari highlighted the association between antibiotic exposure before six months or repeated use during infancy and increased body mass in healthy children, suggesting this could be a factor in the worldwide childhood obesity epidemic, which is more pronounced in boys.

A Buckingham Palace guard, part of the Queen's Guard, slipped on a manhole cover and fell in front of hundreds of tourists during the Changing of the Guard ceremony. The incident, which was caught on camera by a tourist named David Meadwell, resulted in the guard losing his footing, knocking his bearskin, and dropping his rifle. The embarrassed soldier quickly recovered and rejoined his colleagues, with the cause of the slip possibly being metal protectors on his boots. The Queen's Guard, which is not purely ceremonial but comprises fully operational soldiers, performs the Changing of the Guard daily in the summer and every other day in the winter.

A&E networks are remaking the 1977 miniseries "Roots," which had over 100 million viewers, to air in 2016. A&E, Lifetime, and History will simulcast the remake of the story of Kunta Kinte, an African captured and sold into slavery. LeVar Burton, who played Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the new version, which will draw more from Alex Haley's novel and consult historical scholars for authenticity. The remake aims to introduce the powerful tale to a new generation, with producers emphasizing its continued relevance in contemporary society.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, has accused Clarence House aides of attempting to force him into an orgy in January 1978, claiming he was pinned to a chair and groped by a male staff member on his first day of work. He left the job immediately after the incident and was threatened to keep quiet. Lawler, now 64, contacted palace officials again last year after inquiries began into alleged child sex abuse cover-ups, but his complaints were reportedly ignored for months before being passed to Scotland Yard. A retired royal aide, reportedly interviewed, denied involvement. The Palace has stated the Royal Household will cooperate with the police investigation.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy in a rap video set to the theme song of 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air,' which has garnered over 1.7 million views on YouTube. The video, filmed in Happy Valley, Oregon, features the couple rapping about their journey to conception and the pregnancy announcement, including Melissa's realization of being late and seeing a positive pregnancy test. The video was created to inform distant loved ones about the baby and was unexpectedly successful. Jesse Meek is the great-great-grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek. Melissa had previously made a video capturing Jesse's reaction to the pregnancy news, which he learned from a tag on their dog. Another couple in Phoenixville, Pennsylvania, also made a similar pregnancy announcement video last year.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film *Gone With the Wind*, a gray jacket and skirt with black zigzag applique, sold for $137,000 at auction. The ensemble, which has faded from its original slate blue-gray to light gray, was worn in key scenes, including encounters with Rhett Butler. This dress was part of a larger collection of over 150 items from the film, amassed by James Tumblin, who acquired the dress for $20 when it was about to be discarded. Other notable sales included a straw hat worn by Leigh ($52,500), Clark Gable's suit trousers and jacket ($55,000), and a black bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia De Havilland ($30,000). The film, based on Margaret Mitchell's novel, also saw Hattie McDaniel become the first African-American actor to win an Academy Award for her role.

A two-year-old boy is recovering after falling 10 to 12 feet into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo when his parents dangled him over the edge. The child was rescued by his parents before emergency services arrived, suffering minor bumps, bruises, and an injured leg, but was not attacked by the cheetahs. Zoo officials stated there is a strong likelihood the child was dangled over the railing and the zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family. The exhibit was closed following the incident.

A speed camera in Handsworth, Birmingham, which had been non-operational for two years due to the decommissioning of old technology across the West Midlands, has been turned around to face a residential house. Approximately 300 fixed speed and traffic cameras were switched off in March 2013, with mobile units and motorway cameras taking over enforcement. Birmingham City Council is aware of the situation, plans to send an engineer to the site, and may remove the camera, as it will not be part of a new digital technology pilot.

Usain Bolt will compete at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3 as part of the Jamaican team, according to an announcement by the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association. Bolt stated he is happy, fit, healthy, and ready to run, and that he always strives to make his country proud when representing Jamaica. The JAAA General Secretary expressed pleasure at Bolt's availability for selection, anticipating "sprint magic" at the event. The full Jamaican team list is expected to be announced soon.

Neymar and Dani Alves attended a Euro League basketball game between Barcelona and Real Madrid, where Barcelona won 85-80. Despite this victory, Real Madrid remains at the top of their Euro League division due to point difference. Neymar had recently played for Brazil, winning 1-0 against Chile, and will return to La Liga action with Barcelona against Celta Vigo as the team competes for multiple trophies.

Italy is experiencing a surge in migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe, with 8,480 rescued between Friday and Monday. Save the Children fears up to 400 migrants may be missing after a ship reportedly capsized off the Libyan coast, though the Italian coast guard has not confirmed this incident, having rescued 145 from a boat of approximately 550 without finding further evidence. The International Organization for Migration reported over 10,000 migrant arrivals in Italy in the first three months of 2015, with many coming from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit country. The IOM also stated that at least 480 migrants have died this year attempting to cross the Mediterranean, often due to poor weather, overcrowded boats, and abandonment by smugglers.

Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal over other clubs, including Liverpool, and has made an immediate impact, scoring 19 goals this season. Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is pleased with Sanchez's decision, though he acknowledges Liverpool's interest might have been used as leverage in negotiations for Luis Suarez. Wenger also downplayed speculation linking Arsenal with Liverpool's Raheem Sterling.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome. He aims to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes, challenging the current record of 52.491km set by Australian Rohan Dennis. Wiggins, who recently finished his Team Sky career, will also be preparing for the 2016 Rio Olympics. Tickets for his hour record attempt will go on sale on April 19, and the event will be broadcast live on Sky Sports.

Serena Williams, a two-time French Open champion, described her difficult win against Sara Errani in the Fed Cup as an "eye-opener" for the claycourt season, admitting she was not as prepared as she thought. Despite Williams' singles victory, the US team lost the Fed Cup tie 3-2 to Italy, with Williams and Alison Riske losing their doubles match, resulting in the US being relegated to World Group II. Williams acknowledged the need to adapt her game for clay, stating she was playing like she was on a hard court. The US captain, Mary Joe Fernandez, emphasized the need for harder work and expressed hope for promotion back to World Group next year.

River Plate is interested in signing Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao, who previously played for the Argentine club from 2001 to 2009, scoring 34 goals in 90 appearances. River Plate vice president Matias Patanian stated that the club "dreams of Falcao" and that "the doors are open" for his return, although a deal is considered complicated. Falcao has struggled at Manchester United this season, scoring only four Premier League goals, and his future with the club is uncertain. However, he has recently been in good form for Colombia, equaling their all-time goalscoring record with 24 goals.

Ella Henderson, a finalist from The X Factor in 2012 and a pop star, has become the official face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson with various hairstyles against a blurred city background, showcasing her long hair. The partnership was facilitated by the MILES agency and launched with a TV advertisement featuring her song "Mirror Man." Henderson expressed her excitement, noting she regularly uses the product. Mark Hargreaves, CEO of Crown Talent & Media Group, highlighted this as Henderson's first endorsement and praised the natural synergy between the artist and the brand.

Family and friends of Aaron Siler, who was fatally shot by officer Pablo Torres on March 14 after Siler reportedly armed himself with a weapon, are in shock over a billboard erected in Kenosha, Wisconsin, featuring Torres and his dog with the message "Thank you for your support, Kenosha." The billboard, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, is seen as disrespectful by Siler's loved ones, who are requesting its removal, while the association states it was intended to thank the community for its support following recent incidents. Torres is currently on leave pending the investigation into Siler's death, which followed another shooting ten days prior where Torres shot Terry Knight, who was armed with knives, a shooting that was later deemed justified.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Pakistan border in the southeastern town of Negur, with three militants also killed. The militants reportedly crossed into Iran from Pakistan, and Iranian officials have requested Pakistan apprehend the surviving assailants. The militant group Jaish al Adal claimed responsibility for the attack; this anti-Iranian Sunni Muslim group, which has targeted Shiites and aims to thwart Iranian influence in Pakistan, has previously claimed responsibility for attacks on Iranian territory, including one in October 2013 that killed 14 Iranian border guards. Iran has criticized Pakistan for failing to control terrorists, while Pakistan condemned the attack as an "act of terrorism" and stated its security agencies are investigating and will apprehend any militants who fled into Pakistan.

Japan's Defense Minister Gen Nakatani stated that the country's Air Self Defense Force has never encountered extraterrestrial unidentified flying objects, responding to a query from lawmaker Antonio Inoki. Nakatani explained that when unidentified flying objects are detected, fighter jets are scrambled for visual observation, which sometimes reveals birds or other objects, but not those believed to be from beyond Earth. This discussion follows previous political conversations in Japan regarding potential extraterrestrial threats and their implications under the country's constitution.

A passenger named Jin Pai, aged 35, was hospitalized with deep cuts to his leg and buttocks after breaking a toilet he was squatting on in Hefei Xinqiao International Airport. He had been standing on the rim of the toilet due to concerns about cleanliness, but the porcelain tipped over and shattered, causing his injuries. He was found bleeding and received dozens of stitches. While he initially confessed to squatting, he later told police he was sitting to potentially avoid compensation, though authorities believe it was an accident and advise against standing on toilets.
DID NOT RECIEIVE A STRING TYPE FROM OUTPUT

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama's latest series of images features fathers leaping into the air next to their daughters, who are pictured smiling and looking into the camera. The images, from Aoyama's book "Daughter and Salary Man," aim to allow fathers, typically serious, to express their fun side as a "hero jumping the sky." The fathers are depicted in sharp suits, while the daughters wear casual clothing, and the families pose in front of Japanese landmarks. Some older fathers exhibit pained expressions during their jumps, and the series has garnered significant online interest due to its unusual nature.

Kevin Pietersen posed for the Surrey team photo at the KIA Oval before the start of the county championship season, showing a range of emotions from deep thought to jovial moods, as his potential return to the England team moves closer following the dismissal of Paul Downton. Pietersen, who last played internationally during the Ashes tour in Australia last year, has rejoined Surrey to try and force his way back into the Test setup for the upcoming Ashes series on home soil. Surrey's first match of the campaign is against Glamorgan on April 19, and they will also play Oxford MCCU in a MCC University match on Sunday.

Relegation-threatened Romanian club Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt has sacked Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani. Ze Maria, a former Brazil defender capped 25 times, was initially fired on Wednesday but reinstated the next day by owner Angelo Massone. However, a subsequent defeat led to his second dismissal, and he will be replaced by Serbian Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao's former Monaco teammate, Nabil Dirar, believes Falcao regrets his loan move to Manchester United, despite Falcao not being happy in France. Falcao, who moved to Old Trafford on a season-long loan, has struggled to perform at his previous level after a serious knee injury, scoring only four goals all season. Manchester United is unlikely to exercise the option to buy him permanently for £46 million. Dirar suggests Falcao would have been better off staying at Monaco, where he would have played and participated in the Champions League, although Falcao was not feeling well there.

New Zealand police are seeking public assistance to identify a very tall man who robbed a Christchurch dairy on Saturday. The offender, wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt, stole the till containing approximately $1500 in cash. The incident occurred around 12:30 pm at the Union St dairy, where the man demanded cash from the owner's daughter. No weapons were reported to have been used, and the robber remains at large. Police urge anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or message them online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, has been arrested twice for alleged sexual relationships with 15-year-old students. Her first arrest on March 19 was for an inappropriate relationship with one student, which included admitting to kissing him and allowing him to touch her breasts. She was released on bail and placed on administrative leave. Subsequently, she was arrested again on Monday after a second 15-year-old student accused her of having sex with him in her car on consecutive nights in January. This second accusation came to light after school officials heard rumors of a second student being involved. Granado was booked into Irving County Jail for the second time and released on $50,000 bail. The Irving school district has stated they took immediate and appropriate action, and her administrative leave prevents her from working with students or being on school property.

A video of a crocodile swimming through a public marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead dog in its jaws has garnered over half a million views online. The incident, witnessed by New Zealander Tim Weston who was on holiday with his wife, involved a large crocodile holding onto the dog, which belonged to a local bike shop owner, for an extended period. Weston described the event as a shock but acknowledged it as nature, noting that crocodiles are common in Puerto Vallarta due to the resort being built amongst mangroves, their natural habitat. The video has elicited horrified reactions on social media, with some users expressing disgust and fear of crocodiles.

Steve Bruce remains confident that Hull City can avoid relegation from the Barclays Premier League, despite a 2-0 defeat to Southampton leaving them just two points above the drop zone. Hull has secured six wins this season, falling short of Bruce's initial target of ten, and faces difficult upcoming fixtures against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United. Bruce attributes the team's struggles to long-term injuries to key players like Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass. Meanwhile, Southampton's victory, secured by a James Ward-Prowse penalty and a Graziano Pelle goal, moved them to fifth in the league, though manager Ronald Koeman will address team discipline after Sadio Mane attempted to take a penalty designated for Ward-Prowse.

Ian Guffick, a teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School, was banned from the classroom for at least two years after allowing pupils to change their SATs exam answers and altering some himself, which led to the annulment of the entire school's results for the year. An investigation by the local education authority confirmed that changes were made to exam scripts outside of test conditions, and Guffick admitted to the allegations, accepting it constituted unacceptable professional conduct, though he claimed he only asked pupils to improve legibility. The National College for Teaching and Leadership panel found his conduct dishonest but not fraudulent, and while acknowledging his remorse, the Department for Education imposed the ban due to the serious impact on the school's results.

Manchester United goalkeeper Anders Lindegaard, despite limited playing time, is happily married to Swedish model Misse Beqiri, with whom he has a son. The couple, who have been dating since 2012, married in a beach wedding in Mauritius last year. Lindegaard, who has struggled to make an impact since joining the Premier League in 2010 and is currently third-choice at Old Trafford, shared a photo of himself with Beqiri on Instagram, referring to her as his "sunshine." Beqiri, who has Albanian roots, frequently posts modeling pictures on her Instagram account.

The glowing blue letters that once hung above Yankee Stadium in the Bronx, installed in 1976 and taken down in 2008, failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction. The 13 letters, each 10-feet-tall and some 10-feet-wide, were expected to fetch between $300,000 and $600,000, but the only bid was $260,000 from a Sotheby's employee. Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, the current owner who purchased the letters after the stadium's final game in 2008, had hoped a new generation would own the icon. In contrast, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s, estimated at $20,000 to $30,000, sold for $112,500.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has spoken to Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe about their professional responsibilities following incidents where Sterling was exposed for inhaling nitrous oxide and both players were pictured with shisha pipes. Rodgers has decided not to discipline either player and wants to move past the matter, emphasizing the importance of understanding what elite athletes can and cannot be seen doing. Rodgers also has Steven Gerrard available for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, and he believes the team is ready to progress after previous near misses.

Mesut Ozil returned to London after playing for Germany in a Euro 2016 qualifier, posting a picture of himself relaxing with his dog. He impressed in Germany's 2-0 win against Georgia and is preparing for Arsenal's Premier League match against Liverpool. Ozil, who joined Arsenal for £42.5 million in 2013, had previously missed a game due to illness, with claims of him being in a Berlin nightclub being dismissed by his manager. He has been performing well for Arsenal since January, with four assists and three goals, and feels he is adjusting well to English football due to the demanding schedule.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has stated that the club is "very happy" with manager Luis Enrique and has no plans to replace him, despite speculation. Enrique, who took charge last summer on a two-year deal, is close to winning the La Liga title and has impressed the president with his performance. Bartomeu mentioned that there is ample time to discuss Enrique's contract in the future, as the manager is currently focused on La Liga and the team's performance. He highlighted that Barcelona is in contention for three trophies, indicating satisfaction with Enrique's work.

Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with Liverpool, running until 2020, with improved terms likely worth around £100,000 per week. The 24-year-old midfielder, who joined Liverpool in 2011 for £16 million, has been a key player under Brendan Rodgers, contributing seven goals and 13 assists this season. He is also being considered for the club captaincy when Steven Gerrard departs for LA Galaxy. Henderson's contract extension follows similar deals for Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho, and he is the third player to agree to a new deal. Talks with Raheem Sterling are expected to resume at the end of the season.

Filipe Luis wants to stay at Chelsea until the end of his contract, despite Atletico Madrid considering re-signing him. Luis is happy at Chelsea and wants to remain with the club. He played for Brazil in friendly wins against France and Chile during the international break. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is emphasizing focus and concentration for the remaining nine difficult Premier League games.

Nathan Hughes's three-match ban for accidentally knocking out George North was overturned on appeal after Wasps lodged an appeal. Hughes's knee collided with North's head as North scored a try, leaving North unconscious and requiring a stretcher. Despite the initial ruling of 'reckless' play, the appeal panel concluded that no foul play occurred, as the incident was accidental. Hughes had missed his club's Champions Cup quarter-final due to the suspension and is now free to play, though he is not in the squad for the upcoming match.

Fiery sunsets were observed in Washington due to smoke from raging wildfires in southeastern Siberia, which were started by farmers burning grass and spread rapidly due to strong winds, destroying villages. Atmospheric winds carried the smoke across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest, including parts of Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The intense red color of the sunsets is caused by smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelength colors from sunlight, allowing red and orange to penetrate unfiltered, with the effect being more pronounced during sunrises and sunsets due to the increased atmosphere the light travels through.

Becky Schoenig of St. Louis, Missouri had her new 2015 Ford Fusion stolen from her driveway, only to have it returned with red rims and detailing, as well as orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of being upset, Schoenig humorously thanked the thieves on Facebook for "pimping out" her car. She is now having the vehicle professionally cleaned due to the smell of cigarettes and marijuana and is creating a special smoothie at her restaurant, The Hot Pot, to honor the man who found her car.

Manchester City players face losing £500,000 each in bonuses if the team fails to qualify for the Champions League, with star players like Sergio Aguero and David Silva on incentivised contracts tied to financial fairplay rules. The team's recent loss to Manchester United has put their European qualification hopes in jeopardy, as they currently sit in fourth place, with Liverpool close behind. The squad has approximately £12 million at stake regarding their European target, and manager Manuel Pellegrini has acknowledged the team's poor performance in recent months. Failure to secure a Champions League spot could also impact the club's ability to sign top players like Paul Pogba.

Manchester United's Under 18s defeated City 1-0 in a "mini-derby" at Moss Lane, with Callum Gribbin scoring the winning goal from a free-kick. The match featured a high proportion of English and Mancunian players, and United's coach Paul McGuinness aimed to replicate a senior team experience for his players. United's Marcus Rashford missed two chances, while City's Marcus Wood came close with a chip. United's Cameron Borthwick-Jackson also hit the woodwork. The win places United two points behind leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while City has lost both of their Barclays Under 18s Premier League play-off matches.

Joe Hart called Gianluigi Buffon a "legend of the game" after Buffon earned his 147th cap. Hart, who achieved his 50th cap in the same match, stated that Buffon is an inspiration and that he is still learning from the 37-year-old Italian goalkeeper. Hart expressed his pride in reaching his 50th cap at the Juventus Stadium and his desire to continue playing for his club and country.

Chipotle is entering the food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app to offer delivery for online and mobile orders in 67 cities, with a nine percent service charge and delivery fees starting at $5. This move comes as other franchises like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also exploring or launching delivery services. Chipotle has recently seen presidential candidates Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton visit their restaurants.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, are pleading for the death penalty to be removed from consideration for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was convicted on all 30 charges. Bill and Denise Richard, whose son Martin was killed and daughter Jane severely injured, expressed their desire for the Justice Department to agree to Tsarnaev spending the rest of his life in prison without the possibility of release or appeals, believing this would end their anguish and prevent years of painful reminders.

A mystery billionaire has converted a Boeing 747 jumbo jet into a luxury home costing an estimated £400 million, featuring bedrooms, multiple lounges, an onboard restaurant with an adjoining kitchen, a dining room, a "state room," and an "aeroloft" with eight beds. The custom-built aircraft, designed to the owner's specifications over three years, can accommodate dozens of guests in a hotel-like ambiance, with areas for relaxation, work, and dining.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed Dragon cargo spacecraft to the International Space Station, but the attempt to land a rocket stage on a floating barge was unsuccessful, with the rocket landing too hard and tipping over. SpaceX founder Elon Musk aims to reuse rockets to significantly reduce the cost of space access. The Dragon spacecraft will deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies, including an espresso maker, and will later return to Earth with science experiments and trash. This was SpaceX's sixth mission to the ISS and the second attempt for this particular mission, as Monday's launch was postponed due to weather.

Priscilla Presley will witness the first wedding at a new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas, located at the Westgate Hotel. She collaborated with NBC's Today show to host a contest for an Elvis-obsessed couple to win an "ultimate wedding" on April 23rd, which includes a free reception, a two-night hotel stay, airfares, and tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. Priscilla, who wed Elvis in 1967, emphasized that the chapel is a serious, first-class venture and not a joke, and she was involved in its design. The chapel is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit of Elvis's artifacts outside of Memphis. Couples can enter the contest by submitting a video or photos explaining why they deserve the prize.

Liverpool vice-captain Jordan Henderson believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League, as they are currently four points behind them. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet played their 47th game of the season in a 2-0 win against Newcastle United, a record for appearances in the top five European leagues. Raheem Sterling scored the first goal, and Joe Allen scored the second after a defensive error. Henderson stated that after recent disappointing results, the team needed to put things right and that they will continue to win games and perform well to put pressure on Manchester City.

Roma ended a four-month winless streak at home by defeating Napoli in Serie A, with Miralem Pjanic scoring the decisive goal in the 25th minute after a counter-attack, and goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis making numerous saves in the second half. This victory moved Roma provisionally four points ahead of Lazio and extended Napoli's winless streak to five matches. Security was heightened for the match due to a previous incident, with residents of the Campania region barred from buying tickets and a large police presence, though no problems were reported. Roma played without injured captain Francesco Totti and Gervinho, while Napoli's Lorenzo Insigne made his return from injury.

Doncaster Rovers, currently in mid-table mediocrity in League One, played a goalless draw against Fleetwood Town. The match highlights video produced by Doncaster's media team was only 27 seconds long, with 14 seconds of actual match action, featuring just the kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

Roland Giroux has a remarkable relationship with his blood parrot cichlid, interacting with it by hand in its fish tank. He strokes and massages the fish, which remains still and appears to enjoy the sensation, even swimming up his arm and circling his fingers. Giroux began interacting with the fish by hand-feeding it bloodworms after removing two other fish that were bullying it. He found that the fish became more sociable and enjoyed being stroked daily, becoming frustrated if not played with. Giroux spends at least 15 minutes each day massaging and playing with his fish. The blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid first bred in Taiwan around 1986.

Ben Stokes, a fiery character in the England cricket team, has a history of channeling his aggression, including breaking his wrist punching a locker. He responded positively to a clash with Marlon Samuels after a discussion with coach Peter Moores, demonstrating a need for careful man-management to control his natural exuberance while still allowing him to be feisty. England wants Stokes to play as much as possible to reach his full potential, balancing his aggression with the need for runs and wickets, and they are excited about his development alongside other young players like Adil Rashid and Chris Jordan.

Wales' Euro 2016 qualifier against Belgium on June 12 at the Cardiff City Stadium is a 33,000 sell-out due to overwhelming demand, with the match featuring the top two teams in Group B, both having 11 points from five games. Wales' recent 3-0 victory over Israel has increased expectations for them to qualify for the 2016 finals in France, and the team prefers playing at the Cardiff City Stadium over the larger Millennium Stadium.

England coach John Peacock has announced his squad for the UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria, where the Young Lions are the defending champions. They qualified with a perfect record and are in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland, opening their campaign against Italy on May 7. The squad includes players from various Premier League clubs, such as Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo from Chelsea, and Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi from Arsenal, with Willock and Mavididi receiving their first call-ups. Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold from Liverpool have been recalled after missing the Elite Round qualifiers. England's other group matches are against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13.

Manchester City is interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered a top talent from Anderlecht's youth system and has also drawn interest from Arsenal and Barcelona. Patoulidis previously turned down Barcelona's La Masia academy at age 12 due to his family's preference for him to continue his education. Manchester City has engaged in discussions with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock regarding a compensation package, as manager Manuel Pellegrini aims to secure future talent.

Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old transgender escort from Mexico, was found strangled and beaten to death in a Fulham flat at the end of March. A 23-year-old man was arrested in connection with her death but has been bailed pending further questioning. Police are appealing for anyone who had contact with Miss Santillan in the hours before her death to come forward, as they investigate the circumstances surrounding her death, which occurred on March 28th.

A woman named Dawn, who has experienced seven miscarriages, appeared on The Jeremy Kyle show after a family friend, Jamie, stole £207 that she had saved for a gravestone for her deceased baby, Daniel James. A lie detector test confirmed Jamie's guilt, and he later confessed via Facebook, blaming his girlfriend Carol. Dawn expressed her devastation and feeling of betrayal, stating that the money was intended to honor her child.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, primarily women and children, along with the ill and elderly, with Arab tribal leaders helping to coordinate the release. The freed Yazidis were sent to Irbil, the Kurdish regional capital. This release follows previous releases of Yazidis by ISIS, who had previously displaced hundreds of thousands of minorities, including Yazidis, from their homes in northern Iraq. Yazidis, an ancient religious community of Kurdish descent, have faced persecution, with ISIS exhibiting particular cruelty, including slaughtering and enslaving Yazidi captives. International efforts, including airdrops and airstrikes, were launched in response to the humanitarian crisis caused by ISIS' actions.

Harry Kane, a Tottenham sensation who has broken into the first team and the England side, is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards. A new animation, produced by Copa90 using still photographs, features some of his best goals and celebrations from the season, including his 20th Premier League goal against Newcastle, a strike against Chelsea, a header against Arsenal, and his England debut goal. The video, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', was released before the awards ceremony where he is nominated alongside players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

Jamie Carragher believes Brendan Rodgers remains the right manager for Liverpool despite a trophy-less season and a likely failure to finish in the top four, citing the difficulty with new signings not yet settled. Carragher, who received a Beacon Award for his community work in Merseyside, emphasized that a manager's future shouldn't be solely determined by one game and that Rodgers' job is to identify team improvements and ensure successful signings for the next season.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his toy gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport because it resembled a prohibited item, specifically a replica or model gun, according to government regulations. The brightly colored toy, which fires sponge darts, was deemed a security risk by airport security officers, who also frisked the child. James's father, Phil, criticized the security checks as "ludicrous" and "over-zealous," but left the toy to avoid missing their flight to Lanzarote. Upon their return, James was bought a replacement toy gun. East Midlands Airport apologized for the inconvenience and stated they had offered to post the toy back, explaining that all items resembling prohibited items are not permitted through security.

A 31-year-old man named Rich, living in Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. He described himself as athletic, white, heavily tattooed, with brown hair and eyes, who doesn't drink, smoke, or do drugs, enjoys traveling, the outdoors, sports, fishing, and camping. He is 175cm tall, "WELL Endowed," owns property, makes good money, is successful, and loves cars, bikes, and is very independent. His requirements for a partner include loving pets, being a non-drinker and non-smoker (though he acknowledges this is a dream), being fit and attractive, enjoying the outdoors but also being a "princess when need to be," being reliable, honest, loyal, good around the house, good with their hands, a good cook, and great in bed. He offered free gym membership, a phone of the partner's choice, and potentially a company car, phone, and laptop. He also stated he is generous with his money and his partner would receive many benefits, with all reasonable offers considered, but former partners need not apply.

Football Association chairman Greg Dyke is seeking to implement radical changes to increase the number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to 12 and redefine "home-grown" as having trained in England for three years before the age of 18. This proposal faces opposition from the Premier League, but has received backing from five former England managers: Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren, who believe failure to adopt these changes will hinder England's progress and ability to win the World Cup. They highlight that only 36.8% of Premier League starters are eligible for England selection and that the pool of English talent at the top level is shrinking, despite the emergence of promising young players like Barkley, Sterling, and Kane, who are not being given sufficient opportunity.

Demelza Poldark has given birth to a baby daughter, with Ross Poldark gazing lovingly at their new child in the upcoming episode. Despite Ross marrying Demelza out of duty, his affection for her is evident. The passage notes that the timeline of Demelza's pregnancy is not convincing, with her going from eight months pregnant to giving birth very quickly, a rapid progression also seen in a previous pregnancy involving the character Elizabeth. Fans have commented on the show's accelerated pregnancy timelines on Twitter.

Leicester manager Nigel Pearson has advised his team to maintain composure and disregard their relegation competitors, emphasizing that their Premier League survival is dependent on their own performance. Following two consecutive victories, including a recent 3-2 win against West Brom with an injury-time goal from Jamie Vardy, Leicester remains at the bottom of the table but is now only three points from safety. Pearson wants the team to concentrate on their upcoming matches and avoid becoming overly optimistic due to the improved results.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara has set a record for the longest mammal migration ever recorded, swimming nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This journey surpassed the previous record held by a humpback whale. Scientists believe Varvara's extensive travel, which included visits to three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, suggests that some western gray whales may actually be eastern gray whales, potentially impacting the estimated population of the endangered western gray whale species.

Overnight, approximately 1,000 feet of seabed rose to the surface along the Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu, Hokkaido, Japan, creating a new stretch of coastline that is up to 50 feet high in some areas. Geologists attribute this emergence to a nearby landslide, possibly triggered by melting ice and snow, which caused a section of land to drop and pivot the underwater area upwards. The new landmass, measuring roughly 1,000-1,640 feet long and 100 feet wide, appeared without any audible sounds or tremors, surprising local residents. Authorities do not expect the landmass to expand further and have stated it is unrelated to earthquakes.

Gregory van der Wiel has denied reports that he plans to leave Paris Saint-Germain in the summer, stating his happiness with the club, city, and teammates, and expressing a desire to sign a new contract. Despite a recent disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc over being dropped for a Champions League match, Van der Wiel insists he is ready to play when called upon. However, the club's links with Barcelona's Dani Alves raise questions about whether Van der Wiel will have a choice in his future at PSG.

Carlos Tevez has expressed his desire to leave Juventus this summer to return to his former club Boca Juniors. Boca Juniors president Daniel Angelici confirmed they are close to a deal but stressed that Tevez must first terminate his contract with Juventus, which runs until 2016. Tevez, who has scored 17 goals this season and is the league's top scorer, joined Boca's youth academy in 1996 and previously played for them before moving to Corinthians in 2005. Juventus are reportedly accepting his decision to leave and are looking for replacements. Tevez's international manager, Tata Martino, stated that the move would not affect Tevez's future with the Argentina national team, as long as he continues to play well.

During an exciting Champions League match where Bayern Munich defeated Porto 6-1, manager Pep Guardiola tore a hole in his left trouser leg, revealing his underwear. The victory secured Bayern's place in the Champions League semi-finals with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and Robert Lewandowski. Guardiola joked about needing new trousers for the next game and also removed his suit blazer during the match.

A multi-vehicle crash involving three cars occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale, on Wednesday afternoon, involving ten people, including four children. A 40-year-old man and a five-year-old boy were airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital with chest and shoulder injuries and chest pain, respectively. A 27-year-old woman with arm injuries and a six-year-old girl with abdominal pain were also flown out. Six other individuals, including an infant and two young girls, were transported to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for further assessment, while a man sustained hand lacerations and two females were uninjured. Emergency crews freed one person trapped in a vehicle using hydraulic cutting gear, and the highway was closed with diversions in place south of Fernvale.

Arsenal playmaker Mesut Ozil received a new Apple Watch on Thursday, comparing it to Michael Knight's watch from Knight Rider. The watch ranges in price from £299 to £13,500 and will be released for general sale on Friday. Ozil, who has scored four goals in 25 matches this season, is expected to play in Arsenal's upcoming match against Chelsea. Arsenal midfielder Jack Wilshere has returned from injury and is considered by Ray Parlour to be the future of the club, provided he can maintain his fitness.

Referee Mark Clattenburg will officiate the Manchester derby between United and City at Old Trafford. Despite having sent off three players from United and City this season, Clattenburg has only shown two red cards in the Premier League this season, both to United players, Tyler Blackett and Luke Shaw. City captain Vincent Kompany was dismissed by Clattenburg during Belgium's Euro 2016 qualifier against Israel, resulting in his suspension for Belgium's match against Wales. Clattenburg is considered one of the Premier League's leading referees. The derby is significant as it could determine who finishes second in the league, with Manchester United currently a point ahead of Manchester City.

Outspoken MP Bob Katter has accused the Queensland Government of believing embattled MP Billy Gordon was 'a little black puppet on a string', suggesting they expected him to quit after accusations of domestic violence and admitting to a criminal past. Katter, who is of Lebanese descent and has experienced racism, stated he sympathized with Gordon's position and defended his use of the term "black puppet" by referencing his own experiences and the perceived racial overtones of the government's actions. Gordon was forced to quit the Queensland Labor Party but will remain in parliament as an independent, causing chaos for the government. Katter's statement has drawn criticism on social media for his choice of words.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Downers Grove, Illinois, born with cerebral palsy, is using dance videos to inspire others and challenge stereotypes about disabilities. Despite facing bullying and stares, Dayna aims to show that people with cerebral palsy are not fundamentally different and should not be treated as such. She has created multiple dancing videos, including one set to Taylor Swift's "Shake It Off," and has begun motivational speaking at local schools, highlighting her own achievements like walking and attending college, to encourage people to look beyond disabilities.

Orlando City, an MLS side coached by Adrian Heath and captained by Kaka, has expressed interest in Manchester United player Javier Hernandez, who has had a difficult loan spell at Real Madrid. Orlando City, with a large Latin-American fanbase, made enquiries about a deal last week. Hernandez is also of interest to eight European clubs, including Premier League sides Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, and Everton, as well as Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan, with Manchester United willing to sell for approximately £8 million. Meanwhile, Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to teenage prospect Andreas Pereira, who has attracted interest from Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord after rejecting United's initial offer.

A gang of at least three individuals set a white Dodge Charger on fire at a 76 Station in South Los Angeles early Saturday morning after an argument with the driver. The suspects attempted to carjack the driver, pulling out a gun, and then sprayed the car with gasoline before igniting it, with two passengers inside. While no one was injured, the car was completely ruined. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the incident as an arson, and the suspects are still at large, with surveillance video being used in the investigation.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor from Lamoni, Iowa, has surrendered his state license after admitting to accepting sex as payment for services and performing exorcisms on patients. He also recommended patients stop taking prescribed medication. Despite these actions, Manuel received outstanding patient satisfaction evaluations on HealthGrades.com, with three positive responses resulting in a perfect five out of five stars. He has pledged not to apply for reinstatement for at least 10 years and must prove that the circumstances leading to his license revocation no longer exist before he can resume practice.

The United States is complaining to Moscow after a Russian SU-27 Flanker fighter jet intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane in international airspace north of Poland over the Baltic Sea in an "unsafe and unprofessional manner" due to aggressive maneuvers and high speed. The Pentagon stated the claim that the U.S. plane's transponder was switched off was false, while Russia's Defense Ministry claimed the U.S. plane was flying toward the Russian border with its transponder off. This incident follows a similar encounter a year ago where a Russian jet flew within 100 feet of a U.S. RC-135U over the Sea of Okhotsk.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle, along with a gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools, was stolen overnight from a Salt Lake City hotel parking lot. The rifle was secured in a case with padlocks and chains inside the agent's car, which had its window frame pulled from the door. Police suspect the thief broke the window, used a rope to attach to the rifle case, and employed another vehicle's momentum to break it free. The stolen items, except for the rifle, were later found across the street. The theft occurred at the Marriott Springhill Suites, which lacks surveillance cameras, just days before President Obama's visit to Utah. The Secret Service was aware of the theft prior to the visit, but could not confirm if it led to increased security. The rifle's serial number has been entered into a national database, and police are investigating whether the agent's car was specifically targeted.

Luigi Costa, 71, is accused of murdering his elderly neighbour, Terrence Freebody, in July 2012 in Canberra. A forensic psychiatrist, Professor Paul Mullen, testified that Costa was likely suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse at the time, leading to a confused mental state where he may not have understood his actions or their consequences. Evidence supporting this includes Costa's fluctuating mood during triple 0 calls and a trail of faeces from the crime scene to the toilet. While the prosecutor suggested Costa feigned memory loss, Professor Mullen believes Costa had a declining mental state for a significant period leading up to the incident, which is crucial for the jury's verdict.

Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Ross Barkley's decision to take a penalty in their 1-0 win against Burnley, despite Leighton Baines having a superior penalty record. Barkley missed the 10th-minute spot-kick, which was saved by Burnley goalkeeper Tom Heaton. Martinez stated that Barkley showed responsibility and that he is happy to have multiple players capable of taking penalties. The incident brought back memories of a similar penalty miss by Kevin Mirallas against West Brom. Despite Barkley's miss, Kevin Mirallas scored the winning goal for Everton.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the ms Ryndam cruise ship in Puerto Rico, with the cruise line, Holland America Line, stating it appears to be a murder-suicide. The authorities, including the FBI, were notified and are investigating the incident, which was discovered by cleaning staff. The ship departed from Tampa, Florida, on March 29 for a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise and is currently docked in San Juan, Puerto Rico.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, has successfully guided Curacao to the second qualifying round of the 2018 World Cup in CONCACAF. Curacao defeated Montserrat 4-3 on aggregate, securing their advancement with a 2-2 draw in the second leg, where Charlton Vicento scored a late goal. Curacao will next play Cuba on June 8 and 16.

Esteban Cambiasso, who has won numerous major European competitions, believes that keeping Leicester City in the Premier League would be a significant achievement, comparable to winning a trophy. Despite Leicester being seven points adrift at the bottom of the table with eight games remaining, Cambiasso remains optimistic about their chances of survival, citing the team's effort and the remaining portion of the league season. He has enjoyed his time at Leicester, finding it a new challenge after a successful career at Inter Milan and a spell at Real Madrid, and is happy with his decision to join the club.

A 23-year-old mother named Gemma is at risk of being banned from seeing her two young children by her mother, Debbie. Debbie, who has been caring for the children since they were four months old, is concerned about Gemma's drinking, partying, and suspected theft of an iPad. Gemma admits to stealing from her mother in the past, and Debbie believes Gemma is not fit to care for the children, who refer to Debbie as "mum."

Sky Sports pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness agreed that Chelsea captain John Terry committed a foul on Manchester United striker Radamel Falcao during the build-up to Eden Hazard's opening goal. Terry's strong challenge from behind on Falcao, which involved an elbow to the back of his head, led to a loose ball that Cesc Fabregas collected, initiating the scoring move. The pundits felt that play should have been stopped due to Terry's rough tackle.

Lady Antebellum singer Hillary Scott's tour bus caught fire on Interstate 30 near Dallas, Texas, on Thursday morning after a rear tire blew out. Everyone on board, including Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver, was safely evacuated. The fire destroyed everything in the bus's back lounge except for Scott's Bible. The other two band members, Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood, were not on the bus. The band is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas, on Sunday.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is developing a system using space lasers to convert sunlight into energy, which could then be beamed back to Earth to power homes, potentially making solar power viable in Scotland and enabling instant power restoration to disaster-stricken areas. These lasers will not be as powerful as those depicted in science fiction, and are intended to boost the energy received by solar panels. While initial trials in Scotland were successful, Quarterman plans to move them to Portugal. This concept differs from a proposal by Tokyo researchers for a laser system on the International Space Station designed to clear space debris by pushing it into Earth's atmosphere, which would also not be powerful enough to be used as a weapon. Quarterman has, however, raised concerns about who would control his satellites.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile with a fixation on young girls, has escaped from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire. He was last seen on Tuesday evening and is described as approximately 5ft 8ins tall, of heavy build, with dark hair, and may have shaved his beard. Munden was detained under the Mental Health Act and a hospital order after being convicted of sexually touching a three-year-old girl and possessing indecent images of children. He has a history of learning difficulties and autism, and authorities are urgently seeking information on his whereabouts.

A Los Angeles judge has ordered V. Stiviano to repay over $2.6 million in gifts to Donald Sterling's wife, Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling, who sued Stiviano for targeting wealthy older men and using the couple's money. The gifts included luxury cars, a duplex, and smaller items like a blender and a thong. Donald Sterling's racist remarks, made in a recording where he criticized Stiviano for associating with black people, led to his ban from the NBA, a $2.5 million fine, and the termination of his ownership rights.

Thierry Henry has criticized Arsenal's transfer window activity and believes the club needs to sign four top players in the summer: a goalkeeper, centre back, defensive midfielder, and a striker, to compete for the Premier League title. He also expressed doubt that Arsenal can win the league with Olivier Giroud as their primary striker, despite Giroud's 14 league goals this season. Henry cited Chelsea's successful signings of Courtois, Matic, Fabregas, and Costa as an example of what Arsenal needs to do.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is nearing a return to action after being sidelined for over a year due to a serious knee injury sustained in March 2014. He recently played 90 minutes for Arsenal Under 21s against Reading, marking his second full match in a week, and has expressed that he is feeling "better and better" and is over his injury concerns. Gnabry had impressed for the Gunners in the previous season before his progress was halted by the injury.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant, died after falling 70ft down a cliff in Penarth, South Wales, while attempting to evade paying a taxi fare. He had been out with friends in Cardiff and, lacking sufficient funds for the journey home, ran from the taxi. The driver pursued, but Phillips disappeared into the darkness and fell over the cliff at the end of the disused Northern Promenade. His body was discovered the following day by a dog walker. The coroner recorded a verdict of accidental death, noting that Phillips was likely disoriented and unaware of the danger posed by the cliff in the dark.

Thousands of holidaymakers experienced passport delays last summer, with many not receiving compensation despite the Passport Office making a £42 million profit. Ministers refused a blanket refund for those who paid for expedited services or missed trips. Only 2,191 compensation applications were approved between April and January, with a total payout of £203,066. Managers at the Passport Office received bonuses totaling £1.8 million in 2013-14, with individual bonuses reaching up to £3,500.

A 1930s home in Horfield, Bristol, is for sale, remaining unchanged for over 80 years and featuring original elements such as stained-glass windows, oil-fired central heating, original bathroom and kitchen fixtures, wood-panelled hallways, and vintage cupboards. The three-bedroom semi-detached property, described as a collector's paradise, has a guide price of £200,000 to £250,000 and includes original tins of produce on a hallway shelf. While double glazing has been installed, the potential cost of renovations might deter developers, but it is seen as a perfect family home for antique enthusiasts. The house will be auctioned on April 30.

Colin Kaepernick became the 49ers' starting quarterback in the middle of the 2012 season after Alex Smith sustained a concussion, leading the team to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens.
Soul Food is a 1997 American comedy-drama film produced by Kenneth "Babyface" Edmonds, Tracey Edmonds, and Robert Teitel, and released by Fox 2000 Pictures.

Anne Rice was born in New Orleans and spent much of her early life there before moving to Texas and then San Francisco. Route 495 is a 3.45-mile freeway in Hudson County, New Jersey, connecting the New Jersey Turnpike to New York State Route 495 within the Lincoln Tunnel, offering access to Midtown Manhattan.
Telemundo is an American Spanish-language terrestrial television network owned by Comcast through NBCUniversal, specifically NBCUniversal Telemundo Enterprises.

Damon Albarn, raised in East London and Essex, attended Stanway School where he met Graham Coxon and formed Blur. Blur's debut album, *Leisure*, was released in 1991 to mixed reviews. The band, influenced by various genres including alternative rock, trip hop, hip hop, electronica, dub, reggae, and pop music, achieved worldwide success with their self-titled debut album in 2001. Albarn's solo studio album, *Everyday Robots*, co-produced by Richard Russell, was released on April 28, 2014, and included collaborations with Brian Eno, Natasha Khan, and the Leytonstone City Pentecostal Mission Church Choir, as well as samples of Lord Buckley's rants.
Mogadishu, also known as Hamar, is the capital and most populous city of Somalia, and it serves as the location for many important national institutions.
"Happiness in Slavery" is a song by American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails, featured on their debut extended play (EP), *Broken*, released in 1992.
Andrew Kevin Walker, born August 14, 1964, is an American screenwriter who has been nominated for a BAFTA.

The film "Shooter" (2007) features Mark Wahlberg as Bob Lee Swagger, a Force Recon veteran framed for murder by a rogue private military company. The TV series "Shooter" stars Ryan Phillippe as Bob Lee Swagger, an expert marksman in exile who is drawn back into action to prevent a plot to assassinate the president.
House (also called House, M.D.) is an American television medical drama that aired on the Fox network for eight seasons, from November 16, 2004, to May 21, 2012.

Charles Manson was found guilty of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder in 1971 for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate, all of whom were killed by members of his group at his direction. He also received first-degree murder convictions for the deaths of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. Following his charges, commercial releases of songs written and performed by Manson became available.

Sean Justin Penn, born August 17, 1960, is an American actor, filmmaker, and political activist who began his acting career in television and film in the early 1980s. He gained critical attention for his roles in crime dramas and became a prominent leading actor with "Dead Man Walking," earning his first Academy Award nomination and a Best Actor Award at the Berlin Film Festival. Penn received two more Oscar nominations before winning his first Academy Award for Best Actor in 2003 for "Mystic River" and a second in 2008 for "Milk."

Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman, also known as "The Don," was an Australian cricketer born on August 27, 1908, and died on February 25, 2001. He is widely recognized as the greatest batsman in history and remained influential in cricket for thirty years after retiring by serving as an administrator, selector, and writer.
L.A. Reid has held executive positions at major record labels, including chairman and CEO of Epic Records, president and CEO of Arista Records, and chairman and CEO of the Island Def Jam Music Group.

Brad Wilk is best known as the drummer for the rock bands Rage Against the Machine and Audioslave. He began his drumming career with Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage in August 1991. As of 2016, he is a member of the band Prophets of Rage. Rage, a German heavy metal band formed in 1984, is mentioned in relation to Wilk's career.

The multi-camera series "The Millers" aired on CBS from October 3, 2013, to July 18, 2015, spanning two seasons and a total of 34 episodes. CBS announced the cancellation of the show on November 14, 2014, during its second season, after four episodes had aired.

Ann Richards served as the 45th Governor of Texas from 1991 to 1995, a Democrat who gained national attention as the state treasurer and keynote speaker at the 1988 Democratic National Convention. She was the second female governor of Texas and was known for her outspoken feminism and one-liners, ultimately being defeated for re-election in 1994 by George W. Bush. The passage also mentions another Ann Richards, a jazz singer and wife of Stan Kenton.
Drake Bell released an EP titled A Reminder independently in 2011.

Boardwalk is a 1979 American drama film written by Stephen Verona and Leigh Chapman and directed by Verona. Janet Leigh, an American actress, singer, dancer, and author, wrote four books between 1984 and 2002, including two novels.

Simón José Antonio de la Santísima Trinidad Bolívar y Palacios, known as El Libertador, was a Venezuelan military and political leader who was instrumental in the establishment of Venezuela, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, Peru, and Panama as sovereign states, free from Spanish rule.
The Bermuda Triangle, also called the Devil's Triangle, is an area in the western North Atlantic Ocean where many aircraft and ships have reportedly vanished mysteriously.

Colin Kaepernick started his professional career as a backup but became the 49ers' starting quarterback in the middle of the 2012 season after Alex Smith sustained a concussion. He led the team to their first Super Bowl appearance since 1994, where they lost to the Baltimore Ravens. In the 2013 season, his first full year as a starter, Kaepernick helped the 49ers reach the NFC Championship, losing to the Seattle Seahawks.
Marnie is a 1964 American psychological thriller film directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

Advertising is an openly sponsored, nonpersonal audio or visual marketing communication used to promote or sell a product, service, or idea. It differs from personal selling because its message is not directed to a specific individual. Advertising is disseminated through various mass media, encompassing both traditional forms like newspapers, television, and radio, as well as newer channels such as search results, blogs, and text messages.
Private Lives is a 1930 comedy of manners in three acts by Noël Coward, and also a 1931 American Pre-Code comedy film directed by Sidney Franklin.

Maurice Harold Macmillan, 1st Earl of Stockton, was a British Conservative politician and statesman who served as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom from January 10, 1957, to October 19, 1963. He was born on February 10, 1894, and died on December 29, 1986.

Aristotle was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist born in Stagira, Chalkidice. He joined Plato's Academy in Athens at seventeen or eighteen and stayed until around 347 BC. After Plato's death, Aristotle tutored Alexander the Great at the request of Philip II of Macedon, starting in 343 BC.

David Mordechai Packouz, born February 16, 1982, is an American former arms dealer, musician, inventor, and entrepreneur. He invented the BeatBuddy, a guitar pedal drum machine, and is currently the CEO of Singular Sound, a music technology company.

Magic Johnson played point guard for the Lakers for 13 seasons, winning championships in high school and college before being drafted first overall in the 1979 NBA draft. He secured a championship and NBA Finals MVP in his rookie year, followed by four more championships in the 1980s. After a four-year retirement due to player protests, he returned at age 36 for 32 games in 1996 before his final retirement. Johnson is also recognized as an influential black businessman with various business interests and was a part-owner of the Lakers.

Tenacious D is an American comedy rock duo formed in Los Angeles, California in 1994, consisting of Jack Black and Kyle Gass. They have released three albums: Tenacious D (2001), The Pick of Destiny (2006), and Rize of the Fenix (2012). The duo gained popularity in 1997 through their television series and by supporting major rock acts.

James VI and I, born June 19, 1566, and died March 27, 1625, reigned as King of Scotland as James VI from July 24, 1567, and as King of England and Ireland as James I from March 24, 1603, until his death. During his rule, Scotland and England remained separate sovereign states with their own institutions, though united under James. He strongly supported a unified parliament for both nations, achieving success in Scotland but encountering significant challenges in England, such as the Gunpowder Plot in 1605 and ongoing disputes with the English Parliament.

Big Brother 2017, also known as Big Brother 18, is the upcoming eighteenth series of the British reality television series Big Brother, hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley. Marcus Bentley, born October 4, 1967, is a British actor, broadcaster, and voice-over artist most famous for narrating the UK's version of Big Brother since 2000. He also did continuity announcements for Channel 4 until July 2011, when he moved to Channel 5 to continue narrating the revived Big Brother. Bentley's voice-over work and Geordie accent have made him one of Britain's most recognized voices.

The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked federal state of Germany, bordered by Brandenburg, Saxony Anhalt, Thuringia, Bavaria, Poland, and the Czech Republic. It is the tenth largest and sixth most populous of Germany's sixteen states, with an area of 18,413 km2 and 4 million people. Saxony is also a region for quality wine in Germany, and along with Saale-Unstrut, it is one of the northernmost wine regions in Europe and the only two of Germany's 13 wine regions located in the former East Germany.
East End Park was a former major league baseball park in Cincinnati, and "In the End" is a song by Linkin Park.
Mel B. Brown started her solo career with the release of "I Want You Back" featuring Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.
Noah Cyrus is the youngest daughter of Billy Ray Cyrus and the younger sister of Miley Cyrus and Trace Cyrus.

Mohra is a 1994 Indian action thriller film directed by Rajiv Rai, starring Akshay Kumar, Sunil Shetty, Raveena Tandon, and Naseeruddin Shah. It was released on July 1, 1994, and became the second highest-grossing Indian film of that year. The film received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. Raveena Tandon replaced Divya Bharti in the female lead role after Bharti's death. The film is also noted for its popular songs.
"Hourglass" is a song by British electronic duo Disclosure, and it is also the fourteenth studio album by singer-songwriter James Taylor.

Shane Black, born December 16, 1961, is an American screenwriter, director, producer, and actor. He is recognized for writing the 1987 film *Lethal Weapon* and for his directorial debut with *Kiss Kiss Bang Bang* in 2005.
A View to a Kill (1985) is the fourteenth James Bond film and the seventh and final one starring Roger Moore as James Bond.
Papua is Indonesia's largest and easternmost province, encompassing the majority of western New Guinea. Previously known as Irian Jaya, it once included all of Indonesian New Guinea.
Augustus likely died of natural causes, though unconfirmed rumors suggest his wife Livia may have poisoned him.

Jennifer Lopez entered the music industry in 1999 with her debut album *On the 6*, featuring the single "If You Had My Love." In 2001, she made history by having a number one album (*J.Lo*) and film (*The Wedding Planner*) released in the same week. Her third album, *This Is Me... Then* (2002), was influenced by her relationship with Ben Affleck, which also overshadowed the film *Gigli*. After marrying Marc Anthony, she had box office success with *Shall We Dance?* and gave birth to twins in 2008. Lopez regained prominence in 2011 as a judge on *American Idol* and with her hit single "On the Floor."

Working animals are typically domesticated animals trained by humans to perform tasks, ranging from being close family members like assistance dogs to providing tractive force such as draft horses or logging elephants, and also used for milking or herding. While wild animals can occasionally be trained for work, it's usually for novelty or entertainment due to their lack of trustworthiness and mild temper compared to domesticated working animals.

Billboard Dad is a 1998 American direct-to-video comedy film starring Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen, directed by Alan Metter. Billboard magazine publishes Top Latin Albums, considered the most important chart for Spanish language, full-length albums in the American music market, and the Regional Mexican Albums, a genre-specific record chart in the United States.

Global warming poses significant threats to humans, including jeopardizing food security through declining crop yields and forcing the abandonment of populated areas due to rising sea levels.
The 2008 film Australia, directed by Baz Luhrmann, is an Australian-American-British romantic historical adventure drama starring Nicole Kidman and Hugh Jackman.
Michael Vick, born June 26, 1980, is a former American football quarterback who played 13 seasons in the NFL, mainly for the Atlanta Falcons and Philadelphia Eagles.

Canadian folklore encompasses a variety of traditions including songs, legends, jokes, rhymes, proverbs, weather lore, superstitions, and practices like traditional food and craft-making. Oral traditions are a significant part of this, featuring tales, proverbs, and jokes.
The First Motion Picture Unit produced over 400 propaganda and training films that were both informative and entertaining, and also trained combat cameramen.

The passage describes two individuals named James Jones: an author who won the 1952 National Book Award for his novel *From Here to Eternity*, which was adapted into a film and a television series, and a basketball player who averaged 25 points per game as a senior, earned Class 6A Player of the Year and First Team All-State honors, won three NBA championships (two with the Heat and one with the Cavaliers), reached the NBA Finals for the seventh consecutive year with LeBron James in 2017, finished third in the NBA in three-point percentage in the 2007-08 season, and won the Three-Point Contest in 2011.
Humphrey Bogart was ranked as the greatest male star of Classic American cinema by the American Film Institute in 1999.

Trollhunters is an American computer-animated fantasy television series created for Netflix by Guillermo del Toro and produced by DreamWorks Animation and Double Dare You, utilizing computer animation, which is the process for generating animated images.
Shane McMahon resigned from WWE, with his resignation taking effect on January 1, 2010.

Tom Baker is an English actor recognized for his role as the fourth Doctor in Doctor Who from 1974 to 1981, which was the longest tenure for any actor in that role. He is also known for narrating the comedy series Little Britain and has provided narration for commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.
Angelsberg is a small town located in the commune of Fischbach, in central Luxembourg.

The Hanford Site hosts the Columbia Generating Station, a commercial nuclear power plant, and research centers like the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory and the LIGO Hanford Observatory, in addition to a cleanup project.

The White House Press Secretary is a senior official who serves as the spokesperson for the U.S. executive branch, particularly concerning the President, senior executives, and policies. Appointed by and serving at the pleasure of the President, this prominent non-Cabinet position does not require Senate confirmation, but its frequent media briefings make it highly visible to the public.

Kentucky, known as the "Bluegrass State" due to its fertile soil and the bluegrass found in its pastures, has a major region called the Bluegrass Region in central Kentucky, which contains its major cities, Louisville and Lexington. The state is also recognized for horse racing, bourbon distilleries, coal, the historic site My Old Kentucky Home, automobile manufacturing, tobacco, bluegrass music, college basketball, and Kentucky Fried Chicken.
Broken Bridges is a 2006 film featuring Toby Keith, Lindsey Haun, Burt Reynolds, and Kelly Preston, who also appeared in The Cat in the Hat and Old Dogs.
Kesha Rose Sebert, born March 1, 1987, is an American singer, songwriter, and rapper, formerly stylized as Ke$ha.
On May 5, 2017, two versions of "Despacito" were released: an electronic version by Major Lazer and DJ MOSKA, and an urban version produced by Sky.

Starrcade was an annual professional wrestling event held from 1983 to 2000 by the NWA and later WCW, originally broadcast via closed-circuit television and then pay-per-view. In 1987, Starrcade began broadcasting on pay-per-view, the first NWA event to do so, following the WWF's scheduling of Survivor Series. The WWE Network added Starrcades from 1983-1986 to its pay-per-view section in 2014, rating them TV-MA due to violence. Starrcade (1997) was the fifteenth annual event.
Veeru Devgan is an Indian stunt and action choreographer and film director in Bollywood.
Star Trek: Discovery is the first series developed specifically for its streaming service and the first Star Trek series since Star Trek: Enterprise ended in 2005.

Terry Crews played as a defensive end and linebacker in the NFL for the Los Angeles Rams, San Diego Chargers, and Washington Redskins, and also played in the World League of American Football with Rhein Fire.

Excuse My French is the debut studio album by American rapper French Montana. It is also the title of a 2014 Egyptian comedy film directed by Amr Salama, which is based on his experiences at a public middle school in Egypt after returning from Saudi Arabia. Benjamin Paul Ballance-Drew, also known as Plan B or Ben Drew, is a British hip hop recording artist, actor, film director, and producer.

A floppy disk, also known as a floppy, diskette, or disk, is a type of disk storage. It consists of a thin, flexible magnetic storage medium enclosed in a rectangular plastic casing lined with fabric to remove dust.

Guatemala faced chronic instability and civil strife from the mid to late 19th century. Between 1960 and 1996, the country endured a civil war between the US-backed government and leftist rebels, which included genocidal massacres of the Maya population by the military.
Forceps are handheld, hinged instruments used for grasping and holding objects, and are commonly referred to as tweezers, tongs, pliers, clips, or clamps outside of medicine.
The series "The Closer" began its seventh and final season on Monday, July 11, 2011, after concluding its sixth season as cable's highest-rated drama.

Dr. Jack Shephard, portrayed by Matthew Fox, is the protagonist of the ABC television series Lost, which aired from September 22, 2004, to May 23, 2010, spanning six seasons and 121 episodes, with the first season averaging approximately 16 million viewers per episode on ABC.

Matthew McConaughey, born November 4, 1969, is an American actor who has favored dramatic roles since 2011, appearing in films such as The Lincoln Lawyer, Bernie, Killer Joe, The Paperboy, Mud, Magic Mike, The Wolf of Wall Street, Dallas Buyers Club, Interstellar, The Sea of Trees, and Free State of Jones. The 2012 film Mud stars McConaughey alongside Tye Sheridan, Jacob Lofland, Sam Shepard, and Reese Witherspoon.

Robert Palmer was a writer known for his books, music journalism for The New York Times and Rolling Stone, producing blues recordings and the soundtrack for the film Deep Blues, and his clarinet playing in the 1960s band The Insect Trust.

James Lincoln de la Mothe Borglum, an American sculptor, photographer, author, and engineer, was born on April 9, 1912, and died on January 27, 1986.
