He is primarily recognized for completing the Mount Rushmore National Memorial following the death of his father, Gutzon Borglum, who had led the project from 1927 to 1941. Lincoln Borglum assumed leadership of the construction after his father's passing in March 1941.

Underdog is a film directed by Frederik Du Chau and written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams. It stars Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, with voice talents from Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

The 100 is a TV series that follows a group of teens, including Clarke Griffin, Bellamy Blake, and Octavia Blake, who are among the first people from a space habitat called "The Ark" to return to Earth after a nuclear apocalypse. The series also focuses on characters from The Ark, such as Dr. Abby Griffin, Clarke's mother, council member Marcus Kane, and Chancellor Thelonious Jaha, who is Wells' father.

The Concert for Bangladesh is recognized as a highly successful and influential humanitarian aid project that generated awareness and considerable funds, despite subsequent financial problems due to its pioneering nature. It provided valuable lessons and inspiration for later projects, such as Live Aid.
Mani Ratnam is recognized by the media as one of India's influential filmmakers, credited with revolutionizing the Tamil film industry and changing the profile of Indian cinema.

The Freeport Doctrine was articulated by Stephen A. Douglas on August 27, 1858, during the second of the Lincoln-Douglas Debates. These seven debates between Abraham Lincoln and Stephen Douglas, the Republican and Democratic candidates for the U.S. Senate from Illinois respectively, were significant due to the national importance of the issue of slavery.

Easy A is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck and written by Bert V. Royal, starring Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice, born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien on October 4, 1941, is an American author known for gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. Her writing career started with "Interview with the Vampire" in 1976, and she continued writing sequels in the 1980s, gaining popularity with critics and readers during that decade. She was married to Stan Rice, a poet and painter, for 41 years until his death in 2002.

Camden is a city in Camden County, New Jersey, with a population of 77,344 as of the 2010 United States Census, making it the 12th most populous municipality in New Jersey. At the start of the twentieth century, its population was primarily composed of European immigrants.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for the 2013 American erotic thriller-drama film *The Canyons*, which was directed by Paul Schrader.

The Lincoln-Douglas Debates, also known as The Great Debates of 1858, were a series of seven debates held in seven towns across Illinois between Republican candidate Abraham Lincoln and incumbent Democratic Senator Stephen Douglas for the United States Senate seat from Illinois.

Homer is the name given by ancient Greeks to the author of the Iliad and the Odyssey, which are central works of ancient Greek literature. The Thicket is a mystery/suspense novel by American author Joe R. Lansdale.
Christopher Scott Kyle, born April 8, 1974, was a United States Navy SEAL veteran and sniper who was murdered by Eddie Ray Routh on February 2, 2013, at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas.

Audioslave was a four-piece band featuring Chris Cornell, Tom Morello, Tim Commerford, and Brad Wilk. Brad Wilk is known as the drummer for Rage Against the Machine and Audioslave, and also plays in Prophets of Rage with Commerford and Morello. Rage Against the Machine, formed in 1991, consists of Zack de la Rocha, Tim Commerford, Tom Morello, and Brad Wilk.

Janelle Monáe Robinson, born December 1, 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model. She is signed to Wondaland Arts Society and Atlantic Records. In 2010, she released her first full-length studio album, The ArchAndroid, a concept album and sequel to her first EP, which was released by Bad Boy Records.
Winter's Tale is a 1983 novel by Mark Helprin.

Lake Providence is the parish seat of East Carroll Parish in northeastern Louisiana. The University of Mississippi has about 55 percent of its undergraduates and 60 percent overall coming from Mississippi, with 23 percent being minorities and international students from 90 nations.
The series "Flaked" was renewed for a six-episode second season in July 2016, with a premiere date set for June 2, 2017.
Aaron Burr served in the New York State Assembly twice, was appointed New York State Attorney General, and was a U.S. senator from New York before reaching the apex of his career as vice president.

The Soyuz is a series of spacecraft designed by the Korolyov Design Bureau in the 1960s for the Soviet space program, succeeding the Voskhod spacecraft and originally built for Soviet manned lunar programs. It was commissioned to launch Soyuz spacecraft, initially with 8 unmanned test flights and then 19 manned launches, and remains in service today.
Steve Ditko studied under Jerry Robinson, the artist for Batman, at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine's fourth studio album, Renegades, was released on December 5, 2000. The band broke up the same year due to growing tensions, with frontman de la Rocha starting a solo career and the remaining members forming Audioslave with Chris Cornell. Audioslave released three albums before disbanding in 2007, the same year Rage Against the Machine reunited and performed at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival.

The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as the BSE 30 or SENSEX, is a free-float market-weighted stock market index comprising 30 well-established and financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange. Tata Motors is one such company, listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange, and is a constituent of the BSE SENSEX index, as well as being listed on the National Stock Exchange of India and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is the easternmost country on the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia, with an estimated 92.7 million inhabitants, making it the world's 14th-most-populous country and ninth-most-populous Asian country. It shares borders with China, Laos, Cambodia, and Thailand, and is separated from the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia by the South China Sea. Since 2000, Vietnam has experienced high economic growth rates, ranking highest in the Global Growth Generators Index in 2011 among 11 major economies, and it remains one of the world's four remaining one-party socialist states officially espousing communism.
Dreamer is a 2005 American sports drama film written and directed by John Gatins.

Bhagat Singh was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary who became a folk hero of the Indian independence movement due to his dramatic acts of violence against the British and his execution at age 23.
Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut in the 2016 Indian Hindi-language biographical sports drama film "Dangal," directed by Nitesh Tiwari.

James VI and I, born June 19, 1566, and died March 27, 1625, reigned as King of Scotland as James VI from July 24, 1567, and as King of England and Ireland as James I from March 24, 1603, until his death. During his rule, Scotland and England remained separate sovereign states with their own institutions, though united under his personal rule. He was a strong proponent of a unified parliament for both nations and encountered significant parliamentary challenges during his English reign.

Danielle Cormack, born December 26, 1970, is a New Zealand stage and screen actress. She was an original cast member of Shortland Street and is recognized for her roles as Ephiny in Xena: Warrior Princess, Cynthia Ross in The Cult, and Shota in Legend of the Seeker. Her other credits include the film Separation City, the Australian series Rake, and portraying Kate Leigh in Underbelly: Razor. Cormack's most recent significant work was her four-year role as Bea Smith in the Foxtel prison drama Wentworth, departing in 2016.
Rob Sheridan, born October 11, 1979, is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer recognized for his significant contributions to the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade starred and co-starred in films such as Tommy Boy, Black Sheep, Joe Dirt, Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser, Grown Ups, and Grown Ups 2. Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser is a 2015 American comedy film directed by Fred Wolf and written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett, born August 16, 1958, is an American actress.

Artpop, an album that received mixed reviews from music critics, achieved commercial success by debuting at number one on the United States Billboard 200 with 258,000 first-week sales, marking Gaga's second consecutive number-one album in the US. It sold a total of 757,000 copies in the US and was the ninth best-selling album globally in 2013, with 2.3 million copies sold worldwide.

John Frusciante's fifth and final album with the Chili Peppers, *Stadium Arcadium*, was released in 2006. He confirmed his departure from the band in 2009, making *Stadium Arcadium* the group's last album to feature him as guitarist.

Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister, implemented policies known as Thatcherism. She remains a controversial figure, lauded as one of Britain's greatest and most influential politicians, despite ongoing arguments about Thatcherism.
Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan, born February 5, 1964, is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author who has also written weekly columns for SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker is an English actor who has also narrated commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia and the third largest city in Spain, with approximately 800,000 inhabitants in its administrative center. It also boasts the third largest metropolitan area in Spain, with a population between 1.7 and 2.5 million. The Valencian Community, also known as the Valencian Country, is an autonomous community within Spain.
Buffy Summers was portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
The series "Make It or Break It" concluded on April 26, 2012, with its third season being the final one. The series finale was broadcast on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition (SR) is an inter-disciplinary sub-field of computational linguistics that focuses on developing technologies for computers to recognize and translate spoken language into text, drawing from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Its applications are diverse, including voice user interfaces for tasks like voice dialing and call routing, controlling home appliances, searching for spoken content, data entry, preparing structured documents, speech-to-text processing for word processors and emails, and aircraft control. The field's progress is marked by a rise in academic publications and, significantly, by the widespread industry adoption of deep learning methods by major tech companies such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, and Amazon in their SR systems.

Richard Alf, born January 26, 1952, and deceased January 4, 2012, was an American businessman and former comic book store owner. He co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International, initially named the Golden State Comic Book Convention in 1970, and served as its chairman starting that same year. Other co-founders included Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry. The convention was later renamed the "San Diego Comic Book Convention."
Fist of Legend is a remake of the 1972 film Fist of Fury, which starred Bruce Lee.

France's Dubuisson shot a 67 to tie with South Africa's Van Zyl at 16 under par, while McIlroy also carded a 67, reaching 15 under par alongside Thailand's Kiradech Aphibarnrat. McIlroy's round featured an eagle on the 12th, and he expressed confidence in his ability to shoot a low round. Despite an earlier setback with his putter, McIlroy recovered with a birdie and an eagle. Having previously injured his ankle, McIlroy is aiming for his third Race to Dubai title and currently leads Danny Willett in points. English golfers Chris Wood and Richard Bland are in fifth and seventh place respectively.

Sheikh Ali Salman believes that for national dialogue to be meaningful, the government must offer concrete solutions and that a representative of the royal family should be involved. He sees Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa as a reformist, while Prime Minister Sheikh Khalifa bin Salman al-Khalifa and hardliners oppose dialogue, fearing increased opposition demands. Sheikh Salman emphasizes the necessity of dialogue and negotiations, acknowledging that some young protesters have lost faith in opposition parties due to the government's actions. He highlights a previously agreed-upon seven-point plan between the crown prince and the opposition that aimed for a constitutional monarchy, which was interrupted by the arrival of GCC troops. Regarding US policy, Sheikh Salman hopes that Senator John Kerry will be more active in pressuring for human rights and democratic practices. He criticizes the UK's approach, stating that private urgings for reform are insufficient and public pressure is needed. Sheikh Salman reiterates the call for peaceful demonstrations as the only means of pressuring the government and demands the release of imprisoned opposition leaders and activists, stating that their exclusion from dialogue will lead to its failure.

Christopher Hogwood, a highly influential figure in the early-music movement and founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), has died at his home in Cambridge after a months-long illness. He directed the AAM for approximately 30 years, during which they produced over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Hogwood also held various academic positions and artistic directorships, and is remembered for his generosity, academic prowess, and dedication to historically informed music.

In the year ending March, Scotland recorded 57 homicide victims, a decrease of five from the previous year, marking the lowest number since 1976 and half the figure from nine years prior. As of March 31, 2016, only one homicide case from 2015-16 remained unresolved. Sharp instruments were the most common method of killing, accounting for 51% of homicides, with knives involved in most of these cases. Thirty-one percent of accused individuals were identified as being under the influence of alcohol or drugs. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson highlighted the need for continued efforts in education and enforcement to address violent crime, while Scottish Labour's justice spokeswoman Claire Baker urged caution due to past revisions of figures and pointed to a 45-year high in sexual crime and a 27% increase in attempted murder and serious assault.

Bournemouth lost 2-1 to Sunderland, marking Sunderland's first Premier League win of the season. Dan Gosling scored Bournemouth's first goal in three games, but Sunderland secured the win with goals from Victor Anichebe and a Jermain Defoe penalty. Despite creating numerous chances and playing against 10 men after Steven Pienaar's dismissal, Bournemouth failed to equalize. Manager Howe expressed frustration at the team's inability to convert chances, stating they had enough opportunities to win three games.

Australia's policy of detaining migrants arriving by boat and sending them to offshore processing camps to be resettled elsewhere is described by the New York Times as "brutal," "inhumane, of dubious legality and strikingly at odds with the country's tradition of welcoming people fleeing persecution and war." Prime Minister Mr. Abbott stated that the only way to prevent deaths at sea is to "stop the boats," referencing the tragic death of Alan Kurdi as a reason to stop drownings. Mr. Abbott also drew criticism from Australian Jewish groups for comparing the Islamic State (IS) to the Nazis, stating that IS "boast about their evil," while the Nazis "had a sufficient sense of shame to try to hide it." The Executive Council of Australian Jewry responded that IS crimes, while horrific, cannot be compared to the systematic genocide implemented by a state. Mr. Abbott later clarified he was not "in the business of ranking evil."

The United States has suspended bilateral talks with Russia regarding the Syrian conflict, blaming Russia and the Syrian government for intensifying attacks on civilians, particularly in Aleppo. Russia regrets the US decision and accuses the US of shifting blame for the collapse of a previous truce. Aleppo has experienced heavy bombardment since the ceasefire ended, with the main trauma hospital in the rebel-held east being hit multiple times. Hundreds, including children, have died during the Syrian government's offensive to retake Aleppo, where approximately 250,000 people are trapped in the eastern part. The US cited Russia's failure to uphold commitments, its inability to ensure Syrian regime adherence, and the targeting of critical infrastructure like hospitals and humanitarian aid convoys as reasons for suspending the talks. Russia denies involvement in the aid convoy strike, attributing it to ground fire, and claims the US failed to separate jihadist groups from the moderate opposition. While the US is withdrawing personnel and canceling meetings in Geneva, both sides will continue discussions on counter-terrorism operations to prevent clashes.

A report by think tank Policy Exchange, backed by Downing Street, suggests selling vacant high-value social homes could raise £4.5bn annually, potentially funding 80,000 to 170,000 social homes and reducing the waiting list by 500,000. Policy Exchange defines expensive social housing as properties worth more than the average in their region, estimating 21.8% of the total stock, or 816,000 properties, could be worth up to £159bn if sold. While the prime minister's spokesman stated councils can already do this and should use stock efficiently, Labour criticized the idea, arguing it would displace low-wage families and worsen the housing crisis, proposing instead a bank bonus tax to fund affordable homes. Critics warn the policy could create segregated communities, pushing less well-off individuals out of affluent areas.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, 25, died at his home in Swansea, a city experiencing a measles epidemic with 942 cases. While laboratory tests confirmed a measles diagnosis, an examination could not establish it as the main cause of death, and further tests are pending. Mr. Colfer-Williams had recently been treated for asthma at Morriston Hospital and developed a rash after his discharge. He was found dead at his flat the morning after visiting an out-of-hours GP. Since November, 83 people have required hospital treatment for measles.

Vincent Hudson, 54, of Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, has been charged by Cumbria Police with a historical offence on a boy under the age of 16, which was reported to have taken place in 2001. He is scheduled to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

Guiseley took the lead against Gateshead on 15 minutes through Jake Lawlor, but Gateshead equalized in the 62nd minute with a goal from Wes York. The match ended in a 1-1 draw, with both teams having recent unbeaten streaks. Gateshead's Liam Hogan blocked a Jordan Preston effort, and Guiseley's Jonny Maxted saved a shot from Wesley York. Several substitutions were made by both teams during the match, and Gus Mafuta and Simon Walton received yellow cards.

Bristol Sport Ltd plans to redevelop two stands at their football ground to increase capacity, as an alternative to building a new stadium at Ashton Vale, which has been delayed. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown confirmed work would begin in May if there is no judicial review by March, following approval from Bristol City Council in November. The club is awaiting the signing of a section 106 agreement, after which there will be a six-week judicial review period.

Cuadrilla has suspended shale gas drilling operations in Lancashire after a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months, following a similar event on April 1st. The company is examining data from the British Geological Survey (BGS) before deciding whether to resume, with the process of fracking involving shattering underground rocks to release gas. Environmental concerns have been raised, particularly regarding potential water contamination, but a UK parliamentary committee has suggested that tight regulation and good industry practice could mitigate these issues. The BGS is monitoring fracking and has noted that injecting pressurized water into rocks can cause earthquakes, with the recent tremors occurring near the drilling site and sharing similar characteristics.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old piper from Liverpool, was found guilty of one count of fraud after playing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes in April 2015, while being cleared of two other counts. The prosecution alleged he gave the impression he was collecting cash for the campaign, but Carpenter claimed he was simply busking and the banner was a tribute. The chairman of the Hillsborough Justice Campaign confirmed he had given Carpenter permission to display the banner but not to collect funds. Carpenter is due to be sentenced in January.

Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers 3-0, with goals from Grant Ward, Luke Varney, and Tom Lawrence. QPR had limited attacking opportunities, with Sandro hitting the post late in the game. The win moved Ipswich up to 14th in the league, above QPR who dropped to 15th. Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy praised his team's performance, while QPR boss Ian Holloway expressed disappointment with his players' mental toughness and defensive efforts.

Wells, aged 23, had a successful T20 Blast season, scoring 373 runs with an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66. He expressed excitement about the club's direction and the elite performance environment fostered by the coaches, which motivates the players.

The Reds, currently fifth in National Two South, secured their second consecutive victory by defeating third-placed Chinnor 29-12. Coach Churcher highlighted the strong leadership of Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams, noting that the front row and front five's combined 70-plus tackles were crucial to their success. The Reds have a favorable upcoming schedule with seven teams below them in the next eight games, though they will also face league leaders Old Elthamians. Churcher believes the team can still improve, describing the win against Chinnor as a dogged but not complete performance, and emphasized the need to build on their previous success to avoid it being a wasted effort.

Police allege that 28-year-old Nazrul, also known as Nazu, raped a 74-year-old nun during an attack on a convent in Ranaghat town on March 14th. Nazrul, allegedly a Bangladeshi citizen, was arrested at a Kolkata railway station, marking the sixth arrest in the case. Police have identified eight suspects, with two still untraced, and state that the five previously arrested accused have named Nazrul as the perpetrator. The incident, which involved the theft of money and ransacking of the convent school, sparked outrage and street protests across India. Milon Sarkar was previously arrested and described as the gang leader.

Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising, discusses reasons for changes in consumer purchasing habits in an interactive video, noting the impact of the domestic freezer, washing powder, and cheaper imports on popular items in the UK. The video also examines shifts in ownership and ranking of major UK brands, with links provided for supplementary non-interactive content.

Two women, one from Sandyhills and another from Stranraer, have been victims of scams where callers, claiming to be from BT technical support, gained remote access to their computers and took substantial sums of money. The Sandyhills incident occurred on September 15th, followed by the Stranraer incident seven days later. Authorities are warning the public to be extremely cautious of cold calls requesting remote computer access to fix alleged faults and to never share banking or account details over the phone, as reputable organizations do not request such information.

Duffy, a 37-year-old Scotland assistant coach, has signed a one-year contract with third-placed Championship side Featherstone after departing Swinton Lions. He will coach Featherstone in their final league game against Toulouse before the Super 8 Qualifiers. Featherstone chairman Mark Campbell expressed excitement about Duffy's coaching and praised his work at Swinton. Duffy, who had a 16-year playing career with Leigh, Widnes, and Salford, has been succeeded at Swinton by Stuart Littler.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, a medic, and the coastguard search and rescue helicopter were dispatched to Sker Beach on Sunday at 12:50 GMT. The rider sustained head injuries and was found unconscious and cold on wet sand. After receiving treatment, she was airlifted to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales.

At a UN conference in Geneva, representatives from over 160 countries agreed to dedicate a radio frequency to a global flight tracking system, enabling satellites to receive aircraft transmissions for real-time tracking anywhere in the world. This decision, spurred by the disappearance of MH370 in March 2014, aims to improve upon the current ground-based radar system, which leaves about 70% of the world's airspace uncovered. The International Civil Aviation Organisation has set a November 2016 deadline for new tracking guidelines, requiring aircraft to send their position at least every 15 minutes.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five, has been found at 18 years old, living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. Bobby Hernandez, 53, was arrested in Ohio after the FBI received a tip regarding the teenager's identity, which was confirmed through collaboration with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children. The father is also charged with tampering with records in Ohio to obtain a driver's license in 2012 and is being held on $250,000 bail. Authorities had suspected the father was involved in the boy's disappearance in August 2002, when he reportedly took his son to pre-school and then fled.

Following a blaze on March 2nd that disrupted train services, the Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste. The fire service stated the company was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law, despite nine visits in the past year and prior concerns raised by the fire service to the EA in February regarding the potential impact of a fire. The EA has decided to revoke the company's environmental permit, effective August 7th, unless an appeal is successful, after which the company can no longer operate from the site but must still remove all waste. The cause of the fire is undetermined.

Pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia has introduced two bills linked to the situation in Ukraine, particularly concerning the Crimea region where separatist and pro-Russian sentiments are strong. One bill would allow Russia to accept a territory into the Russian Federation based on a referendum or a plea from its leaders, bypassing the need for a treaty with the existing state, especially if that state is perceived to be disintegrating. The other bill aims to expedite the issuance of Russian passports to Ukrainians, removing requirements such as state tax, previous residence, sufficient funds, and the need to renounce Ukrainian citizenship, with the stated goal of supporting "fraternal people of Ukraine" against a "brown threat." This fast-track passport procedure was announced in Sevastopol, and several Russian MPs have visited Crimea.

McLaren, a team with a rich history of 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently experiencing a slump that began in 2013 due to chassis design issues, and now faces problems with their Honda power-unit, despite having two world champions, Fernando Alonso and Lewis Hamilton, in their lineup. The team's past successes include a dominant era with Honda in the late 1980s and early 1990s, and victories with Mika Hakkinen and Mercedes engines in 1998-99, though they were disqualified from the 2007 constructors' championship due to a spying scandal and faced another scandal in 2008. Ron Dennis, who has been instrumental in the team's history, returned in 2013 and believes McLaren will break Mercedes' dominance and win championships again, a sentiment shared by Fernando Alonso who returned in 2015 seeking a third title.

Thomas Baker, a 44-year-old man from Everton, was found severely injured at Stanley Meat Market in Liverpool on January 27th, having been shot in the head and chest, and later died in hospital. Three Liverpool men, aged 29 and 32, have been arrested and remain in custody. Mr. Baker was shot after leaving Phoenix Gym at the market and getting into his car, with detectives believing the perpetrators waited for about an hour. Police are searching for a silver VW Polo that left the scene at speed and are appealing for individuals captured on CCTV near the market to come forward, as they may possess crucial information.

The passage discusses ways to engage with spirituality online during Christmas, highlighting Everyday Church Online's virtual services and Star Wars-themed sermons, the game Guardians of Ancora which uses Bible stories to combat darkness in a fictional world, and the use of digital platforms for religious messaging, citing examples like Viral.de's "The Digital Story of Nativity" told through social media updates and the Churches Advertising Network's video "Christmas Starts with a Baby's Giggle." It also mentions Next Manga's distribution of Bible stories in app and e-book form, including the "Manga Messiah," and the broader trend of churches using social media like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to connect with communities and share messages.

An eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is considering a proposal to take over 250 hectares of common land for a circuit, with 320 hectares of replacement land offered. Experts have presented conflicting views on the potential damage to habitats and plant life. Natural Resources Wales found it difficult to conclude the replacement land was of equal value but did not oppose the development. Developers claim a "net gain" in biodiversity due to plans to enhance nearby habitats, a claim disputed by the Gwent wildlife trust. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will recommend a decision, with Welsh government ministers having the final say.

Chechen Muslim clerics declared that a report by Novaya Gazeta, which detailed the detention and killing of over 100 suspected homosexual individuals in Chechnya, insulted their faith and the dignity of Chechen men, vowing retribution against the instigators. Novaya Gazeta stated this amounted to a call for reprisals against journalists and urged Russian authorities to prevent incitement of hatred towards them. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report's truth, with a spokeswoman detailing torture of detainees at a prison near Argun. Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov denied the allegations, and his spokesman claimed there were no gay people in Chechnya. The spiritual leader, Mufti Salah-haji Mezhiev, confirmed "retribution" was part of the resolution, stating Allah would punish those who slandered the Chechen nation. Novaya Gazeta's chief editor wrote an open letter to the mufti, asserting their journalists would continue investigating human rights abuses and denying any intention to insult the Chechen people. The passage also mentions past murders of Novaya Gazeta reporters and an opposition politician linked to Chechnya, and the LGBT Network is assisting people fleeing persecution, threatening to file a case at the International Criminal Court if Russia fails to prosecute.

Investing Solutions, a letting agent that houses single homeless men over 35, profits by charging housing benefit for each person in a property rather than for the property itself, leading to payouts higher than the rent passed to landlords. The company, set up by Samir Patel who also founded the charity Fresh Start Housing, operates from a south London storage unit and is a major recipient of housing benefit, with Wandsworth Council paying them over £2.1m. While neither entity acts illegally, a homeless group has criticized the relationship as "a new low," citing tenant complaints of unsuitable living conditions. Investing Solutions claims the majority of rents are passed to private landlords, and Fresh Start Housing states they refer clients to both Investing Solutions and private landlords.

Great Britain, led by Andrew Lawrence with 14 points and Ben Gordon with 13, lost their final warm-up match before their Eurobasket qualifying campaign. Despite leading for most of the game, they were overtaken by the Netherlands in the final quarter, with Worthy De Jong scoring 18 points for the Dutch. Coach Joe Prunty emphasized the importance of consistent effort in the upcoming qualifiers and noted Gordon's positive contribution, particularly in the third quarter. Great Britain's next game is in Hungary.

The Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC) will debate on August 16 whether to allow Conor McGregor to use 8oz gloves for his upcoming fight against Floyd Mayweather, as NAC rules require 10oz gloves for bouts at 154 lbs. McGregor submitted a necessary waiver, while Mayweather had previously stated his intention to wear 8oz gloves. The NAC prioritizes fighter safety and will consider McGregor's UFC background, including his sparring with Nate Diaz, and Mayweather's recent knockout history in their decision. McGregor, making his boxing debut, has been advised by the NAC to hire a boxing referee, leading to the hiring of Joe Cortez, who oversaw a sparring session with Paulie Malignaggi.

Fleet Street, once the heart of British journalism and a symbol of the industry, is seeing the end of an era with the closure of the Sunday Post's London office, marking the departure of its last two journalists, Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith. Historically, Fleet Street was the primary source of information for the public, with the first British daily newspaper, the Daily Courant, published there in 1702. At its peak, it was a prestigious location for journalists, with numerous national and provincial newspapers having offices nearby, characterized by a vibrant atmosphere of pubs filled with journalists and printers, and a less technologically advanced working environment. The shift away from Fleet Street began in 1986 when Rupert Murdoch moved his papers to Wapping, followed by most national newspapers by 1988, as they adopted new, cheaper, computerized printing technologies. This exodus led to the repurposing of former newspaper buildings, transforming the iconic street into a place with sandwich bars and other businesses, signifying the end of its reign as the center of the newspaper industry.

J.K. Rowling, the Harry Potter author, has expressed that comments she receives remind her of the vastness of the world and the prevalence of decent people, while also stating that her personal line has been crossed by abusive comments on Twitter, and she believes in confronting bullies. She previously donated £1m to the campaign for a No vote in the Scottish independence referendum and the same amount to the Labour party in 2008. Rowling revealed she was called "a traitor" for her political views and blocked abusive Twitter users, some of whom she believed supported the Scottish National Party (SNP), stating she feels no responsibility to silence such behavior to protect any political party's image. She also mentioned engaging with nice SNP supporters and discussing political commonalities, and humorously responded to a suggestion to burn her books by offering to bring marshmallows. The SNP won 56 out of 59 seats in Scotland in a recent election, becoming the third-largest party in the UK.

A study by University of Edinburgh researchers found that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action and five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision than better-off children who commit the same crime, with poverty increasing the likelihood of violence for both boys and girls. A history of police trouble was the strongest predictor of a young person not being in education, employment, or training by age 18, and household poverty was an exacerbating factor for offending, even when other risk factors were considered. The study also indicated that people in extreme poverty were more likely to be victims and perpetrators of crime, and boys were three times more likely than girls to engage in violent acts, with girls from poorer backgrounds being twice as likely as affluent girls to be involved in violent crime. The findings suggest that crime remains concentrated in poor neighborhoods and among poor people, raising questions about the government's tackling of inequality, despite a general fall in crime rates in Scotland.

Robbie Walsh has been charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr Haugh, who was stabbed in the Marian estate and later died. Walsh was remanded in custody and is due to appear in court again next week. Two other men arrested in connection with the killing were released without charge. It is alleged that Walsh and two other males entered the Marian Estate, sought out Mr Haugh, and a fight ensued where weapons, including knives and golf clubs, were used. Mr Haugh sustained a stab wound to his back and was pronounced dead at Limerick University Hospital. A knife blade with blood on it was recovered at the scene. A judge noted tension in the area following the killing and remanded Walsh in custody until August 14.

Fermanagh MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted an accusation about Tom Elliott, a former UDR member, on BBC radio in May 2014. The tweet, which questioned Elliott's actions during his service, was brought to Elliott's attention by Ann Travers and Arlene Foster. Flanagan deleted the tweet within an hour and has since admitted it was untrue and without foundation, agreeing to post an apology on Twitter. Mr. Elliott, who has a clear MoD record, stated he has been vindicated and expressed disappointment at the time taken to resolve the issue. The insurance firm indemnifying MLAs has refused to cover Flanagan's compensation and costs, a decision he is challenging separately. Mr. Justice Stevens has reserved judgment on the compensation amount.

Hawick Knitwear, a company established in 1874 and bought by Benny Hartop last November, has increased its weekly sweater production from approximately 7,500 to 9,500 to meet rising demand. This surge in orders is attributed to strong sales of its Hawick Knitwear-branded range, launched in January, and growth in its private label business. The company supplies customers in various European countries, including Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy, and Spain, as well as international markets such as the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan.

Brian Wright, 55, is on trial at Luton Crown Court for allegedly causing serious injury by dangerous driving after his VW Golf failed to stop for a red light and struck Sylvia Blackburn, 72, a lollipop lady of 20 years, outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Mr. Wright claims he was blinded by the setting sun and cannot recall if the traffic lights were red or green, stating he only heard a bump and was in shock. Mrs. Blackburn suffered serious head injuries and is now in residential care, and Mr. Wright has expressed remorse for his actions and their impact on her and her family. The trial is ongoing.

The passage describes NATO's "Dynamic Mongoose" exercise, a response to the growing threat of Russian submarines, which have increased patrols in European waters. The exercise involves 10 NATO warships, including the Royal Navy Frigate HMS Portland, hunting a German U-boat, the U33, which is simulating an enemy submarine. The exercise highlights a significant gap in Britain's defenses due to its lack of maritime patrol aircraft, forcing it to rely on allies to monitor Russian submarine activity. Russia has been heavily investing in its submarine fleet, which is considered technologically advanced and challenging to detect, leading to concerns about its increasing military strength and potential to exploit vulnerabilities in NATO defenses. The exercise also utilizes anti-submarine warfare helicopters and, for the first time, NATO research vessels have deployed underwater unmanned vehicles (drones) to aid in tracking submarines.

United Nations officials are concerned that genocide and ethnic cleansing could occur in South Sudan, where violence that began in Juba in July has spread to the Equatoria states, causing 340,000 people to flee to Uganda. This influx is the largest of any country this year, with an average of 2,500 South Sudanese becoming refugees daily. Survivors report killings, rape, and targeting of civilians along ethnic lines, with testimonies describing brutal violence such as being cut with knives. The conflict is characterized by ethnic violence, initially between the Dinka and Nuer tribes, and has recently targeted Equatorians. Uganda has been accommodating refugees by providing land and shelter, but the sheer volume is beginning to strain resources, prompting calls for international attention and pressure on South Sudanese leaders to end the violence.

McKenzie, aged 38, will compete for the English super-middleweight championship against Jahmaine Smyle at York Hall on November 12. He transitioned to professional boxing in 2013 after leaving football two years prior, and has a professional record of eight wins and one draw in nine fights. McKenzie is the son of former British and European champion Clinton and is coached by his uncle, Duke McKenzie, a three-time world champion.

Bridgwater Community Hospital is receiving £33m in funding as part of a £330m coalition investment in new NHS facilities across England, with NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust covering the remaining balance. The new hospital will feature 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, and X-ray facilities, replacing the current cramped and outdated 1813 building. The project aims to provide a more modern and conducive environment for patient recovery, with completion anticipated by autumn 2014, contingent on planning permission for the proposed Bowers Lane site. This development is seen as a significant step in improving healthcare delivery in Somerset, fostering collaboration among GPs, nurses, and therapists.

A man was fatally injured outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, after being shot in the chest. Officers were called to the scene at approximately 13:35 GMT and found the victim near a black Mercedes car. He was taken to Northern General hospital but died from his injuries. Local residents stated the victim was part of a family who live nearby and that relatives were gathered for a celebration when the attack happened. This incident follows several other shootings in Sheffield in recent weeks, though these have occurred in the north of the city.

The passage describes the activities of virtual warrior groups involved in the conflict in Ukraine, specifically the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, utilize distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks, target electronic payment systems, and hack CCTV systems and network printers to spread pro-Ukrainian messages. Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, aims to thwart Ukraine's military plans and has hacked Ukrainian government websites, displayed critical messages on electronic billboards, and claims to have disrupted vote-counting systems and leaked defense data. Anonymous International, also known as b0ltai or Shaltay Boltay, is known for publishing leaked documents from the Kremlin and has focused on Russia's domestic affairs and some material related to Ukraine, including leaking emails from a former Russian FSB colonel.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick became emotional as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond bid farewell to the parliament, with both standing down ahead of the May 5 election. Salmond, in his valedictory address, reiterated his belief that Scotland is diverse rather than divided and spoke of the parliament's journey towards greater responsibility, while also noting that the Scotland Bill did not fully meet promises made during the referendum. He made lighthearted remarks about competition from a UK budget and wished candidates luck in the upcoming election, concluding by stating that serving in the parliament and for Scotland is a great honor and task. Marwick thanked Salmond for his distinguished service, and McNeil, who has served since 1999, warned that Holyrood has lessons to learn from Westminster, particularly regarding the committee system and the need for accountability and scrutiny. Former Scottish Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie is also leaving, humorously mentioning she will miss her dealings with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care across Wales. She is gathering evidence from pensioners, their families, and friends to understand their experiences, both positive and negative, with residential care. This information will inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will assess the quality of life for older people in residential care by examining factors such as physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Rochira's team will also consult with care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. Mario Kreft, chair of Care Forum Wales, expressed disappointment that the advisory panel for the review does not include any provider experts, believing this is a missed opportunity for partnership and sector engagement.

Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, experienced a pre-tax profit increase of £800,000 to £3.5 million in the year ending June 2016, despite a £1 million decrease in turnover to just over £100 million. The company, which manufactures and supplies feeds for various livestock sectors and operates 19 Country Store shops across Scotland selling farming and rural community products, noted growth in international sales in Europe and new markets. Harbro acknowledged challenging times in the agricultural industry but expressed confidence in its ability to navigate future business challenges, including the impact of Brexit.

The body of a man in his 70s was discovered at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday afternoon. A man in his 80s was hospitalized. Police are seeking to question 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, in connection with the death, which is being treated as murder. McLoughlin is described as white, approximately 6ft tall, with straight, greying, collar-length hair and of average build, and may have been wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a checked short-sleeved shirt. The public has been warned not to approach him, and anyone with information is urged to contact the police or Crimestoppers. Additional patrols are being conducted in the area.

David Lipton, second in command at the IMF, stated that the IMF's latest assessment of the global economy indicates a weakening baseline, placing the world at a delicate juncture. This assessment follows disappointing trade figures from China, which showed a 25% year-on-year drop in exports. The IMF anticipates downgrading its current global growth forecast of 3.4% in its upcoming April economic predictions, a development with ongoing consequences for businesses and industries that relied on China's growth.

The council leader announced that the Cowes crossing will be free until July 2nd due to problems with the new vessel, and a review by auditors has been ordered. The ferry has experienced breakdowns, run aground, and been suspended due to training issues since its launch, with cars also being damaged. Local businesses are concerned about the impact on their trade and are seeking compensation, which is under discussion. The transport councillor described the issues as "teething problems" for a prototype, noting that electrical problems have been rectified and ramp extensions have been authorized to prevent vehicles from scraping. Groundings were attributed to seamanship issues that have since been resolved.

A fatal crash involving multiple vehicles occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday, resulting in the death of a 32-year-old man. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road remained closed until early evening for investigations.

Matching Models, an international temp agency for "beautiful and talented people," has faced criticism for discriminatory job advertisements, including one seeking a personal assistant with a "classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup" and another for a "sexy female driver." The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) deemed these ads "appalling, unlawful and demeaning to women," and stated they would be asking the agency to clarify its hiring practices. Women's equality campaigners described the ads as "straight out of the 1970s" and likely in violation of equality legislation. The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defended the practice by stating that "looks are important" to their clients, citing a client who requested a personal assistant with a specific cup size to fit a Christian Dior outfit designed to emulate a "Jackie O" look, and another Indian businessman who hired six blonde, blue-eyed Greek women to work on his plane. Employment lawyer James Lynas noted that such adverts are "clearly unlawful" and could lead to sex discrimination claims with unlimited compensation, as phrases like "beautiful and attractive" could be interpreted as code for "young," discriminating against older women. The 2010 Equality Act prohibits employers from implying discrimination and restricts inquiries into a candidate's age, sexual orientation, marital status, number of children, disability, race, or religion, with exceptions for specifying clothing sizes only if essential to the job. Despite the controversy, Matching Models' clients include major companies like MTV, Louis Vuitton, Coca-Cola, the Renault Formula 1 team, and Harrods.

A shooting incident took place at a hostel attached to the Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, where an office assistant named Mahesh allegedly shot and killed 18-year-old Gautami and injured another student, Sirisha. Mahesh, who was arrested after a manhunt, has been remanded until April 12. Gun crime at educational institutions in India is uncommon, and the motive for the shooting is unclear.

Glaad's analysis of shows from June 2016 to May 2017 found 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters, with transgender characters increasing from seven to 16. However, the group noted the deaths of over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters, including Poussey Washington and Bea Smith. The study also reported a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, largely due to shows like Empire, Luke Cage, and How to Get Away with Murder. Glaad's president, Sarah Kate Ellis, acknowledged progress but stated that numbers are "only part of the story."

David Mackintosh, Conservative MP for Northampton South, will not seek re-election after facing opposition from his local party due to criticism over a £10.25m loan from the borough council to Northampton Town FC, which is now missing and under police investigation for alleged financial irregularities, leaving the football stand half-built.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old police officer, was fired for policy violations after shooting into a car of teenagers leaving a party in Balch Springs, Texas, killing 15-year-old Jordan Edwards. Oliver fired his rifle as the car drove away, and footage contradicted the initial police claim that the vehicle reversed aggressively towards him. He faces charges of murder and four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon. If convicted of murder, Oliver could receive five to 99 years in prison and would be the first police officer convicted of murder in Dallas County since 1973. The Edwards family lawyer expressed caution, noting the long time since a police officer was convicted of murder in Texas.

Melania Trump will move to Washington "very soon, after he's finished with school," but no specific date has been set, with her focus on her son Barron's schooling being a primary reason for the delay. This decision has drawn criticism, with some viewing it as a departure from the traditional role of a First Lady, while others support it as responsible parenting. Historically, only Martha Washington and Anna Harrison did not reside in the White House during their husbands' presidencies, for specific reasons. Other First Ladies, like Frances Folsom Cleveland, also spent time away from the White House, and children of presidents like John Tyler and Payne Todd were not immediately moved to the White House. Recent First Families, including the Clintons and Obamas, have navigated the challenges of children living in the White House, with the Obamas even moving early to avoid mid-term school changes. The role of the First Lady is ceremonial, involving hosting and supporting causes, with figures like Lou Henry Hoover and Eleanor Roosevelt being more publicly active, while Nancy Reagan was more private. Melania Trump has indicated her priority is tackling cyber-bullying. In cases where a president's wife has passed away, other female family members have taken on First Lady duties, and there is speculation about Ivanka Trump potentially filling a similar role. The White House can be adapted to family life, as seen with the Clintons and Obamas, who prioritized family time and their children's privacy.

A 72-year-old man died in Inverness on October 27th, and the Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, has been asked by the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) to investigate the initial police response to his call. Police Scotland is cooperating with the investigation, and a report of the commissioner's findings will be submitted to the COPFS.

A yellow warning for wind has been issued, with gusts potentially reaching 75mph (120kmph) locally, especially west of the mountains, and an unusual easterly direction may intensify the impact. Disruption to road and sea travel is anticipated in Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. Overnight gusts caused a tree to fall in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, blocking a main route into the town, with Telford Road expected to be closed for most of Monday for clean-up.

The Giants took an early lead through Derrick Walser, but Jeff Dimmen leveled for the Panthers. In the second period, Mike Forney's powerplay goal put the Giants ahead 2-1, with Andy Bohmback equalizing for the Panthers. Mike Radja scored from an acute angle and James Desmarais extended the Giants' lead to 4-2, before David Ling scored for Nottingham. Nottingham currently leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 and Belfast with 25. The two teams will play again on Saturday night.

Lewis Hamilton started from the back, suffered a broken front wing on lap one, and made five pit stops, facing a 36-point deficit in the remaining 18 races. Sebastian Vettel finished second after colliding with his teammate Kimi Raikkonen on the first lap, an incident that also damaged Raikkonen's car, though he recovered to fifth. The race was marked by an incident-packed opening, including multiple first-lap collisions that led to a safety car. Daniel Ricciardo took the lead from pole-sitter Nico Rosberg but suffered a puncture, allowing Rosberg to secure the win. Hamilton's progress was hampered by damage to his car from a collision with Felipe Nasr, and despite his confidence in overcoming Rosberg's lead, the fact remains that no driver who has won the first three races of a season has failed to claim the World Championship.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a prominent footballer, publicly revealed his homosexuality in an interview with Die Zeit to address the "ignored" topic in German football, receiving widespread praise from former teammates, football administrators like Theo Zwanziger and Reinhard Rauball, and politicians. His announcement is considered a significant moment in Germany's struggle with homophobia in football, a sentiment echoed by Gary Lineker, Joseph Barton, and John Amaechi. While Hitzlsperger's former Germany captain Philipp Lahm had previously advised gay footballers to remain silent, Hitzlsperger's courageous step is hoped to encourage others and break down taboos, with German Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman commending his openness and Volker Beck urging the German FA to support active players.

Steve Sidwell, a 34-year-old midfielder, has made 32 Championship appearances for Brighton this season, contributing to their promotion to the top flight for the first time in 34 years. His contract is expiring, and he hopes to sign a new deal, expressing his desire to be part of the team in the Premier League next year. Brighton recently secured promotion with a win over Wigan and are aiming to win the league title. Sidwell previously played for Brighton on loan in 2015-16 before signing a one-year deal in June 2016, and he has prior Premier League experience with several other clubs. He believes he has performed well and earned the opportunity for a new contract.

The Seasiders took the lead after 12 minutes with a goal from Jamille Matt, but Colchester United equalized from a corner through Kurtis Guthrie. Colchester had chances to regain the lead before halftime, with Sam Slocombe making saves and Guthrie hitting the bar. Blackpool missed a late opportunity to win the match when Tom Aldred headed wide. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after Sean Murray received a red card for a bad tackle. The match ended in a 1-1 draw.

The 29-year-old, who has previously played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston, made 37 appearances for the Sky Blues last season as they were relegated from League One. He may debut for the U's in their EFL Cup first-round match against Aston Villa. Colchester began their season with a 3-1 loss to Accrington.

The murder of PC Keith Palmer has led to increased calls for a permanent memorial to honor police officers and staff. The UK Police Memorial Trust is seeking £1.5 million for its construction at the National Memorial Arboretum, which will list over 1,400 names. The memorial, dedicated to the courage and sacrifice of officers over the past 250 years, will include a brass screen with leaf shapes for families of fallen officers. The government has committed £1 million towards the £4 million project, with completion expected by 2019.

Manchester United secured a 1-0 victory at Sunderland, maintaining a 15-point lead at the top of the table with eight games remaining. Manager Ferguson emphasized the team's focus on future games, highlighting their record of 25 wins in the first 30 matches. The team has accumulated 50 out of a possible 54 points in their last 18 Premier League games and aims to surpass Chelsea's 2005 record of 95 points. Ferguson plans to make changes for the upcoming FA Cup quarter-final replay against Chelsea due to injuries sustained by Rafael and Anderson at Sunderland, as well as a knock to goalkeeper David De Gea. Wayne Rooney, Danny Welbeck, and Tom Cleverley did not start the Sunderland match, and Rooney's availability for the Chelsea game is uncertain due to fatigue. Ryan Giggs and Javier Hernandez will be available, along with other players who were rested for the Sunderland game. Ferguson acknowledged Sunderland's strong performance, stating that United's win was due to determined defending and courage.

Google paid £10m in UK corporate taxes between 2006 and 2011, with Mr Schmidt stating the company complied with all legally required tax payments and that any changes to tax laws should be made by the government. The head of the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee suggested a new committee to oversee major firms' tax arrangements, allowing for secret evidence hearings. Google, which routes most UK sales through Ireland, is criticized for minimizing UK tax payments, while EU leaders agreed to tackle tax avoidance through automatic information exchange. The Google chairman advocates for corporate taxes to be levied where economic activity occurs and calls for international tax reform, emphasizing that politicians should set tax rules.

NHS Improvement wants the NHS to reduce its agency staff bill by £1bn by the end of the financial year, having spent £3.6bn last year. A cap introduced in October has saved £600m, limiting payments to 55% above normal shift rates for most staff, with only senior managers exempted. The aim is to lower overall costs and reliance on agency staff, who are more expensive due to agency fees and employer costs. While progress is promising, NHS trusts are still 10% behind their targets, and it's unclear if spending on other pay areas has increased. NHS Improvement will publish league tables for trusts and collect data on high-earning agency staff, as examples of trusts being quoted rates significantly above the cap have emerged.

The Longford Town Centre, once envisioned as a "cathedral of commerce," now symbolizes Ireland's economic downturn, but local traders like Matt O'Brien are seeing signs of improvement, with his business expanding into new areas. The opposition party criticizes the government's investment priorities, advocating for broadband over water meters and highlighting the lack of Industrial Development Authority (IDA) client visits to Longford. The government points to the planned Center Parcs development in Ballymahon, which could create 1,000 jobs, as a positive step, though it awaits planning permission. Local Fine Gael TD James Bannon is optimistic about the region's tourism potential due to its natural resources. Traders, however, believe more can be done, suggesting free parking to attract more visitors to the town, indicating that while economic recovery is beginning, further action is needed.

The competition features eight teams playing each other twice, with the top four advancing to the play-offs, concluding on May 29th in the same stadium. Key performers include Warner as the leading run-scorer with 294 runs, De Kock with the highest score of 108, and McClenaghan with the most wickets (9). Four current or former England players are participating: Eoin Morgan, Jos Buttler, Sam Billings, and Kevin Pietersen. The passage also lists a series of fixtures and results from April 25th to May 29th, including play-off matches.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported a 200 million increase in plastic carrier bags since 2013, with many being unrecyclable and discarded after a single use, leading to environmental issues in landfills and rivers. To address this, England will implement a 5p charge for plastic bags starting in October, aiming to encourage reuse. This measure follows similar charges in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland, which have resulted in reduced bag usage in supermarkets. Campaigners anticipate the charge in England will similarly decrease the number of bags discarded, benefiting the environment.

A yellow 'be aware' wind warning across Wales led to a school roof being ripped off in Rhosgadfan, power cuts for hundreds of homes, train delays, and restrictions on major bridges. Irish Ferries cancelled fast sailings between Holyhead and Dublin, and Arriva Trains Wales warned of delays between Llandudno Junction and Holyhead. The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle. While restrictions on the A55 Britannia Bridge and M48 Severn Bridge were lifted as winds eased, a blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend caused Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip to be postponed.

Michael B. Jordan is "super excited" to put a "different spin" on his role in the upcoming Black Panther film, which will see him reunite with his Creed director Ryan Coogler. Jordan expressed his anticipation for working with Coogler again and with Lupita Nyong'o, an Oscar winner for 12 Years a Slave, and Chadwick Boseman, who currently plays Black Panther. Nyong'o also voiced the CGI character Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens, and Jordan previously played the Human Torch in Fantastic Four. Black Panther is scheduled for release in February 2018.

The east wing restoration project at Alexandra Palace aims to transform it into a new cultural destination, with the theatre, founded in 1875, intended for theatrical performances, cinema screenings, comedy, and live music. The BBC studios will also be repaired and refurbished. The project, costing £26.6m, is funded by the Heritage Lottery Fund (£18.8m), Haringey Council (£6.8m), and Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust (£1m). If fundraising is successful, the theatre hopes to reopen in 2018. The glazed east court will be a public space for exhibitions, and the theatre retains much of its original decor and stage machinery.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, has retired from international football after earning 61 caps for England since his senior debut in 2009. He was part of the England squad for two World Cups and two European Championships, though he only played three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps, starting his international career at that level in 2004. His sole international goal came in a 5-0 win against Moldova during the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers.

Marcy Smith and her family escaped a house fire in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, that completely destroyed their home. Her son David woke her and her daughter, saving their lives, as the fire, started by rubbish in the wood stove, spread rapidly. The family's pets did not survive, and the fire alarm failed to activate. The community has provided support by donating clothing, shoes, and a bike for David.

The energy drinks giant was reportedly considering a £200m offer for the Premier League club, West Ham. Sullivan and Gold acquired a majority stake in West Ham in 2010 for £105m and now own over 85% of the club. Following their move to London Stadium in August, West Ham has also been associated with potential takeovers by Qatari and Chinese groups. Last year, Sullivan mentioned the possibility of selling a minority shareholding to settle debts, but he and Gold planned for their children to inherit the ownership.

The MTV Movie Awards ceremony, described as not the Oscars, served as a promotional platform for summer blockbusters and featured fan-voted awards. The Fault in Our Stars was the biggest winner, taking home best movie and best female performance for Shailene Woodley, who also received the Trailblazer Award and best kiss. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for American Sniper, Channing Tatum won best comedic performance for 22 Jump Street, and Meryl Streep won best villain for Into the Woods. Other winners included Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, and Rose Byrne. Kevin Hart accepted the comedic genius award with his children, and Robert Downey Jr. accepted the Generation Award with his Avengers co-stars. Promotional clips for upcoming films like Pitch Perfect 2, Trainwreck, and Ultron were also shown.

Cammy Smith, a 21-year-old Scotland Under-21 player who has scored five goals this season, was loaned to United in July. He made his Aberdeen debut in 2012 and has scored four goals in 89 appearances for them. St Mirren boss Jack Ross considers Smith a "brilliant acquisition" and a "really good player" who will be a good fit and provide an attacking option. St Mirren, currently at the bottom of the Championship, will host Falkirk on Saturday.

Northumberland County Council is using Jetpatcher machines to repair potholes, with a goal of filling 145 potholes daily for the next four months. Additionally, extra staff will be deployed to fix drainage systems damaged by heavy rain and to clear debris from gutters.

In December, six Wood Group contractors working on EnQuest's Thistle platform off Shetland were exposed to low levels of naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM) while removing pipework. Rigging supervisor Steve Innes stated that the workers were not provided with proper personal protective equipment and are now concerned about cancer, with ongoing blood tests. EnQuest confirmed the incident, noting that the exposure level was less than 1% of the reportable threshold to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE), but they did inform the HSE. EnQuest has since implemented additional precautionary steps. Wood Group emphasized its commitment to employee safety, stating they downmanned employees for medical assessments and supported a joint investigation. The Unite union criticized the treatment of the workers and called for transparency in safety incidents. The HSE confirmed awareness of the incident but stated no investigation was carried out as it was not reportable under current regulations and no staff raised the issue separately.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) is returning a sculpture of Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari to India after it was discovered to have been sold by a dealer who admitted to selling stolen Indian antiquities. The ACM purchased the artwork for $650,000 in 2007, and the allegations of it being stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu surfaced during a 2012 court case. The decision to return the sculpture was made after discussions between Singapore's National Heritage Board and India's Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), which submitted an official request for its return. While there is no conclusive proof of its origin, the ACM noted the dealer's confession of dealing in looted Indian antiquities. The museum plans to take legal action to seek compensation for the fraud.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake struck at a depth of 15.5km, 35km north of Lucca, Italy, and was felt in Milan and Florence. The quake occurred at 15:48 (14:48 GMT) with its epicenter in Garfagnana, and was described as a classic, medium-strong, and fairly shallow earthquake for the area. Phone lines and power supplies were cut in Garfagnana, and schools in the vicinity were evacuated as a precaution. This event follows a history of earthquakes in Italy, including a deadly quake in L'Aquila in 2009 that resulted in the conviction of several officials for providing inaccurate information.

Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, was overjoyed to see results from his fruit plant, having been dubious about South Yorkshire's climate. The fruit is still attached to the plant and is not yet ripe enough to eat.

Rockstar has delayed the release of the latest version of their open world adventure game until March 24th, originally scheduled for January 27th, citing the need for additional testing and polish. Online heists will be available on consoles before the PC release, and the PC version will feature enhanced detail, with Los Santos and Blaine County visible in 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, and support for triple monitor configurations. Minimum PC specifications have also been released. Grand Theft Auto V previously became the fastest-selling entertainment product ever, generating $1 billion in revenue within three days of its September 17, 2013 release.

A 76-year-old artist won the Â£25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his work "Squint (19)," displayed at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. The artist, who had been shortlisted in 1991 and longlisted three other times, described winning as "very nice indeed." Judge Ansel Krut praised "Squint (19)" as "quite extraordinary" and a "difficult painting to look at," explaining it depicts a leper squint, which allowed "undesirables" to view church services. The artist noted the painting's relatively small size, about 7ft in height, was a factor in his decision to enter it, and stated the prize money would be used for art materials like stretches, canvas, and quality paints. Krut further described the painting as a "tone poem" with subtle technique and minimal language that evokes great sympathy due to its subject matter. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with past winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig, and Sir Peter Blake as a former junior title winner and current patron.

The offices of the daily Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit were attacked by four masked assailants early on Thursday, with windows shattered by gunfire and spent bullet casings found at both scenes. Firefighters extinguished a blaze at the Yeni Safak building, and police have cordoned off the area while hunting for the assailants. No casualties were reported, and no group has yet claimed responsibility for the attacks, which occurred almost simultaneously on buildings located 20km apart. Both newspapers support President Recep Tayyip Erdogan's governing AK Party.

A 24-year-old player, previously under contract with the Stags, will join the Mariners on a free transfer on January 1st. He spent the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, where he scored three goals in 23 appearances. This marks the first signing for Marcus Bignot's side.

Arsene Wenger commented on Gareth Southgate's suitability for the England manager role, noting Southgate's experience and observational skills, while also stating his own focus remains on his current job. Southgate has upcoming matches against Scotland and Spain to prove his capabilities to the Football Association. Wenger also mentioned that Arsenal plans to offer a new contract to Hector Bellerin, expressing surprise at transfer speculation surrounding the defender, and confirmed that Aaron Ramsey will miss a couple more games due to a hamstring injury.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road is believed to have fallen from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT on Thursday, prompting a joint inquiry by Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive, with the company fully cooperating.

A new charter arrangement will resolve the long-running dispute over seafarers' pay on freight vessels serving the Northern Isles, with all crew members to be paid at least the minimum wage starting next month. The RMT union had alleged some workers were paid less than £4 an hour. The freight boats Hellier and Hildasay, previously operated by Seatruck under contract to Serco Northlink, will return to Serco Northlink's direct operation. Seatruck had contended the national minimum wage was not applicable to its crew, many of whom are non-UK residents, and declined Serco Northlink's offers to bridge the pay gap. Serco Northlink was awarded the six-year £243m contract for the Northern Isles route in 2012, operating three ferries and two cargo boats subsidized by the Scottish government.

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on May 14, six days after an incident at the Rockley Park site in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted intervening in an argument between Mr. Dickie and his mother, Samantha Mitchell, 57. The jury at Winchester Crown Court found Jamie Mitchell guilty. The court heard that Mr. Mitchell and Mr. Dickie had been drinking at the holiday park bar on May 7, leading to a confrontation outside where they were separated by others. Jamie Mitchell had pleaded guilty to common assault for the fight. Both Jamie and Samantha Mitchell admitted attempting to pervert the course of justice by providing false information to the police about the events. They will be sentenced on February 6.

Rod Temperton, a prolific songwriter nicknamed "The Invisible Man," died in London at age 66 after a battle with cancer. He was known for writing hits for Michael Jackson, including "Thriller," "Rock With You," and "Off The Wall," as well as songs for his band Heatwave like "Boogie Nights." Temperton's songwriting, influenced by his father and early exposure to Radio Luxembourg, also produced hits for artists such as Anita Baker and Donna Summer. He won a Grammy for his work on "Birdland" and was nominated for two Oscars for his contributions to "The Color Purple" soundtrack. His family has requested privacy following his private funeral.

Ancient earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old, have been discovered in Acre state in the western Brazilian Amazon by a team including researchers from Swansea University. These ditched enclosures, referred to as geoglyphs, were hidden by rainforest until deforestation revealed over 450 large geometrical shapes. The function of these sites remains unclear, with evidence suggesting they were not villages or defensive structures, but possibly ritual gathering places. Analysis of soil samples indicates the geoglyphs were built among taller vegetation, raising questions about their visibility and purpose. The research also challenges the assumption of pristine Amazonian forests before European arrival, suggesting humans actively managed the environment by concentrating on economically valuable trees, creating a "prehistoric supermarket" that may have influenced the biodiversity of current forests.

Australian Nick Kyrgios, ranked 12th in the world, defeated world number 29 Querrey 6-4 6-4 in 53 minutes to advance to the second round of the tournament. Kyrgios, who recently won the Japan Open, attributed his subdued performance to fatigue from his previous win and the travel involved, including a difficult journey to the Qi Zhong Stadium. He also mentioned not sleeping well the night before. The passage also notes that Kyrgios was fined $1,500 at the Shanghai Masters last year for calling the tournament a "circus."

Scientists and charities are urging the Welsh government to extend the HPV vaccination to boys, as the number of head and neck cancer cases, which are increasingly affecting younger, non-smoking men, is rising. The HPV jab currently protects girls aged 12 and 13 against cervical cancer, and an 85% vaccination rate was achieved in girls in Wales in 2008. Organizations like Tenovus Cancer Care, BMA Cymru, and Cardiff University's HPV research team will present a letter to the Welsh government advocating for this change, while the government awaits advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old suffering from gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, passed away after a battle with a rare blood cancer.
