The Scottish government considers single market membership essential for Scotland's economic prosperity and intends to oppose the UK government in the Supreme Court appeal regarding the triggering of Article 50.

A flock of 13 cloned sheep, including four cloned from the same adult ewe as Dolly, are undergoing extensive physical examinations to assess their health and aging process, with a focus on cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and osteoarthritis. These tests are crucial to understanding whether cloning, which involves extracting DNA from adult cells, might transfer an "age-memory" that could lead to premature aging and age-associated diseases in cloned animals. The study aims to determine if Dolly's early death from lung lesions and osteoarthritis was due to bad luck or a consequence of the cloning process itself, with results expected to have significant implications for the future of cloning.

Shutter Speed, trained by John Gosden and ridden by Dettori, won the Musidora Stakes, beating Vintage Folly by a length and three quarters. She will race at Chantilly instead of the Epsom Oaks, where stablemates Enable and Coronet are contenders. Tasleet, trained by William Haggas and ridden by Jim Crowley, won the Duke of York Stakes. Gosden expressed concern about the soft ground for his colt Cracksman in the Dante Stakes, a Derby trial. Shutter Speed is expected to perform better on firmer ground and will be prepared for the French Oaks.

The pound initially slipped against the dollar and euro, then recovered before falling again, with the volatility index reaching levels not seen since the 2008 financial crisis. The Leave campaign claimed the pound had only retreated to March levels, while the pound was down 0.2% against the dollar, 0.6% against the euro, and 1% against the Japanese yen. Investors were spooked by falling chances of a Remain vote and global economic worries, with polls showing the Leave camp ahead and betting firms indicating a decrease in the probability of a Remain vote. Analysts expect incoming polls to cause more aggressive movement in the pound, with increased volatility likely if the race remains tight. Hedge funds have been short-selling sterling, anticipating further depreciation, and markets are on "Brexit alert" due to the close race. Worries about the economic impact of leaving the EU also contributed to falls in Asian stock markets, with Japan's Nikkei index down 3.5% and Hong Kong's main index down 2.5%. London's FTSE 100 ended the day down 1.1%, with Lloyds Banking Group being the biggest faller. A Leave campaigner argued that sterling had strengthened since March and that a weaker pound benefits UK exporters, citing a narrowing UK trade deficit in April due to increased exports.

The Iron are sixth in the National League, one point and one place outside the play-off spots. After a long journey and conceding an early goal, they lost to a strong Barrow team, extending their losing streak to three games. Despite this, manager Cowley remains positive, calling their performance "remarkable" and acknowledging the challenge of being a part-time team facing their toughest challenge yet, which they intend to embrace and enjoy.

From April 2015, councils in Northern Ireland will gain the authority to make planning decisions, shifting this responsibility from the Planning Service. This change, which includes increased responsibility for off-street parking and tourism, is seen by some, like Michael Corr of PLACE, as a significant opportunity for local development. However, concerns exist regarding politicians' skills and the potential for discrimination or unfairness, reminiscent of past housing allocation issues in the 1960s. Friends of the Earth, represented by James Orr, warns of potential favoritism towards certain communities and the continuation of close relationships between developers and political parties, emphasizing the need for transparency and a strict code of conduct. The debate also touches upon political donations and the security of donors, with differing views on the relevance of donation limits.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot twice in the shoulder and once in its left back leg, requiring amputation, after being found injured by its owner. The Scottish SPCA stated the cat was lucky to survive and highlighted the incident as a reason for the Scottish government to urgently implement air weapon licensing, a proposal that was largely opposed in a previous consultation where 87% of respondents rejected the idea of requiring a legitimate reason to own an air gun.

Christian Benteke has signed for Liverpool on a long-term contract, becoming the club's second most expensive signing. Liverpool triggered a release clause in Benteke's contract to make him their seventh summer signing. The Belgium international scored 49 goals in 101 games for Aston Villa and expressed his happiness at joining Liverpool to win trophies and achieve great goals with the team, citing a good conversation with the manager as a key factor. Liverpool, who struggled for goals last season after selling Luis Suarez and due to Daniel Sturridge's injuries, have brought in Benteke to revitalize their attack, alongside other signings like Danny Ings and Roberto Firmino. Benteke, who missed the 2014 World Cup with an Achilles injury, returned to score 15 goals for Villa last season. Former Villa manager Paul Lambert believes Benteke will perform well at Anfield, highlighting his ability as a number nine and his potential to score goals with good service. Former Liverpool striker John Aldridge is also optimistic about Benteke's impact, noting his presence, speed, strength, and aggression as valuable assets for the team.

A study commissioned by Tablets for Schools found that tablet computers are increasingly prevalent in schools, with 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools using them to some extent, and 9% of schools providing an individual tablet for every pupil. While the study found no clear evidence of academic improvement directly linked to tablet use, head teachers reported positive impacts, particularly in motivating disengaged pupils and increasing family involvement when tablets are taken home. A separate study suggested touch-screen computers are beneficial for boys and poorer pupils in learning to read. The overall trend indicates a growing number of tablets in schools, with 45% of schools not currently using them planning to introduce them soon, and the number of tablet computers in schools expected to rise significantly between 2014 and 2016. Some pupils reported being internet "addicts" and taking devices to bed for social media or videos, highlighting the integration of online technology into young people's lives. Head teachers also noted that using technology in schools aligns with the modern world and can foster a sense of empowerment and trust among students.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 photographs spanning from the 1880s to the 1990s, capturing over a century of children's lives in Liverpool and offering a social history of the city. The oldest photograph, from 1887, depicts the Rollo children from Waterloo Park. The exhibition, curated by Kay Jones, includes images of children at play and also highlights those who worked during their childhood, aiming to present both the positive and negative experiences of growing up. The exhibition runs until September 25th.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has mutually terminated his Barrow contract to join a National League rival, potentially playing against his former club on February 18th. Striker Keating, 21, recommended by Micky Adams, has also joined, with his move pending international clearance. Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson described Anderson as a leader and Keating as young and hungry. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone, having won only one of their last six matches.

Bolivia has enacted a new law allowing 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization, a move Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera stated reflects the country's needs and aims to balance reality with law and international treaties. The legislation also imposes a 30-year jail sentence for child homicide and was signed by Mr. Garcia in the absence of President Evo Morales. This law comes as over 500,000 children in Bolivia already work, with many in difficult conditions, and the government hopes it will help eradicate extreme poverty, despite the International Labour Organisation's recommendation of a minimum working age of 15, or 14 for developing countries. The ILO is currently reviewing the legislation to determine if it violates international child labor regulations.

O'Donnell, a 50-year-old actress, experienced a heart attack after helping someone with their car, experiencing symptoms like nausea and aches. She researched "women's heart attack symptoms" online, took aspirin, and visited a cardiologist the next day, who found a 99% blocked artery and inserted a stent. O'Donnell referred to her attack as a "widow maker" and advised women to recognize symptoms and call 911, noting she did not call emergency services herself.

Che Labastide-Wellington, a boy from Harrow, was fatally stabbed in an alleyway in Kenton on Saturday evening around 00:30 GMT after a fight, and was pronounced dead an hour later. A 16-year-old boy was also stabbed and is in stable condition. Police believe Che was targeted later and was not involved in an earlier altercation where youths were denied entry to a party. A 21-year-old man has been arrested on suspicion of murder, along with two boys aged 15 and 16 who have been bailed, and a 14-year-old boy is being held for possession of an offensive weapon.

Denmark reorganized its patient diagnosis system, particularly for non-obvious cancer cases, by implementing a three-route model. This approach addresses long waiting times and vague symptoms that previously hindered early diagnosis. The first route involves fast-track diagnosis and treatment for "alarm" symptoms, with a legal requirement for investigation within 30 days of GP referral. The second route establishes diagnosis centers for patients with undiagnosed symptoms, offering quick tests and scans. The third route utilizes "yes-no" centers for patients with minor symptoms, providing rapid testing to rule out serious conditions. These changes have improved diagnosis organization, not increased system flooding, and have led to better survival rates, with Denmark showing faster improvement compared to other Scandinavian countries.

Powys council will take over the role of regulating estate agents from the OFT, which was disbanded by the UK government. Powys will receive £170,000 annually to issue warning and banning orders against dishonest agents or those breaching estate agent laws. Complaints will still be handled by local authority trading standards departments, who will refer cases to Powys if the Estate Agents Act is believed to have been breached. James Munro from Powys council will lead the new team, expressing hope that this will lead to more contracts and outside work for Powys in the future.

NHS Employers has approved a plan to reshape the healthcare workforce, allowing nurses and pharmacists to take on additional tasks with further training, following a Nuffield Trust review that identified nurses filling in for doctors and pharmacists for GPs. This initiative aims to address gaps in junior doctor rotas and the increasing patient load for GPs, and is seen as beneficial due to the shift towards managing long-term conditions. While the report highlights opportunities for improved patient care and more rewarding roles for staff, unions caution against using this as a quick fix for NHS problems, emphasizing the importance of quality training for doctors and adequate funding for workforce development.

Avon and Somerset Police closed the Lower Bristol Road in Bath at Rackfield Place following a crash at 03:00 GMT. The A36 road closure, which was lifted at 14:00 GMT, caused disruption and delays to commuters and bus services. Investigations into the collision are ongoing, and while some First bus services had resumed a normal schedule, it was expected to take a few hours for all services to return to normal.

Natural Resources Wales (NRW) estimated that a tidal lagoon would cause 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout to die annually during migration, based on the "best available evidence." Tidal Lagoon Power (TLP) disputed these figures, claiming they lacked a "clear scientific basis" and were based on "what if" scenarios, stating their own computer modeling estimated a "worst case scenario" of 2% fish mortality. TLP also alleged NRW refused to share its methodology, while NRW stated they had shared extensive information and data, including their methodology, with TLP over 18 months, and expressed surprise and disappointment at TLP's criticism. The £1.3bn Swansea tidal lagoon project is intended as a test bed for larger versions, with UK government ministers reviewing the scheme's viability, and the Welsh Government expressing strong support but seeking clarity on the UK government's position.

Northern Ireland's Enterprise, Trade and Investment Minister Arlene Foster announced the development of a new industry-led agri-food marketing body, similar to Scotland Food and Drink, to be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board (AFSB). This initiative aims to provide strategic leadership and direction for marketing activities in the Northern Ireland agri-food industry, which is crucial for economic growth and supports nearly 100,000 jobs. Agriculture Minister Michelle O'Neill welcomed the move, acknowledging the need for better coordination of marketing activities, but also noted potential implications for other organizations, including her department.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a project to plant 40,000 native trees at Brackfield Wood in the Faughan Valley, as part of a larger UK-wide initiative to plant millions of trees to commemorate those who died in WW1. This four-year project aims to create a living tribute to the estimated 40,000 people from the island of Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict. The public is invited to participate in the tree planting, with the charity providing saplings and advising volunteers on appropriate footwear. Brackfield Wood, located near Derry city, is intended to be a place for wildlife to thrive and for people to walk, relax, and reflect.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for "Someone Else's Skin," a thriller about domestic violence and honor crime, praised for its fine writing, atmosphere, and plotting. Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution honor for her 23-year career creating the female detective VI Warshawski, who was described as a "game changer" and an "action hero," and for her work supporting female crime writers through Sisters In Crime. The awards were presented at the North Yorkshire crime writing festival.

Mitchell Santner, a 24-year-old left-arm batsman and spinner who made his Test debut in 2015, will rejoin the Worcestershire Rapids following June's ICC Trophy in England. He previously broke his finger in his second game for the county in 2016, which director of cricket Steve Rhodes described as a "massive blow" to the team's qualifying hopes. Santner expressed his frustration with the injury and his eagerness to return and make an impact with both bat and ball. Worcestershire also signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old millionaire, was killed in 2008 on the hard shoulder of a dual carriageway in Kiev by a speeding car with stolen license plates that did not stop. The coroner recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, stating that Pring's inebriation lowered his guard and that the evidence, though circumstantial, was overwhelming. Pring's wife, Ganna Ziuzina, who was 19 years his junior, tried to claim his assets shortly after his death, and his family believes he was murdered in a staged hit-and-run accident. Ziuzina, who claimed to be a teacher but was a lap dancer, sold Pring's car and moved funds from his bank account, and was having an affair with another man. Ukrainian police initially closed their inquiry but reopened it as a murder inquiry in 2011, and the case remains active.

Charlie Fearns, from Merseyside, needs to return to Seattle, America for experimental T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital because his last transplant failed and the treatment is unavailable in the UK. His mother, Sophie Fearns, expressed extreme gratitude to an anonymous donor who has paid for the treatment, stating it means an incredible amount to the family. Charlie has been ill since he was three, and after a third relapse in April, there were no further treatment options in the UK. The family received confirmation of the paid treatment via email, and it will commence as soon as possible, with the date expected next week.

Apple has implemented a security measure to prevent unauthorized access to iCloud, following reports of intimate celebrity photos being stolen using third-party software. This measure introduces an extra step requiring a four-digit code, sent to a trusted mobile phone or via the Find My iPhone app, after a user enters their username and password on an unfamiliar device. While this system was previously available, it did not apply to Apple's backup service, allowing attackers to download data using tools like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker. The software's creator has acknowledged that Apple's changes have secured this vulnerability. However, concerns remain about the recovery key's memorability and the potential for it to be lost or stolen, which could lead to permanent data loss. Security experts advocate for two-factor authentication to be the default setting for all users, not just an opt-in choice, and Apple plans to encourage its adoption more actively.

Wright is reportedly set to buy 20% of Billericay Football Club and become a director, though the finer details of the deal are not yet released. Billericay is currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division. The club was recently acquired by Glenn Tamplin, who is investing £10,000 weekly, and has signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

Mr Ashley has been asked to give evidence regarding the treatment of his workers, following a BBC investigation into the Derbyshire company's warehouse working practices. Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills (BIS) select committee, has given Mr Ashley until March 21 to respond. Mr Ashley had previously invited the committee to a meeting at the company's Shirebrook base, but the committee normally meets in public at Westminster and agreed to this practice. Despite being offered alternative dates, Mr Ashley has not accepted any or agreed in principle to attend, and the committee reserves the right to take further action, including seeking the House of Commons' support for any complaint of contempt, if he fails to agree to attend. Sports Direct has not commented on the BBC's request, though the company has previously pledged to review worker rights with Mr Ashley's oversight.

Colleagues of a murdered opposition politician, led by Ilya Yashin, have completed a report titled "Putin. War," which compiles facts from media since the 2014 annexation of Crimea and the conflict in eastern Ukraine. The report argues that President Vladimir Putin is waging war in Ukraine for his own purposes, citing evidence that Russian soldiers and equipment, directed by Russian generals, were decisive in rebel victories. The report also details volunteer soldiers' admissions of being directed by Russian generals and notes that salaries for these volunteers can reach $2,000-3,000 per month, with overall Russian spending on the conflict estimated at 53 billion roubles. The report's authors faced difficulties in publishing due to fear among publishers, and the opposition accuses Putin of orchestrating the war to improve his popularity, a goal they admit he achieved.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, a 34-year-old from Wath-Upon-Dearn in Rotherham, was discovered at the Woodhead Tunnels off the A628 in Derbyshire at 11:00 BST on Monday. A post-mortem revealed his death was caused by head injuries. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman have been arrested in Sheffield by South Yorkshire Police and are currently in custody.

Carwyn Jones, the First Minister, expressed frustration that he did not see the Article 50 letter before its publication and that devolved administrations were not invited to contribute to its drafting, viewing this as a lack of respect. Welsh Secretary Alun Cairns countered that the UK government is acting in the interests of the whole UK, and that Wales was mentioned in the letter. Prime Minister Theresa May stated in the letter that the UK government will consult on the devolution of powers returning to the UK, expecting a significant increase in decision-making power for devolved administrations. However, questions remain about which specific powers will be devolved and whether funding will accompany them, with Carwyn Jones fearing a lack of funds after 2020.

Two cars were damaged in an incident in the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry on Friday night, which Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin described as "mindless attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community." Police were carrying out duties when they were attacked, and the PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page appealed to parents to know their children's whereabouts and activities.

Mr. Charney, the founder of the company, was removed last year due to employee complaints and accusations of misusing company funds. The company's board stated in a San Francisco court filing that they do not anticipate his return, citing evidence of illicit emails to female employees and racially derogatory taunts, which violate the company's sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policy. Mr. Charney's lawyer claims the company invaded his privacy to extort him, and that many statements are false. This filing is in response to Mr. Charney's defamation lawsuit against the company and its chair. American Apparel was also granted a restraining order against him to prevent negative press and attempts to remove board members.

The upcoming basketball game between Great Britain and Greece will be covered on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. Great Britain is seeking revenge after losing to Greece 92-64 in Patras earlier this month, though Greece will be missing three players from that squad. GB guard Teddy Okereafor expressed excitement about playing in London at the Copper Box, noting it's an important preparation game for EuroBasket 2017. This match is Great Britain's only home game before the tournament begins in September with a qualifying group in Istanbul, Turkey. Following the game against Greece, the team will participate in a four-team tournament in Poland as their final warm-up before EuroBasket.

The passage describes the author's experience obtaining and reporting on the first iPhone shortly after its unveiling by Steve Jobs. Initially, the iPhone was not readily available to the press, but the author managed to get a brief look at it from Apple's marketing chief, Phil Schiller, for a news segment. This coverage led to some viewer complaints about undue prominence given to a product launch, which the author defended by arguing that some products represent a significant change in how people live. The author reflects on the revolutionary impact of the smartphone, comparing its transformative potential to the Model T Ford, and highlights how smartphones have changed photography and enabled mobile connectivity, marking the beginning of the mobile connected era.

Seven cats in Melton Mowbray, Leicestershire, have died after ingesting a toxic substance, with the most recent victim being a seven-month-old cat named Meereen. Meereen's owner, Adria Pearce, described finding the cat shivering and foaming at the mouth before she was taken to the vet, where it was confirmed she had consumed antifreeze. The RSPCA is investigating whether the poisonings were accidental or deliberate and is urging residents to store pesticides and chemicals safely, and to ensure no leaks or spills of antifreeze occur.

Despite the Syriza government's agreement to austerity and liberalization measures mandated by creditors, there are no street demonstrations in Athens, and Greece's resorts are experiencing a surge in tourism, with Athens airport expecting 25 million arrivals. The passage suggests this calm might be due to holidaymakers preferring Greece over areas affected by the Islamic State, or anticipation of the details of the â‚¬86bn bailout agreement. The government's shift to accepting terms previously opposed is attributed to a "near-death experience" in July, leading to a TINA ("there is no alternative") stance. Prime Minister Tsipras remains popular despite failing to end fiscal austerity and imposing monetary austerity through continued bank closures, which hinders credit for businesses and threatens Christmas retail. The new bailout's success hinges on Tsipras offering hope for better times, and creditors, particularly Berlin, must offer debt forgiveness to facilitate genuine recovery.

Ross Kemp is returning to EastEnders for a brief appearance as Grant Mitchell to reunite with his mother, Peggy, for her final episodes. Peggy, played by Dame Barbara, announced her character would be killed off after her cancer returned. Kemp, who last played Grant in 2006, stated he couldn't turn down the opportunity to be with his close friend Barbara for her character's send-off. Grant Mitchell, a memorable character who arrived in 1990 with his brother Phil, will be reunited with his mother and brother for emotional scenes.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and fatally attacked 24-year-old Alice Ruggles, leading to his conviction for murder and a sentence of at least 22 years. Alice's parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, learned of her death from Northumbria Police and immediately suspected Dhillon due to his obsessive stalking. Alice's mother expressed guilt for reassuring her daughter and dismissing her sister's concerns about Dhillon's threats. The Alice Ruggles Trust has been established by her parents to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking, aiming to remember Alice for her vibrant personality.

French firm EDF approved funding for the £18bn Hinkley Point project, with contracts expected to be signed on Friday, but the UK government, through Business Secretary Greg Clark, stated they will "consider carefully" before backing it, leading EDF's chief executive to cancel a trip to the site. Critics have raised concerns about environmental damage, escalating costs, and foreign government involvement, with Chinese investors providing one-third of the cost. The government launched a further review of the project hours after EDF's board vote, which was seen as a significant development impacting Anglo-French relations and potentially signaling a policy change. The Nuclear Industry Association urged a swift decision to avoid energy supply problems, while environmentalists and manufacturers expressed concerns about the project's value and delays. Hinkley Point C is projected to supply 7% of the UK's electricity, and EDF described it as a "unique asset for French and British industries," but the project has faced financial capacity concerns for EDF, with a board member and finance director resigning due to the project's perceived risks.

A newly designed divorce application form in England and Wales asks for the name of the person a spouse has committed adultery with, which family lawyers believe adds conflict and complexity, although the Ministry of Justice states there is no obligation to name this individual. While guidance on the form clarifies it's not normally necessary, lawyers fear people will fill in the box, potentially involving the third party in court proceedings, leading to delays and increased costs. In 2015, adultery was cited in 12,148 of over 100,000 divorces granted in England and Wales, with "unreasonable behaviour" being a more common reason. Lawyers also note that clients often want to involve the new partner, but this can reflect poorly on the petitioner and is generally viewed unfavorably by judges.

There is a conflict in Welsh forestry policy, with some believing too much emphasis is placed on the environment at the expense of timber production, while others argue commercial forests harm wildlife. Confor, a forestry industry promoter, warns that 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost since 2001 and need replanting to meet demand, as Britain is the third-largest wood importer globally. The Welsh government aims for a balance between environmental, economic, and social aspects of forestry, citing its Glastir scheme and Woodlands for Wales strategy. However, Confor believes the current system is too bureaucratic and that the focus on environmental aspects is prioritized over commercial forestry, hindering the planting of new woodland needed to meet targets and satisfy the timber market.

A boy was seriously injured after being struck by a vehicle on Bank Street in Coatbridge, near Langloan Primary School, at approximately 16:40. Emergency services transported him to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow.

Defence attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko presented Ushakov medals to Arctic Convoys veterans, including Able seaman Charles Lewis, who described the experience as an honor. The Foreign Office initially blocked the award due to rules on foreign medals, but an exception was made, allowing President Vladimir Putin to present the first medals in London on June 16, 2013. The Russian embassy stated the convoys were a material expression of their wartime alliance, providing supplies that helped defeat the Germans on the Eastern Front. The Arctic Convoys, which involved vessels traveling from Britain to northern Russia during World War II, faced constant threats from German U-boats and aircraft, severe weather, and ice, resulting in the loss of 104 merchant and 16 military vessels and thousands of Allied seamen's lives. Winston Churchill reportedly called the missions "the worst journey in the world."

HM Inspectorate of Probation found delays in offenders starting unpaid work and too many were excused for non-attendance, with one offender completing only 16 hours in 17 months. The Ministry of Justice is acting on the report's 15 recommendations, which aim to improve the "community payback" scheme, involving tasks like garden maintenance and litter-picking, for around 70,000 offenders annually. While inspectors noted instances of high-quality work and offenders gaining skills, they also found that unpaid work was often viewed solely as punishment, a "wasted opportunity." Recommendations include reducing how often offenders are turned away when on time and matching work objectives to offender circumstances. The chief inspector called for urgent remedial action, and the Ministry of Justice acknowledged the need for more effective rehabilitation, including ensuring offenders attend on time and face consequences for non-compliance.

A newspaper headline called a comedian a "hypocrite" for campaigning for economic and political revolution to help the poor while living in a luxury home, an accusation he has faced before. When questioned by a reporter about his own accommodation while supporting residents facing eviction, the comedian called the journalist "a snide" and walked off. He has not responded to inquiries about legal action against the newspaper but has tweeted about their accusations using the hashtag #TheSunLogic. Previously, he has acknowledged his wealth and fame, stating that revolution means change, including personal change and sharing wealth, but that systemic change is also necessary. He also believes that focusing on his hypocrisy distracts from the real issues of economic disparity and ecological disaster.

Dr. Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, accelerated the mapping of the human genome, a feat that drew criticism from the scientific community but undeniably sped up the process. He later focused on creating a synthetic life form, an organism named Synthia, developed over a decade by scientists at the J Craig Venter Institute. Venter's career was marked by a sense of urgency, stemming from his experiences in Vietnam, and a drive to decode genes efficiently, leading him to develop faster methods and eventually establish private research institutes. His work, including the sequencing of the first complete genome of a free-living organism and the ambitious goal of cracking the human genetic code, often challenged scientific conventions and generated controversy, but also provided him with the financial independence to pursue his research. He has also undertaken projects like exploring ocean microbes to understand gene evolution and function, and believes synthetic microbes could revolutionize industry and help address environmental issues.

Research commissioned by England's School Food Trust found that four out of five children in England who ate school lunches had tried new foods at school, and half of parents reported their children requested school lunch foods be cooked at home. The most popular vegetables among children were carrots, sweetcorn, and peas, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were least popular. School meals are seen as a way to encourage children to try new foods and increase dietary variety, with school meals in England now adhering to strict nutritional guidelines. Approximately four in 10 primary school children in England eat school lunches, and a higher proportion, about 46%, of children in Scotland eat school lunches.

Alvaro Morata, a 23-year-old striker currently playing for Spain at Euro 2016, joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid. Real Madrid has an option to buy him back for up to 30 million euros. Morata has scored three goals for Spain in France and previously scored 27 goals in two years for Juventus, winning two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. He played in the 2014 Champions League final for Real Madrid and scored in the 2015 final for Juventus. Morata began his career at Real Madrid, debuting for the first team at 18 and scoring 10 goals for them.

Wilson rejoined Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013 and has been without a team since May. The 30-year-old made 51 appearances in his second spell at Forest, having previously spent four seasons there before joining Celtic. He has also played for Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the world's third largest retailer, is exiting the US market by selling its loss-making Fresh & Easy chain, which has operated 200 stores in California, Nevada, and Arizona since 2007. Approximately 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business as part of the deal with Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity company run by Ron Burkle. Tesco will loan the new business around £80m, and the remaining 50 stores are expected to close. The disposal of the Fresh & Easy brand will cost Tesco £150m, though some of this is a loan that may be repaid, and Tesco has the option to buy a stake if Yucaipa's venture becomes profitable. This move follows Tesco's first fall in annual profits in 20 years.
The passage describes an athlete who experienced racial abuse but overcame it, and after considering representing France, is now aiming for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics.

A new inventory of French Alps glaciers, compiled by Marie Gardent and colleagues from the University of Savoie, reveals a significant reduction in ice coverage. In the late 1960s/early 1970s, the ice fields covered approximately 375 sq km, a figure that dropped to about 275 sq km by the late 2000s, representing a 26% loss over 40 years. This retreat is more pronounced in the southern Alps, with glaciers in the Belledonne Massif nearly disappearing and glacial retreat in the Ecrins Massif being more than three times stronger than in the Mont Blanc Massif. The research, which involved manual inspection to verify satellite data, found that by 1985-86, glacial coverage had decreased to around 340 sq km, with the withdrawal accelerating since then. This trend mirrors findings of glacier retreat in other parts of the Alps.

Scotland has won all five of their qualifiers and will host Iceland, who are ranked one place higher, at Falkirk Stadium. A victory would almost guarantee Scotland a place in the finals, a feat they have narrowly missed in previous play-offs. The outcome of this match and the return fixture in Reykjavik are likely to determine the group winner. Scotland is in a strong position to qualify automatically, even without a play-off, as the best six of the eight group runners-up also advance. Scotland's squad includes 12 players who play outside Scotland, with some at English clubs, in Sweden, and in the US National Women's Soccer League, including Kim Little. Forward Evans, who recently won the women's Bundesliga with Bayern Munich, believes playing in top leagues like Germany's improves the national team by exposing players to a higher level of competition and different playing cultures.

Stuart Campbell was arrested in the west of England following a complaint from a woman in south London who alleged harassment over a two-year period. Campbell, who was released on bail, stated the issue concerned tweets that he insists were not threatening, accusing the media of using innuendo to encourage speculation. The Metropolitan Police confirmed they are investigating an allegation of online harassment made by a woman in her 30s. Campbell, a blogger and former computer games reviewer, launched the Wings Over Scotland blog in 2011 and is a campaigner for Scottish independence. He has stated that the alleged events relate entirely to publicly visible tweets from his account, none of which are threatening.

Peta has proposed replacing the Jolly Fisherman mascot of Skegness with a fish mascot named "Skegness - A Happy Plaice," arguing that the current mascot evokes images of animal cruelty. Peta's representative, Dawn Carr, cited the suffering of fish being caught as the reason for this concern. However, the mayor of Skegness, Carl Macey, stated that while all suggestions are welcome, he believes there is little support for removing Jolly, as the mascot is loved by both adults and children and is not perceived as promoting animal cruelty. The original Jolly Fisherman poster was created in 1908 to encourage train travel to Skegness and has become a symbol of the resort.

Scotland secured a victory over Georgia, with tries from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, Stuart Hogg (twice), and Hamish Watson. Vasil Lobzhanidze scored two tries for Georgia. Scotland dominated possession for much of the game, though Georgia's scrum proved effective at times, leading to a yellow card for Scotland's Moray Low. Scotland's head coach, Vern Cotter, praised his team's performance, particularly their ability to score points and manage the game.

Widnes defeated Castleford 38-26, with tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, Chris Bridge, Lloyd White (2), and Joe Mellor. Paddy Flynn scored three tries for Castleford, with Larne Patrick and Luke Gale also contributing. Widnes held a significant lead before Castleford's late surge, but ultimately secured the win. This victory moved Widnes to seventh place in the league, while Castleford remained in sixth.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti detainee, was released from the US facility in Cuba after a review panel determined he was not a continuing significant threat. He had been held since 2002 after being arrested in Pakistan on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, which he denies. Al-Odah argued he traveled to Afghanistan and Pakistan to teach the Koran and provide humanitarian aid. His release, which occurred on a Wednesday morning US time, brings the total number of inmates at the base to 148. He will now spend at least a year at a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait as part of the release terms.

The earworm 'PPAP' (Pen-Pineapple-Apple-Pen) was performed by Piko-Taro, a fictional character played by Japanese entertainer Kazuhiko Kosaka, and features lyrics about combining a pen with an apple and a pineapple. The song's viral success is attributed to its addictive beat, silly lyrics, and simple dance, with the original YouTube video amassing over 4 million views and a Facebook version by 9GAG exceeding 44 million views. While some viewers find the song amusing and catchy, others find it irritating, and it has gained international attention with numerous tributes and covers from various artists and social media stars, leading to comparisons with Psy's global hit "Gangnam Style."

Anzac Day commemorations in London included an early morning service at Hyde Park Corner, a parade to the Cenotaph, and a service at Westminster Abbey. The day commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces in World War One, specifically the Anzac landings at Gallipoli. The first commemoration in the capital was in 1916, attended by King George V. The events honor the sacrifices of Australians and New Zealanders in all wars, with participants reflecting on the courage and heroism of Anzac troops. The Gallipoli campaign was a significant and bloody battle aimed at removing the Ottoman empire from the war.

Clarkson, a 30-year-old player who scored nine goals at Dundee last season, joined Premiership Well for a second spell in July and is ready to make his St Mirren debut in the Championship against Alloa on Saturday. He has been playing games and training hard to maintain his match fitness and is looking forward to getting started. Clarkson has been capped twice for Scotland and has made almost 400 senior club appearances for teams like Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. St Mirren is currently eighth in the Championship, seven points ahead of bottom-placed Alloa, and Clarkson believes winning games will build confidence and help the club climb the table.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to Ranjit Boparan on Tuesday, and Unite regional officer Steve Harley confirmed that all current agreements, including pension schemes, will be honored. The Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme was closed in 2004, and current members have an unaffected alternative pension scheme. Boparan Private Office confirmed that existing pension arrangements will continue. The new owner intends to restore Bernard Matthews to profitability through increased investment, cost savings, and utilizing spare capacity to process chicken as well as turkeys.

The council leader announced that the Cowes crossing will be free until July 2nd due to problems with the new vessel, and a review by auditors has been ordered. The chain ferry has experienced breakdowns, run aground, and been suspended due to training issues since its launch on May 14th, with cars also being damaged. Local businesses are concerned about the impact on trade, and compensation for these losses is under discussion, similar to compensation for damaged cars. The council has addressed electrical problems and is manufacturing ramp extensions to prevent vehicles from scraping the concrete, while groundings are attributed to seamanship issues that have since been resolved.

A House of Lords report highlights that fishing communities, who voted heavily for Brexit, risk being marginalized in negotiations, despite the industry's argument that Brexit offers a chance to regain control of UK waters and become a leading fish exporter. The report warns that Britain may have to allow EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters in exchange for continued tariff-free access to the EU market for its fish exports, which constitute a significant portion of the UK's catch. The report also suggests retaining elements of the EU's Common Fisheries Policy, such as basing quotas on scientific advice, and acknowledges the potential for four different fisheries management regimes post-Brexit. While many in the industry are optimistic about Brexit bringing more opportunities, the government aims to ensure British companies have maximum freedom to trade with the single market and to review fisheries management for fair access and sustainable stocks.
DID NOT RECIEIVE A STRING TYPE FROM OUTPUT

Following a fire on March 2nd that disrupted train services, the Environment Agency (EA) suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste. Despite the fire service stating the company was "broadly compliant" with fire safety law after nine visits in the past year, the EA decided to revoke the company's environmental permit, effective August 7th, due to concerns raised by the fire service in February about the potential impact of a fire on residents, transport, and the environment. The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

Syria is working to destroy its chemical weapons, but missed a deadline to hand over its entire stockpile, with Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad citing attacks on shipments by "terrorist groups" and the ongoing war. He also defended the government's actions in Aleppo, denying the use of barrel bombs on civilians and accusing the US of supporting terrorists, while the Syrian government denied reports of rebels seizing Aleppo's central prison, though activist groups claim otherwise. Syria has approximately 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, with only about 4% having left the country, and Russia has urged completion of the transfer by March 1, with a final destruction deadline by the end of June, though the OPCW acknowledges security concerns are slowing the process.

England secured a significant victory over Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series with a day to spare. England posted scores of 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, resulting in their second-largest win against Pakistan by runs. Joe Root was named man of the match for his outstanding performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, along with taking four catches and a wicket. England's captain, Alastair Cook, praised Root's batting and his move to number three. Former England batsman Geoffrey Boycott commended England's performance, while former captain Michael Vaughan anticipates a tight series despite England's current advantage. Pakistan's captain, Misbah-ul-Haq, expressed disappointment with his team's performance, citing a lack of confidence and poor shot selection.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care across Wales. She is gathering evidence from pensioners, their families, and friends to inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies, aiming to highlight both good and poor care. The review will assess factors like physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment, and will also involve discussions with care providers, social care staff, and public bodies. Care Forum Wales supports the review's aims but expresses disappointment that no care home provider experts are included on the main advisory panel.

Sheerin, a 39-year-old former midfielder, has been appointed player-manager at Pittodrie, replacing Neil Cooper. He previously served as player-manager for Arbroath since 2010, leading them to their first national trophy, the Scottish Third Division title and promotion in 2011, though they were later relegated to Scottish League Two. Aberdeen chief executive Duncan Fraser stated that manager Derek McInnes selected Sheerin after a thorough process, and Arbroath chairman John Christison was cooperative in allowing Sheerin to return to Aberdeen. Sheerin also played for other Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden, and earned a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s.

Curtis and Paul Williams will manage Swansea's upcoming match after Bob Bradley's dismissal, with Paul Clement being the preferred candidate for the new manager position. The club, promoted to the Premier League in 2011, has experienced a significant rise from near bankruptcy. Curtis believes the team has lost its identity since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014, attributing this to frequent managerial changes and a dilution of the "Swansea Way." Despite these concerns, Curtis is confident the current squad can avoid relegation, emphasizing the club's history and the importance of staying in the top flight to the local community.

Dr. Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, accelerated the mapping of the human genome, a feat that drew criticism from the scientific community but also led to his wealth. He later focused on creating a synthetic life form, an organism named Synthia, detailed in the journal Science. His early life experiences in Vietnam instilled a sense of urgency, influencing his approach to scientific research. Venter's innovations in gene sequencing, including the use of automated decoding machines and focusing on messenger RNA, allowed for unprecedented rates of gene sequence production. This success, however, was met with skepticism from figures like James Watson. Venter left the NIH to establish private research institutes, achieving milestones such as sequencing the first complete genome of a free-living organism. His commercial venture, Celera Genomics, aimed to decode the human genetic code, publishing results alongside the public project. Venter also led expeditions to collect marine life for genetic study and expressed optimism about the potential of synthetic microbes to revolutionize industry and address environmental issues.

The Sutton Trust warns that many UK apprenticeships are low quality and too short compared to other European countries, with fewer than 200,000 of England's 520,000 annual apprenticeships being at level three or above, unlike Germany where over half of employers offer apprenticeships and 90% of those for young people are equivalent to A-levels. The report highlights that since 2010, over half of apprenticeships have been below level three and aimed at older workers, leading to 11 young people competing for each place, and calls for 300,000 new starts annually, predominantly at level three or higher. While the Department for Education states reforms are underway to drive up standards, the Association of Colleges notes the challenge of creating more places and the need to preserve respected lower-level apprenticeships.

Storey, a 37-year-old Briton, won a race in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing over two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. This victory brings her closer to a potential 17th title in Saturday's road race. Storey is Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals, including 11 gold, eight silver, and three bronze from cycling and swimming across six Paralympic Games. She won four golds at the 2012 London Games and has now achieved 21 world titles in both sports. Storey started her career in swimming, winning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics, before transitioning to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United has been expelled from the Football Conference due to financial worries, specifically failing to meet payment deadlines for football creditors totaling £148,000, as well as owing over £70,000 to HMRC. Despite multiple deadline extensions and a takeover by Tommy Agombar, the club could not provide the necessary assurances to the Conference. Chester City has been reinstated as a Conference Premier club and will take Hereford's place, while Hayes & Yeading will remain in Conference South. The club's financial decline since relegation from the Football League in 2012 has been worsened by falling attendances.

James Milner, a 30-year-old former Manchester City player, has retired from international football after earning 61 caps for England since his senior debut in 2009. He was part of the squad for two World Cups and two European Championships, though he only played three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner also holds the record for the most England Under-21 caps with 46, earned from his first appearance in 2004. His sole international goal came in a 5-0 win against Moldova during the 2014 Fifa World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood, a highly influential conductor and founder of the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM), has died at his home in Cambridge after a months-long illness. He led the AAM for approximately 30 years, during which they produced over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Hogwood also held academic positions at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell universities and was artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society. He is remembered for his generosity, his role as a founder of the early-music movement, and his ability to nurture talent, with many leading orchestral players having started their careers under his guidance.

A boy from Northern Ireland, whose identity is being protected, was removed from mainstream schooling due to not coping, and his family is awaiting a place at a special school, which is currently full. His mother expressed concern about his isolation and the system's impact on him, while also worrying about the broader issue of special needs schools being over-subscribed. The Education Authority stated they are reviewing special school provision in Northern Ireland to ensure places are available for children starting in 2016, but could not comment on the specific case due to privacy concerns.

The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) is attempting to take over Newport Gwent Dragons, viewing Rodney Parade as a rugby venue. Newport County has a lease to use the ground until 2023, with primacy of fixtures if they remain in the Football League. Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey stated that County and Newport Squash Club are protected under their current agreements, and the WRU has been informed of this. The WRU's intention to install an artificial surface at Rodney Parade is contrary to Football League rules. Newport County is currently two points above the League Two relegation zone with two games left and faces a significant setback if relegated. The WRU's takeover bid will be voted on by Newport Rugby shareholders on May 9th.

The passage describes a person's experiences during a civil war, including being kidnapped, forced to commit atrocities, and using drugs, followed by their involvement in combating the Ebola crisis in Sierra Leone. After escaping the war and facing hardship, they found hope through a preacher and a project called Lifeline Nehemiah, which encouraged them to contribute to rebuilding the nation. This led to their work in educating communities about Ebola, providing support, and establishing an Ebola treatment unit, ultimately saving many lives. The individual now regrets their past actions but is confident in the future and believes in investing in young people to change the world. The passage also notes that Sierra Leone had 3,955 probable, confirmed, and suspected Ebola deaths.

A public fundraising campaign successfully raised enough money to prevent approximately 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs from being auctioned to pay off a pottery firm's pension debt. The collection will remain on display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, and will be gifted to the Victoria and Albert Museum before being loaned to the Wedgwood Museum. The Wedgwood Museum had inherited the pension bill after the firm collapsed in 2009 and subsequently went into administration in 2010, with a court ruling in 2011 allowing the collection to be sold to reimburse the Pension Protection Fund. The campaign's success ensures the collection, which is considered important for Staffordshire and charts a significant part of Britain's cultural development, will not be sold and scattered globally.

Wright is reportedly set to buy 20% of Billericay Football Club and become a director, though the finer points of the deal are not yet released. Billericay is currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, three points from a play-off spot. The club was recently acquired by Glenn Tamplin, who is investing £10,000 weekly, and has signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

Mark Carney, Governor of the Bank of England, announced he would extend his term by one year, serving until 2019 instead of leaving in 2018 as originally planned, or staying until 2021. This decision was primarily driven by personal circumstances, specifically his daughters' educational milestones in 2018, which made returning to Canada with his family the preferred option. While he acknowledged the professional challenge of leaving during Brexit negotiations, his family's departure timeline limited his ability to extend his tenure further. Carney emphasized that his decision was personal and not indicative of any government policy or reaction to economic forecasts.

The Seasiders took the lead after 12 minutes with a goal from Jamille Matt, assisted by Nathan Delfouneso. Blackpool goalkeeper Sam Slocombe made a save from Matthew Briggs, but Colchester equalized from the resulting corner through Kurtis Guthrie. Colchester missed further chances before halftime, with Slocombe saving from George Elokobi and Guthrie hitting the bar. Tom Aldred missed a chance for Blackpool to win the game late on. Colchester finished the match with 10 men after Sean Murray received a red card for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister in injury time. The match ended in a 1-1 draw.

The Healthy Me programme, developed by Action Mental Health, aims to help P6 and P7 children cope with change and the stresses of transitioning to secondary school. The programme, which has been piloted in five schools and is hoped to be rolled out across Northern Ireland, consists of interactive workshops that focus on emotional wellbeing, seeking help when distressed, and identifying support sources. These workshops also provide teachers with basic training in promoting emotional wellbeing. The initiative was launched at Carrick Primary School, where the pastoral care co-ordinator noted the anxiety children and parents experience during this transition. The programme teaches children coping mechanisms like breathing exercises and relaxation techniques. This initiative aligns with the chief inspector of schools' view that strengthening the resilience of young people is a key challenge in Northern Ireland's education system, given the changing social context and complex challenges children face.

The disused Fawley power station chimney is planned to become the tallest attraction south of London's Shard as the centerpiece of a £1bn "merchant city" development by Fawley Waterside. This development will include a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The oil-fired power station, commissioned in 1971 and capable of powering one million homes, closed in 2013 after over 40 years of operation. The 300-acre site was sold in 2016, and the developers consider the 198-meter-high chimney a signature piece of infrastructure that can be transformed with relatively little investment. An application for outline planning permission is expected later this year, with construction potentially starting in 2018.

At the Hong Kong championships, a 23-year-old named Latham secured GB's second medal, a bronze, in an event where Poland's Adrian Teklinski won gold and Germany's Lucass Liss took silver. In the men's team pursuit, GB lost to Italy for the bronze medal. Joe Truman was outclassed in the men's keirin semi-final, and the GB women's team pursuit finished fifth, failing to reach the bronze-medal ride. Olympic gold medallist Elinor Barker joined a young women's team pursuit squad, and despite not medalling, Barker expressed optimism about their potential for improvement. Olympic bronze medallist Katy Marchant was eliminated in the first round of the women's sprint, attributing her performance to a lack of "zing" after Rio and focusing on preparation for Tokyo.

Ross Kemp is returning to EastEnders to reprise his role as Grant Mitchell for Barbara Windsor's final episodes as Peggy Mitchell. Peggy's character, who left in 2010, reappeared to inform her son Phil that her cancer had returned, and producers have revealed she will die from the disease in the spring. Kemp, who last played Grant in 2006, stated his return is a brief one to reunite the Mitchell family and say goodbye to their mother. Grant Mitchell, a memorable character who arrived in 1990, was involved in significant family dramas and is described as an EastEnders legend returning home to Walford.

Sadio Mane scored twice in quick succession, contributing to Spurs' disappointing performance at Anfield. Manager Pochettino expressed frustration with his team's lack of desire and inability to cope with pressure, stating it makes challenging for the Premier League difficult. Spurs have a poor recent away record against top-six teams, winning only once in their last 17 such matches. Danny Murphy criticized Spurs' defensive setup and lack of pace and mindset away from home, contrasting it with their strong home form.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 declared governor posts in recent elections, marking the biggest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since 1999. APC leader Muhammadu Buhari will be inaugurated on May 29th after defeating President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP lost in key northern states and control of Adamawa, though it retained Rivers State. The APC made historic gains, becoming dominant in the north and the commercial hub of Lagos, but failed to win in any oil-producing states, which could impact oil revenue. While some elections were marred by violence, overall they were more peaceful than in previous years. The PDP's decline is attributed to a desire for change after 16 years in power, defections to the APC, allegations of corruption, and failure to address the insurgency.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt), held in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis from July 19-22, is introducing an augmented reality app that allows visitors to trigger online information, such as videos and band interviews, from items like signs and posters. This feature aims to enhance the festival experience and enable people globally to interact with the event and its atmosphere. The app will provide instant access to information, interviews, and ticket purchasing, with updates provided before and during the festival. This year's acts include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean.

Birmingham academies Park View and Nansen Primary, rated inadequate by Ofsted, will have their funding agreements terminated, potentially leading to their removal from the Park View Educational Trust. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, have been warned of funding termination unless concerns are addressed, including issues like segregation of boys and girls and ensuring a more "broad and balanced" curriculum. A head teacher from one of the "Trojan Horse" schools described parental attempts to undermine her authority during an Ofsted inspection and feeling isolated until the Trojan Horse letter broke. Ofsted reports into 21 schools allegedly targeted for a hardline Muslim takeover found five, including Park View and Oldknow, to be inadequate, with concerns raised about a "culture of fear and intimidation" and an "organised campaign to target certain schools in order to impose a narrow, faith-based ideology." Park View School's work to keep students safe was deemed inadequate, with external speakers not properly vetted and a guest with known extremist views allowed to speak to students. Parents have criticized Ofsted's reports, accusing inspectors of bias and using "loaded questions."

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, sentenced to five years for allegedly plotting to topple the government in Tehran, has had her appeal hearing held in secret. Her husband, Richard Ratcliffe, criticizes the UK government's lack of action and believes his wife is being used as a bargaining chip in a diplomatic dispute. Zaghari-Ratcliffe, arrested last April, has spent time in solitary confinement with her two-year-old daughter Gabriella, whose passport was confiscated, leaving her in Iran with her grandparents. Amnesty International UK considers Zaghari-Ratcliffe a "prisoner of conscience."

Vincent Barker, also known as Vinnie, died in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. The prosecution alleges that eye specialist Honey Rose's conduct was so far below the expected standard that it was criminal, specifically her alleged failure to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs during the test and refer him for further investigation. This failure, the prosecution claims, led to a build-up of fluid in Vinnie's brain, increasing skull pressure and ultimately causing his death, and that his death was preventable if Ms. Rose had performed her job properly. Ms. Rose denies a charge of gross negligence manslaughter.

Clive Weatherhogg was found guilty of coercing a woman into sexual activity and intercourse, filming them, and sending a sexually explicit clip to her sister on Christmas Day. He was also convicted of intentionally causing the woman's sister and father to view sexual images and behaving in a threatening or abusive manner. Weatherhogg, who denied the charges, was placed on the sex offenders register and his case was remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh due to its greater sentencing powers. The judge stated the sentence would reflect society's abhorrence of such conduct, and Weatherhogg was assessed as posing a moderate risk of sexual re-offending.

Ireland scored 165-5 in Greater Noida, with Stuart Thompson hitting 56, Gary Wilson 41 not out, and William Porterfield 39. However, Afghanistan reached 171-4 with two overs remaining, thanks to Samiullah Shenwari's 56 and Mohammad Shahzad's 47. Paul Stirling was dismissed for a duck early in Ireland's innings. Afghanistan's opening partnership of 51 between Shahzad and Najeeb Tarakai was significant. Amir Hamza took two wickets for Afghanistan. Ireland captain William Porterfield felt they fell short of a larger score and their bowling execution could have been better. Ireland also faced a setback with the absence of paceman Boyd Rankin due to a back problem, though he is expected to return for the upcoming ODIs.

Barcelona has made a supplementary tax declaration of 13,550,830.56 euros to cover potential interpretations of contracts related to Neymar's signing, despite insisting they committed no offense and that their original tax payment was in line with obligations. The club paid £48.6m for Neymar, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee, and the total cost is estimated to be £106.8m. Former Barcelona president Sandro Rosell resigned due to accusations of misappropriating money and is under investigation. A judge found sufficient evidence to continue investigations into the transfer, and it is unconfirmed if the case will be dropped following Barcelona's payment.

British detectives have completed their review of the investigation into the murders of David Miller and Hannah Witheridge on Koh Tao, Thailand, and will return to the UK to compile a report and update the victims' families. Two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, are charged with murder, rape, and robbery, and have allegedly confessed, though reports of withdrawn confessions have been denied by Thai police. The UK Foreign Office has expressed concerns about the investigation, particularly regarding DNA sample verification and alleged mistreatment of the suspects. The visit by UK police followed an agreement between the Thai Prime Minister and Mr Cameron. Post-mortem examinations revealed Miller died from drowning and a blow to the head, while Witheridge died from head wounds, with Thai police stating DNA found on Witheridge matched the suspects.

Virtual reality (VR) is being used in unexpected ways by journalists, teachers, healthcare workers, and retailers. The National Autistic Society created a VR film to help people understand autism by experiencing sensory overload, and Alzheimer's Research UK released a film to show the challenges of dementia. Retailers like Ikea and Westfield are using VR for virtual property tours and fashion shows, with Ikea even seeing demand for virtual meatballs. In healthcare, VR is used for surgical training and to treat phobias, with a virtual surgery experience reaching thousands globally. VR is also being used in education, with Google's Expeditions program offering virtual trips and a VR app being developed to improve language skills. While VR has the potential to transform learning, challenges remain, including the cost of hardware for schools.

The "black box" of a downed Su-24 jet was opened in Moscow, with Russian investigators reporting missing flight information that could clarify the jet's location when it was hit. The incident, which occurred on November 24th when Turkish F-16 fighters shot down the jet, has caused a crisis in relations between Russia and Turkey. Turkey claims the jet ignored warnings to leave its airspace, while Russia asserts it was within Syrian airspace. The downing resulted in the death of the pilot and a Russian marine, and the destruction of a helicopter, leading Russia to impose sanctions on Turkey.

Scotland has won all five of their qualifiers and will host Iceland, who are ranked one place higher and also unbeaten, at Falkirk Stadium. A victory would significantly improve Scotland's chances of qualifying for the finals in the Netherlands, with the top six runners-up also advancing. Scotland's forward, Evans, is eager to avoid another play-off loss after previous disappointments. The squad includes 12 players who play outside Scotland, with some at top clubs in Germany and the United States, which Evans believes enhances the national team's performance.

A review for the Commission on Local Tax Reform found no easy solution to the defects in the current system, noting that council tax has had inherent problems since its inception and that a failure to modify it has created further difficulties. The commission, established by the Scottish government and Cosla, is examining different local taxation systems globally. While property taxes are common and considered stable, they cause confusion regarding their purpose and fairness, as they are not linked to current income. Local income taxes are perceived as fairer but create income instability for local authorities and limit their ability to adjust tax rates. Reform is acknowledged as a difficult undertaking due to past experiences. The Scottish government considers the current council tax unfair and is awaiting the commission's report, which will be preceded by a public consultation.

Apple has implemented a security measure to prevent unauthorized access to iCloud, following reports of intimate celebrity photos being stolen using third-party software. This new safety measure introduces an extra step for users logging into unfamiliar devices, requiring a four-digit code sent to a trusted mobile phone or via the Find My iPhone app. Previously, this two-step verification did not apply to Apple's backup service, allowing tools like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker to download data even with two-step verification enabled. The owner of Elcomsoft has acknowledged that Apple's changes now block their technique. While Apple is encouraging users to enable two-factor authentication and use stronger passwords, some experts suggest making it the default option for all users, as single-step verification is vulnerable. Concerns remain about the recovery key, which can be difficult to remember and could be lost or stolen, potentially leading to permanent data loss or unauthorized access.

In the May election, UKIP spent £2,956,737, the Tories £2,980,815, the Lib Dems £1,580,575, and Labour £1,027,339. UKIP's spending per vote was 68p, Labour's 26p, the Conservatives' 79p, and the Lib Dems' £1.45. The Green Party spent £534,249, or 43p per vote. The six highest-spending parties, including the SNP's £267,372, collectively spent £9,347,087 on campaigning, with all but Labour increasing their spending compared to the 2009 European election campaign.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, has mutually cancelled his Barrow contract to join a National League rival, potentially playing against his former club on February 18th. Striker Keating, 21, recommended by Micky Adams, has had previous spells with Irish clubs and awaits international clearance. Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson described Anderson as a leader and Keating as young and hungry. The Gulls are four points above the relegation zone, with one win in their last six games.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse named Many Clouds collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day, having narrowly beaten Thistlecrack. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the cause of death was a "severe pulmonary haemorrhage," an episode described as rare and potentially occurring in horses without underlying health issues. While Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, including overheating and wobbling, he had never collapsed before and displayed no such symptoms on the day of his death. The horse's trainer, Oliver Sherwood, called him the "horse of a lifetime," and despite past treatments for overheating, the report concludes his death was due to a rare hemorrhage, not a linked underlying condition.

Presiding officer Tricia Marwick became emotional as veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond bid farewell to the parliament, as both are standing down ahead of the May 5th election. Salmond, in his valedictory address, reiterated his belief that Scotland is diverse rather than divided and that there is a consensus for the parliament to gain greater responsibility, while also noting that the Scotland Bill did not fully meet promises made during the referendum. He also made lighthearted remarks about competition from the UK budget and the Cheltenham races. McNeil, who has served since 1999, warned that Holyrood has lessons to learn from Westminster, particularly regarding the committee system and the need for accountability and scrutiny. Former Scottish Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie is also leaving, humorously mentioning she will miss Finance Secretary John Swinney.

The upcoming film, set for release in US cinemas on March 17, 2017, will feature Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, and Josh Gad as LeFou. The star will portray Mrs. Potts, a role previously voiced by Dame Angela Lansbury, and Kevin Kline will play Maurice, Belle's father. Bill Condon, known for directing "Dreamgirls" and the last two "Twilight" films, will direct the movie, with filming commencing at Shepperton Studios in May.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) will announce its decisions regarding potential charges related to the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster, where 96 football fans died, at a meeting with victims' relatives. New inquests concluded the fans were unlawfully killed, and evidence files concerning 23 suspects, stemming from investigations into the disaster's causes and the subsequent police conduct, were referred to the CPS. Relatives are awaiting these decisions with anticipation, hoping for accountability after a long struggle.

Chelmsford Prison has experienced numerous incidents of packages being thrown over its walls, with a former inmate describing the jail as notorious for being flooded with mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. Residents living near the prison have witnessed packages being thrown over the wall multiple times in recent weeks. The Ministry of Justice stated that staff work hard to prevent contraband from entering prisons and that new laws allow for jail sentences of up to two years for those who smuggle packages over prison walls. While a former inmate claimed drones were used to deliver contraband, the Ministry of Justice reported no evidence of drones entering the Chelmsford site.

Brian Wright, 55, is on trial at Luton Crown Court for allegedly causing serious injury by dangerous driving after striking Sylvia Blackburn, 72, a lollipop lady of 20 years, outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Mr. Wright claims he was blinded by the setting sun and denies causing serious injury, stating he heard a bump and was in shock. Mrs. Blackburn suffered serious head injuries and is now in residential care. The jury heard that Mr. Wright's VW Golf failed to stop for a red light while Mrs. Blackburn was escorting a woman and her daughter across the road. The trial is ongoing.

Laura Muir will miss next year's Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast due to her veterinary medicine studies, with her final year exams scheduled for May, after the Commonwealths take place in April. Muir, who finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, stated that while she loves running for Scotland, her degree is a priority. She believes she has at least two or three more Olympics ahead of her and is considering the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target, aiming to run in Birmingham. Muir achieved a new outdoor personal best in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, finishing with a time of 14 minutes 52.07 seconds, despite it being her fifth race in ten days.

A search is underway in Chapelizod, Dublin, for Trevor Deely, who disappeared in December 2000 after a Christmas party. The search, covering three acres of woodlands, will involve excavations and is expected to last several weeks. A review of his disappearance included enhancing CCTV footage showing Deely talking to an unidentified man in black on Baggot Street, and later being followed by the same man on Haddington Road. Gardai have renewed their appeal for the man to come forward.

Juan Martin del Potro, ranked 165th, defeated a Swiss player 3-6 6-3 7-6 (7-2) 6-3 after overcoming significant injury problems and three wrist operations, marking his first Grand Slam since the Australian Open in 2014. In the same half of the draw as Andy Murray, Del Potro will face Lucas Pouille or Donald Young next. Nick Kyrgios, the 15th seed, also advanced by beating Dustin Brown 6-7 (3-7) 6-1 2-6 6-4 6-4 in a rain-affected match and will play Feliciano Lopez next. Feliciano Lopez came back from two sets down to defeat Fabio Fognini. Routine victories were also secured by Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations until they apologized to Caf for complaints lodged during the previous year's tournament, specifically regarding a contentious penalty awarded to hosts Equatorial Guinea in their quarter-final match. Morocco was allowed to enter the 2017 qualifying draw after the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned a ban imposed after they refused to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola fears, reducing their fine from $1 million to $50,000.
