Both nations have since resolved their issues with Caf and are preparing for the 2017 Nations Cup, with Tunisia aiming for a record thirteenth consecutive appearance.

McLaren, a team with a rich history of 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and eight constructors' titles, is currently experiencing a slump, with their current goals being fourth on the grid and decent points. The team's decline began in 2013 due to chassis design issues, and while they have improved their car, problems persist with the Honda power unit. This contrasts with their past successes, including a dominant period with Honda in the late 1980s and early 1990s, and later success with Mercedes engines in 1998-99. Despite a constructors' title in 1998 and a near miss in 2007, the team faced disqualification and fines due to a spying scandal. Further controversy arose in 2009 with a "lie-gate" incident. While McLaren achieved victories until 2012, titles have been absent since Hamilton's 2008 win, and wins have ceased entirely. The team's history is characterized by cycles of triumph and decline, from their founding by Bruce McLaren and early titles in the 1970s to periods of success under Ron Dennis, including partnerships with Honda and Mercedes. Dennis, who returned to the team after the 2013 season, believes McLaren will break Mercedes' dominance and win championships again, a sentiment shared by Fernando Alonso, who rejoined the team in 2015 seeking a third title. McLaren's leadership is confident in their progress, expecting Honda to improve their engine and lead to future championships, though currently, their success relies on belief.

Paramedics were called to Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on 6 October 2014 following a sudden death. Police found alcohol was still being served as late as 04:49 BST. Colleen O'Neill, the license holder, and James Thomas were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. The defense admitted that licensing laws were not strictly adhered to and the premises had not been run properly. The judge, citing Ms. O'Neill's "appalling record," ordered the bar's closure for three months and fined Ms. O'Neill £3,000 and Mr. Thomas £1,000.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for most 3-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry hit eight 3-pointers, surpassing his previous record of 272. Klay Thompson added 26 points for the Warriors. In another game, the Chicago Bulls, with 16 points and 15 rebounds from Pau Gasol, overcame a halftime deficit to defeat the Miami Heat 89-78, impacting Miami's playoff chances.

YouTube star Bas van Velzen visited Melwood, the training ground of Liverpool Football Club, where he met players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic. The players initially believed Van Velzen was a competition winner receiving a masterclass, but soon realized he was a skilled free-kick specialist, a YouTube sensation known for his dead-ball abilities. Van Velzen expressed his enjoyment of playing with his idols and surprising the players with his skills, even unveiling Balotelli's infamous slogan at the end of his visit.

Women diagnosed with breast cancer who carry the BRCA1 gene mutation can significantly reduce their risk of death by having their ovaries removed, a procedure known as oophorectomy. A study found that this surgery was associated with a 62% drop in breast cancer deaths for BRCA1 carriers, and a 65% reduction in death from all causes. The protective effect of oophorectomy was apparent immediately after diagnosis and lasted for 15 years, particularly benefiting women with estrogen-receptor negative breast cancer. While the study focused on BRCA1, further research is needed on BRCA2 carriers and the timing of the procedure in relation to diagnosis.

On Easter morning in Durham, North Carolina, a married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were killed when an Amtrak train, the Carolinian, struck them as they lingered on the tracks. The train, en route from Charlotte to New York City, was on property owned by Norfolk-Southern. None of the 166 passengers on board were injured, though one passenger received treatment for falling ill during the delay. The Lowes were pronounced dead at the scene, and the train resumed its journey after a delay of approximately two hours and 45 minutes. A man who knew the couple suggested they may have been homeless, noting they had a grocery cart with items and had asked for help crossing the difficult railroad tracks with it.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former informant for the DEA who worked undercover for 27 years, is facing deportation from the United States after retiring due to declining health. Toro, who was a mid-level member of the Medellin Cartel in the 1980s, fled Colombia fearing for his life and later provided information to the DEA that aided in the prosecution of figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega. He was promised US citizenship in exchange for his work, but this has not materialized, leaving him technically living in the US illegally. The DEA has refused to assist him with his citizenship, and Toro fears for his life if deported back to Colombia, stating he would be dead within four hours. He is currently in limbo, unable to secure a green card or passport, which prevents him from collecting social security benefits.

The US body regulating internet addresses, ICANN, is investigating the Canadian company Vox Populi Registry Ltd. for allegedly using the '.sucks' domain name to charge exorbitant sums to celebrities like Kevin Spacey and companies seeking to protect their reputations. Major brands such as YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, and Yahoo have had '.sucks' domains purchased, with Kevin Spacey reportedly paying to have his name removed. ICANN is collaborating with US and Canadian regulators to determine if Vox Populi's actions are illegal, as an advisory panel has labeled the scheme as predatory. While Vox Populi claims its business aligns with ICANN rules, the threat of making '.sucks' sites available to the public is seen as a coercive tactic.

A mother was arrested 27 years after her baby boy's body was found in a village pond in Norfolk, England. The case was reopened when police exhumed the body for a review, and DNA evidence led them to the mother. She explained that the baby was stillborn and she had concealed the pregnancy, placing the dead baby in the pond in 1988. Police have ruled out foul play, and the woman is on bail while authorities decide whether to charge her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial. The baby has been reburied with a headstone naming him Peter.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, has been ordered to pay compensation to Kristopher Hicks, a passenger who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping from Young's moving taxi. Young mistakenly believed Hicks was planning to "do a runner" and drove him away from his destination to teach him a lesson. Hicks objected, and Young continued driving for nearly a mile with the vehicle traveling over 20 mph, leading Hicks to jump out. The High Court ruled that Young unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to damages, though the exact amount is yet to be determined and will be reduced by 50% due to Hicks's decision to jump. Hicks sustained devastating brain injuries, developed epilepsy, and now requires round-the-clock care.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas on Wednesday night with reports of twisters near Goddard and in southwestern Kansas near Aetna. A tornado may have also touched down in Potosi, Missouri, causing wind damage, flooding, and fallen trees, while Farmington experienced baseball-sized hail. More storms are anticipated on Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold plans to be the "bull" against Lyoto Machida's "matador" style in their upcoming middleweight fight, aiming for his fourth consecutive win and a title shot. Rockhold believes he can dominate Machida by cutting him off, progressing slowly, and forcing him into unfavorable situations, highlighting his well-rounded mixed martial arts skills as an advantage. Machida, conversely, is confident that applying his style and technique can lead to a victory and a title shot, acknowledging potential weaknesses in Rockhold but preferring to assess them during the fight. Both fighters express mutual respect but are determined to win and showcase their own styles.

An Aerostar plane made a belly landing at the Aero Acres residential airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida, without deploying its landing gear, skidding along the runway on its belly with propellers hitting the tarmac. The pilot, Chris Georgaklis, 85, then re-engaged the engines and took off, flying 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale where he landed safely with his dog, Buddy. The Federal Aviation Administration is investigating the incident, which is commonly caused by human error or mechanical fault.

Manuel Pellegrini is disappointed in Yaya Toure's performances this season but will back him until the end of the season, despite Manchester City considering offers for the midfielder in the summer. Toure is determined not to be forced out, and Pellegrini acknowledged the midfielder's underperformance but dismissed claims he needs a rest. Manchester City goalkeeper Joe Hart stated that the players should take responsibility for letting the manager down. Meanwhile, Sam Allardyce has warned Aaron Cresswell against joining Manchester City, citing the experiences of Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian mafia fugitive known as the "godfather of Uxbridge," will be allowed to remain in the UK because his seven-year sentence for membership in Cosa Nostra, imposed in 1999, has expired under Italian law. Although he lost his extradition battle in February, his case expired in October, leading to the withdrawal of his European arrest warrant. His conviction remains intact, but Italian law states a sentence is extinguished after double the penalty period has passed. The Italian court of appeal agreed to extinguish his conviction due to its age, and his solicitor is confident the Italian government will withdraw the warrant, allowing him to live in peace in England. Legal experts have criticized the time and money spent on the case, suggesting Italy should have withdrawn the extradition request earlier when they realized the sentence was unenforceable. The Crown Prosecution Service admitted to an administrative error in March of the previous year by failing to serve appeal papers on time, which could have contributed to the delay.

Mr Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, is a co-favourite at 7-2 for the Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, alongside Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre. This race will be McCoy's final Grade One ride, and his full book of rides for his last day as a professional jockey will be confirmed on Friday. Mr Mole was also the horse McCoy was riding when he announced his retirement after a victory at Newbury in February. Somersby is another participant in the Celebration Chase.

Virginia Trimble Ritter, whose daughter Marcia was murdered 40 years ago, recently viewed crime scene photos of her daughter's body, a decision she now regrets, stating she wants revenge. Marcia was raped and choked to death by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975, and her body was found 33 days later. Ritter had previously declined to see the photos for decades, even after Barrett's conviction, but last year she requested to see them and viewed them on the lead investigator's laptop. Barrett, who was 15 at the time of the crime, was arrested in 2006 after DNA evidence matched him to Marcia's clothing and he was convicted of second-degree murder in 2009, receiving a 44-year sentence.

Rory McIlroy considers it "unthinkable" that he will not win the Masters at some point to complete the career grand slam, aiming to become the sixth player to achieve this feat. He views his 2011 Masters collapse as the most important day of his career, as it taught him valuable lessons that helped him win his first major title two months later. McIlroy, who tees off at the Arnold Palmer Invitational on March 19, believes winning all four majors signifies a complete player and hopes to win multiple green jackets, starting with his first. He plans to use the golf course as his "sanctuary" from the pressure and hype surrounding Augusta.

This week's trending stories include four rainbows appearing in the New York area after heavy rain, the practice of hiring exotic dancers at wakes in rural China being targeted by a crackdown on vice, actor RDJ becoming agitated during an interview about his private life, a new trend of lip plumping inspired by Kylie Jenner using the hashtag #kyliejennerchallenge, 102-year-old Alice Barker revisiting the past with filmmakers, a school rejecting a prom-posal referencing bombs leading to accusations of racism, Ewan McGregor being cast as Lumiere in "Beauty and the Beast," Johnny Depp's unrecognizable appearance in the "Black Mass" trailer, a pregnancy announcement referencing "The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air," and a military dad photobombing his son.

Alarming new figures reveal that 272 children were hospitalized in England in the past 12 months due to being born with fetal alcohol syndrome, a condition caused by prenatal alcohol exposure. Experts warn that the actual number of affected children could be much higher, with World Health Organization research suggesting that at least one in 100 babies born in the UK may suffer from learning, behavioral, and physical problems due to alcohol exposure, equating to approximately 7,500 annually. Children with fetal alcohol syndrome do not recover, and the condition is considered a vast and under-diagnosed problem. Other medical issues linked to prenatal alcohol consumption include liver, kidney, and heart problems, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy. While government advice suggests pregnant women limit consumption to two units no more than twice a week, some experts advocate for complete abstinence from alcohol during pregnancy.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31-year-old ex-juvenile offender, was jailed for six years for attempted robbery after he burst into Shildon Post Office and Stores waving an axe and demanding cash. The shopkeeper, Sab Dhillon, tackled McKerry to the ground, and his wife, Sam, hit McKerry twice with a baseball bat, disarming him. McKerry, who previously earned nicknames like "boomerang boy" for always returning home after committing crimes, had a history of offenses starting at age 12.

Four Royal Navy sailors have been charged with the gang rape of a young woman at an alcohol-fuelled party at a Canadian barracks and must remain in Nova Scotia until their trial. The men, Joshua Finbow, Craig Stoner, Simon Radford, and Darren Smalley, appeared in court in Dartmouth and were granted bail with unusual conditions, including surrendering their passports and living at the Stadacona naval base in Halifax. They will continue to work for the Royal Navy and receive their current pay. The alleged sexual assault occurred on April 10 after the sailors participated in an ice hockey tournament. They are forbidden from contacting the victim and six witnesses and must not leave Nova Scotia or resign from the navy without court permission. The charges include sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, which carry a maximum penalty of 14 years in prison.

Valerie Jackson's four-year-old son, RJ, suffers from Netherton's syndrome, a rare disease causing his skin to appear red and scaly, leading to him being mistaken for a victim of abuse. A stranger reported Jackson to the police for child abuse while they were shopping, and she has also faced taunts and denial of entry to play centers due to her son's condition. Netherton's syndrome is a rare congenital skin disease, a severe form of ichthyosis, with no cure, though symptoms often improve with time.

Campaigners are celebrating the removal of Protein World's "Are you beach body ready?" adverts from the London Underground, which featured a bikini-clad model. Transport for London (TfL) confirmed the posters were being taken down as their paid advertising period ended, though they also stated they would be guided by the Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) if similar adverts were submitted in the future. The adverts had generated over 50,000 signatures on a petition, numerous complaints to the ASA, and widespread backlash on social media, with many finding them to promote an unhealthy body image. Protein World defended the campaign, claiming the image was unphotoshopped and aimed at health-conscious individuals, while also engaging in heated exchanges on social media and reporting threats, including a bomb threat.

Rail firms are planning fare hikes of up to 87 percent shortly after the general election, despite pledges from main party leaders to freeze prices. Prime Minister David Cameron has requested First Great Western (FGW) urgently review its decision to nearly double some fares on the London to Cotswolds route, which passes through his constituency. Passengers traveling from Charlbury to London face an 87 percent increase on off-peak return tickets, rising from £33.30 to £62.40 from May 17. FGW states the change is to align the north Cotswolds route with its other services, and they are offering cheaper advance single tickets. Other significant price hikes include an off-peak first-class single from Crewe to Northampton on London Midlands rising by £7, and an anytime return between Stafford and Liverpool on Virgin increasing by 24.5 percent. Virgin claims the majority of its hikes affect cheaper "virgin trains-only fares" and that its overall fare increase on the west coast is 1.65 percent. Trainsplit.com notes that passengers may be surprised by these increases given the talk of price freezes, and that hundreds of "anytime" and "off-peak" returns already rose by 40 percent in January, with increases affecting tickets bought on the day and on rural routes.

John Young, a 66-year-old former soldier, was blinded in one eye after confronting vandals who were throwing stones at his home in Oldham. When he opened his front door to speak to the attackers, he was hit in the face with a brick, suffering a serious eye injury and a forehead wound. Despite emergency surgery, his eyesight could not be saved. The attack occurred shortly after his wedding, and he and his wife are now too scared to live in their home and are moving away. Police are investigating but currently believe there is no motive, suggesting the attackers may have been "messing around."

Derbyshire wicketkeeper Tom Poynton, aged 25, has signed a one-year contract extension until the end of the 2016 season, following his successful return from leg injuries sustained in a road accident that also resulted in the death of his father. Poynton, who underwent ankle surgery, made his comeback during Derbyshire's pre-season tour of Abu Dhabi and has shown good form in training and during the tour. Derbyshire's elite performance director, Graeme Welch, praised Poynton's character and hard work in preparing for his return, expressing the club's delight and hope that the new contract will provide him with confidence.

A five-year-old boy named Harley Renshaw, who was diagnosed with neuroblastoma, a rare and aggressive childhood cancer affecting his kidney, neck, lungs, and bones, has been given the all clear by doctors. Harley used a superhero mask, decorated like a ninja turtle, to help him feel braver during his radiotherapy treatment. His story gained international attention, leading to gifts from Nickelodeon and recognition from Cancer Research UK, where he became the face of their kids and teens campaign. Harley underwent intensive chemotherapy, surgery, a stem cell transplant, and radiotherapy. He is now cancer-free and expected to return to school full-time, though he will have regular check-ups.

Tim Sherwood advises Jack Grealish to prioritize his Aston Villa career over his international future, emphasizing that Grealish must continue to impress for the club before making a decision between the Republic of Ireland and England. Grealish's father agrees, stating that his son needs to maintain his current form for Aston Villa, and the international decision is entirely up to Jack. Grealish is expected to choose between the two countries at the end of the season, and he has played for Ireland's youth teams.

The passage discusses the high landing fees charged at airports for private jets, highlighting that these fees can offer insight into unexpectedly popular transport hubs for the wealthy. Traveling by private jet is a growing trend, with significant market worth in the US and Europe. Busiest and priciest times for private jet travel coincide with major sporting events like the Super Bowl and the Monaco Grand Prix. The passage lists several airports with high landing fees for a 767-400 aircraft, with Haneda Airport in Tokyo, Japan, being the most expensive at £4,559. Other expensive airports include Narita International Airport in Tokyo, Kansai International Airport in Osaka, Darwin International Airport in Australia, and LaGuardia Airport in New York.

Katie Gallegos took her dogs, Cooper the Labrador and Daisy, to a McDonald's drive-thru for ice cream, where Cooper ate his cone in one bite while Daisy licked hers. Gallegos, who runs a dog resort, stated that Cooper always eats quickly and she ensures Daisy gets her share first. A video of Cooper's ice cream consumption has been viewed over seven million times, with some viewers criticizing the treat while Gallegos defends it, noting Cooper's athleticism and health, and comparing his weekly ice cream to that of her previous dog who lived to 19. Daisy, being smaller, only gets a few licks. The dogs also visited Starbucks for a "pup-uccino," which is described as whipped cream in a cup, and Cooper again consumed it rapidly.

Gary Locke has been appointed Kilmarnock's permanent manager, signing a three-year deal after a successful interim spell. He joined the club as assistant boss last summer and took over as interim manager in February. Since then, the 41-year-old has lost only once in seven games.

A Florida mother, Jessica Kemp, has accused Seminole County Elementary of threatening to suspend her five-year-old autistic son, Logan, for wearing essential oils. Kemp states that teachers warned they would remove Logan from class because the Doterra products, which she applies to his head and neck to help him stay calm and focused, smell and are a distraction. She claims her son has been using them all year without issue until a teacher's aide complained. Kemp received a letter from the school board stating the oils created a "problem" for staff and students, and she questions why natural remedies are prohibited while chemicals are not. Despite the threat, Kemp intends to continue fighting the decision, asserting the oils have a positive impact on her son. However, the Lake County school district later stated they would not suspend Logan, classifying it as a "health issue." The family uses oils with scents like lavender, chamomile, and sandalwood.

A beach-side apartment complex in Westhampton, known as the Sandpiper complex, was destroyed by flames on Wednesday afternoon. The fire spread through 90 condos before the building collapsed, with smoke visible from three miles away. Twelve fire crews attempted to control the blaze, but were unable to enter the summer homes. The cause of the fire is under investigation, with claims that it may have started near a parked car. Residents, who use the complex as a holiday home between May and November, expressed their shock and distress at losing their properties.

The Queen, aged 88, was seen riding her black fell pony, Carltonlima Emma, in Windsor Great Park, accompanied by a groom. She chose not to wear a helmet, opting for a silk scarf, a preference she attributes to her hairstyle. Her lifelong passion for horses began at age four with a Shetland pony named Peggy, and she has owned many horses throughout her life, including Betsy and Surprise. Despite a knee injury that has reduced her riding time and prevented her from riding in the Trooping the Colour, she remains an enthusiastic equestrienne and breeds horses, including fell and highland ponies, some of which are now ridden by her grandchildren. Fell ponies, an ancient breed from Cumbria, are known for their docile and hardy nature, and have been used for various purposes throughout history, becoming popular as riding horses in the 1950s.

An argument over noise levels between two Brisbane neighbours resulted in the death of 55-year-old Leon Yeaman, who was allegedly killed by a single punch to the head from 28-year-old Phillip Pama. The incident occurred on Muller Road when Yeaman was reportedly making a lot of noise. Pama, a shift worker who was sleeping at the time, confronted Yeaman, and during the altercation, Pama allegedly hit Yeaman while being pushed. Yeaman was pronounced dead at the scene. Pama was granted conditional bail, ordered to surrender his passport, adhere to a curfew, and report to the police twice a week. The case is scheduled to return to court on May 18.

Yulia Simonova, a 52-year-old music teacher, was arrested in Shatura, Russia, after a hidden camera filmed her attempting to hire a hitman to torture and murder her 15-year-old former pupil, Damian Vanya, for 100,000 rubles. Simonova, who had showered Vanya with gifts for a year, expressed a desire for him to suffer severe pain, including broken limbs and kidney damage, before being killed. She was apprehended by undercover police after handing over expense money and now faces 15 years in prison for attempted murder. Vanya, who ended the relationship for a classmate, expressed relief and hoped Simonova would be imprisoned indefinitely.

Chelsea football manager Jose Mourinho, a 52-year-old father-of-two, revealed he talks to God daily about his personal life but never about football, and he also never discusses the game with his wife. He believes he is a good person, a good family man, and a good friend, and tries to support strangers. Mourinho, who has worked with the World Food Programme as an ambassador against hunger, separates his professional and family life, and while he admits to making mistakes in his competitive professional area, he believes a person is more than their profession. He was fined £25,000 earlier this season for claiming there was a "campaign" against Chelsea.

Bob Barker, a TV legend who hosted "The Price Is Right" for 35 years, returned to the show on April 1st for the first time in eight years. At 91 years old, Barker hosted the first price-guessing game, "lucky seven," before handing over hosting duties to Drew Carey. Barker appeared to be in good form and did not seem to miss a beat despite his absence from the show for most of the past eight years.

An off-duty Secret Service agent, Arthur Baldwin, was arrested in Washington D.C. early Friday morning and charged with attempted burglary and destruction of property after allegedly trying to break into a house. Baldwin, who is posted with the Foreign Missions Branch, had his security clearance revoked and was placed on leave by the agency. This arrest follows an earlier incident where a high-ranking supervisor was put on leave due to alleged misconduct, and both events are seen as further negative publicity for the agency. The Homeland Security Department's inspector general is investigating the supervisor's allegations and a separate March 4 incident involving two officials accused of driving into a secure White House area after drinking.

Freelance photographer Atif Saeed, 38, from Lahore, Pakistan, risked his life at a safari park by getting out of his car and creeping within ten feet of a hungry male lion, armed only with a camera, to capture its character and status. The clicking of his camera alerted the lion, which aggressively jumped towards Saeed, forcing him to retreat rapidly into his car. Saeed described it as a close encounter, stating he wouldn't attempt it again.

The New York City Police Department has released an image of a tattoo on the right leg of an unidentified woman, believed to be between 25 and 45 years old, who was found dead on March 22nd in Brooklyn. The tattoo, described as a heart with the name "Monique" etched across a ribbon and topped with a rose, is being used in hopes of identifying her. The cause of her death is still pending a medical examiner's report.

A New Zealand couple, Hannah and Alex, built a solar-powered, two-bedroom home on the back of a 1986 Hino flatbed truck after returning from the UK in 2009 and being unable to afford property. The year-and-a-half project resulted in a wood and steel home in Nelson, New Zealand, allowing them to live almost self-sufficiently with gas-powered stove and hot water, and water from a nearby spring. The project cost approximately $25,000.

Researchers claim that children who share iPads in class perform significantly better on early literacy tests, scoring approximately 30 points higher than those who use iPads individually or do not use them at all. This finding emerged from a study involving 352 kindergarten students, suggesting that the collaborative learning experience around the technology, rather than the technology itself, is the key factor. The research indicates that schools might benefit from reconsidering how tablets are implemented, particularly in earlier grades, to maximize their effectiveness.

A piglet born without hind legs has become an internet sensation after learning to walk on its front trotters, mastering balance despite appearing close to tipping over. The piglet, nicknamed 'super pig', happily mixes with its siblings and has drawn villagers and online viewers alike. This phenomenon is not unique in China, as a rabbit at Liuzhou zoo also gained fame for walking on its front paws.

During the IndyCar Grand Prix of Louisiana, pit crew member Todd Phillips, a front-outside tire changer for Dale Coyne Racing, was injured when Francesco Dracone's car spun while exiting the pit box on lap 25, clipping Phillips' leg. Phillips received stitches for a cut on his leg at the infield care center and was released. Dracone did not finish the race, ending in 23rd place. The race was affected by rain, causing many cars to struggle with traction.

Milton Vieira Severiano, 32, brutally murdered his dancer wife, Cicera Alves de Sena, 29, by smashing her head into concrete 11 times and shooting her five times in the face. Severiano confessed to the crime, stating his jealousy of other men looking at her as the motive. The attack occurred shortly after their marriage, with neighbors hearing a violent argument where Severiano accused his wife of being a "slut" and a "whore." Severiano was apprehended by police after crashing a stolen car during his escape, and he now faces a life sentence.

Sarah Wilson, author of "I Quit Sugar," revealed her personal struggle with mental illness, including anxiety and depression, which led her to a point where she considered ending her life. She attributed these feelings to a combination of stress, anxiety, thyroid disease, and distant family, making her feel isolated and unable to see a way out. Wilson believes depression and anxiety are linked and that acknowledging this connection is crucial for addressing the rising rates of stress and anxiety among Australian women, noting that anxiety is becoming the "new depression."

Elena Curtin of Portland, Oregon, was charged with second-degree assault after beating her boyfriend's ex-girlfriend with a crowbar in November 2014, but prosecutors dropped the charge because she was justified in her outrage. Curtin, seven months pregnant at the time, found the ex-girlfriend using heroin in her bathroom and struck her with a crowbar when she refused to leave, an action permitted under Oregon law for intruders who won't leave a resident's home. Curtin's defense attorney stated the ex-girlfriend was jealous and had harassed Curtin for two years. Curtin gave birth in January and is now living with her parents.

Gemma, a pit bull in California, was filmed reacting with disgust and spitting out a piece of broccoli offered by her owner among treats. The passage also mentions that Gemma enjoys sleeping and spending time with her human family.

HSBC has apologized after a link on its official website directed visitors to a pornographic page. The link, which was for the young entrepreneur awards, was shut down after it was discovered that the address had been taken over by a porn site after the awards were scrapped in 2011 and the organizers allowed its registration on hsbc.com.hk to retire. HSBC removed the hyperlink from its main website and stated that it is not associated with the external third-party website.

A 13-year-old Maryland boy named Marcus called 911 after a fire broke out in his Clinton home on Sunday morning, providing instructions to firefighters that helped him and his nine-year-old sister, Aaliyah, escape from a second-floor bedroom. Marcus remained calm during the 11-minute call, reassuring Aaliyah and guiding rescuers to their location. Firefighters entered the room by breaking a window, with one firefighter handing Marcus out and then giving his gas mask to Aaliyah. Both siblings were taken to the hospital with non-life-threatening injuries, while the other three family members escaped on their own.

Blue fluorescent algae, caused by millions of plankton emitting light as a defense mechanism, have been observed lighting up Australia's east coast, specifically in Jervis Bay, South Coast of NSW. Photographer Andy Hutchinson described the phenomenon as a "beautiful supernatural scene." A similar display occurred at Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014. Iain Suthers from the University of New South Wales explained that the glow is from *noctiluca scintillans*, a single-celled phytoplankton that blooms in spring and autumn, usually due to natural causes. This carnivorous cell preys on diatoms and emits light as a defense.

New tests that identify genetic markers in breast tumors can determine their aggressiveness, potentially sparing patients from chemotherapy. After surgery, cancer cells are screened to assess the risk of recurrence. For some women, these tests can indicate a low risk, as low as five percent, which is comparable to or better than the outcomes of chemotherapy. While chemotherapy is routinely given to prevent recurrence, it has severe side effects. The endopredict test, for example, allows patients with a low score to opt out of chemotherapy. Although currently available privately for around £2,500, there is hope for NHS availability, with experts suggesting cost savings from avoiding chemotherapy could balance the test's price. This allows patients to make informed decisions, unlike in the past when chemotherapy was almost universally administered. Becca Cornford, a patient who underwent this testing, had a low endopredict score indicating a five percent chance of recurrence within ten years, leading her to forgo chemotherapy.

More than 25 women have been airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy, with HMS Ocean having five such emergency evacuations in the last nine years. HMS Illustrious also had at least one woman airlifted. Eighteen other ships, including HMS Dragon, HMS Enterprise, and HMS Richmond, experienced emergency evacuations. A Ministry of Defence spokesman stated there is a strict "no touching" rule at sea, suggesting pregnancies occurred before boarding or during leave. This data emerges after Commander Sarah West, the first woman to captain a Royal Navy warship, was flown back to the UK following claims of a sexual relationship with a crew member. Women have served on Royal Navy ships since 1990, and in 2014, approximately 9% of personnel were female. In Afghanistan, nearly 100 female British soldiers were sent home due to pregnancy between January 2006 and December 2013, with 16 removed in 2013 and 18 in 2011. Additionally, 102 women were evacuated from Iraq. Military rules prohibit expectant mothers from serving in war zones, and while troops are reminded to check for pregnancy before deployment, pregnancy tests are not mandatory.

A drone carrying traces of radioactive material, believed to be cesium, was discovered on the rooftop of Japan's prime minister's residence, raising concerns about potential terrorism involving drones, particularly in light of upcoming events like the Olympics and G7 summit. The drone, equipped with a camera and smoke flares, was found by a staff member and is being investigated by police. This discovery occurs as Japan plans to restart nuclear reactors, a move that is unpopular due to safety concerns following the Fukushima disaster. Current Japanese law has limited restrictions on drone flights in Tokyo, including around government buildings.

A security guard from China, Lu Xincai, takes his 84-year-old mother, who suffers from Alzheimer's, to work with him every day on the back of his motorbike. He does this because he fears she will get lost if left alone, as she has a history of wandering off. Lu Xincai ties a sash around both of them for safety during the hour-long, four-kilometer journey to his workplace, a bank, where his mother has been given her own room. He feels a duty to care for her in return for her past devotion to him.

A major study published in the American Journal of Public Health indicates that heavy drinking and binge drinking have increased among Americans between 2005 and 2012, with a significant rise in women's drinking habits attributed to changing social norms. The study, which tracked adult drinking patterns at the county level, found that in 2012, 8% of Americans were heavy drinkers and 18% were binge drinkers. Factors contributing to this increase include cultural and economic explanations such as more acceptable drinking norms for women, increased alcohol advertising, and weakened alcohol control policies. The study also noted that the cost of alcohol has decreased in real dollars over time.

UN officials warn that doctors are performing caesarean sections too readily, putting the health of women and their babies at risk, as the procedure should only be carried out when medically necessary due to potential complications like infections and death. In England, over a quarter of births are now caesareans, more than double the rate since the early 1990s, with a rise in planned caesareans due to maternal anxiety. The World Health Organization suggests the ideal rate should be between 10% and 15% due to the dangers and costs, contradicting current NHS guidelines that allow for caesareans even without medical justification, such as for women with tokophobia or those over 40.

Michelle Filkins, 44, of West Wareham, was arrested on April 17 for allegedly breaking into a home on Martha's Vineyard, living there for at least a week, and selling the owners' belongings in a yard sale. She was discovered by the owner, Mark Conklin, in his summer home, where she claimed ownership. Filkins fled when Conklin called the police, who found a broken window at the property. She was arrested later that day when she attempted to re-enter the home. Filkins is charged with breaking and entering, larceny over $250, and malicious destruction of property, and her next court date is May 14. Police are asking anyone who received items from the home to return them and are seeking information from the public.

A lost iPhone belonging to Bella Crooke from Melbourne was reunited with her after police in Albury posted humorous selfies and photos of the phone on her Facebook page. The unlocked phone was handed in to the police station on Sunday morning, and officers used it to post updates, including a picture of the phone in a holding cell and puns about it being "charged" and a "cell" phone. Bella, who lost her phone at a party the night before, was amused by the posts when she collected it, and the police's unconventional approach was praised by her friends. Bella has since secured her phone with a password.

A five-day-old baby hippopotamus was killed after being caught in a fight between two adult male hippos in the iSimangaliso Wetland Park in eastern South Africa. The calf was thrown into the air and dragged along the water's surface by one of the fighting adults, with its mother watching in horror. The calf died hours later from its injuries.

A three-bedroom apartment in Knightsbridge, London, is on the market for £575,000, significantly less than neighboring properties, but it has only three years left on its lease and requires modernization. The cost equates to £191,000 per year or £15,000 per month, similar to renting in the area. If the lease is extended, the property could be worth upwards of £6 million. The maisonette, located in Egerton Place, offers 1,990 sq/ft of space with three bedrooms, two bathrooms, a reception room, utility room, lift, parking, and a communal garden. It is being sold by Russell Simpson, with another similar property on Egerton Place on the market for £595,000. Negotiating a lease extension with the current freeholder, likely the Welcome Trust, for a 90-year lease is estimated to cost between £3.35 and £4.5 million. Experts warn that while the price appears cheap, there's a significant premium for lease extension, and potential buyers should carefully check lease terms.

A computer outage affecting registers at 8,000 Starbucks stores in the US and Canada, which began Friday evening, has been resolved. The glitch, caused by a failure during a daily system refresh, prompted baristas to give away free drinks and baked goods, and some stores closed early. The outage also impacted Evolution Fresh and Teavana stores. This incident occurred shortly after Starbucks reported record quarterly earnings.

Terrorist training is occurring in rural areas of West Wales, specifically in Ceredigion, Powys, and Pembrokeshire, where Muslims are being radicalized. Detective Constable Gareth Jones of the Wales Extremism and Counter Terrorism Unit stated that individuals involved engage in ordinary community activities with an ulterior motive. Incidents of Islamic extremist activity in Wales date back to 1998, with claims of hate preacher Abu Hamza sending extremists to train in the Brecon Beacons. Notable events include two of the 7/7 bombers being photographed white water rafting in Bala in 2005, and the arrest of three Cardiff-based individuals in 2010 as part of an al-Qaeda inspired plot. Michael Adebowale, convicted of murdering Fusilier Lee Rigby, is understood to have studied Arabic at the former European Institute of Human Sciences near Llanybydder. Community intelligence is considered vital by authorities in addressing these issues.

An Omura's whale, a species previously feared extinct, was found washed up on a remote West Australian beach after a cyclone. This is the first sighting of the species in Western Australia and only the second in Australia. Scientists identified the 5.68m juvenile female using DNA profiling. The find is significant as little is known about Omura's whales, which were first described in 2003 and are typically found in tropical and subtropical waters like Indonesian waters, the Philippines, and the Sea of Japan. The whale has a sleek body shape and unique skeletal features, including 53 vertebrae. The carcass has been buried, and the skeleton will be recovered for further study and potential museum display.

The passage discusses the notion that hormones are a factor in presidential candidacy, citing a businesswoman who believes Hillary Clinton's hormones would make her irrational and prone to starting unnecessary wars. The author counters this by suggesting male hormones have historically impaired male leaders' decision-making and that studies show women leaders take fewer risks. The core issue highlighted is the pervasive gender bias against women in the workplace and politics, which makes a female candidate's path to leadership more challenging, regardless of their qualifications. The passage argues that gender equality benefits society, the economy, and families, and that it's crucial to acknowledge and combat this bias.

Veteran actor Robert Hardy is selling his extensive antique collection, comprising over 200 items, in a £100,000 auction due to downsizing his home. The collection, reflecting his passion for military history and classic literature, includes a hand-painted diorama of the Battle of Agincourt, a yew longbow, and a portrait of himself with the bow, alongside paintings, furniture, weapons, and books. Hardy, known for his roles in "All Creatures Great and Small" and portraying Winston Churchill, studied English with J.R.R. Tolkien and is an expert on the medieval longbow. The auction, featuring 238 lots, is being held by Dominic Winter Auctioneers in Gloucestershire.

Michael Scott Shemansky is a suspect in the murder of his mother, Sandra Shemansky, who was found dead at their shared home in Winter Garden. Shemansky failed to appear for a supervised visit with his son on the same day his mother was discovered. He has a history of mental illness, including bipolar disorder and an attempted suicide, and is on parole for battery on law enforcement. Neighbors suggest that divorce proceedings and his mother's potential interference with his visit with his son may have contributed to the situation. Authorities have the murder weapon but have not released details on the cause of death. Shemansky was last seen fleeing on foot without provisions or medication, and his estranged wife is preparing to protect herself.

The city of Eugene, United States, has been awarded the rights to host the 2021 IAAF World Championships. The International Association of Athletics Federations (IAAF) council made this decision, bypassing the usual bidding process due to a unique strategic opportunity to host the event in the USA for the first time. Eugene had previously failed in its bid for the 2019 event, which was awarded to Doha. The IAAF president stated that this decision was a strategic choice to access a key market and promote the global development of the sport, noting that the 2007 World Championships in Osaka were also awarded without a bidding process.

Leonie Granger, a 25-year-old aspiring model, has been jailed for 16 years for manslaughter after orchestrating a honey trap to lure professional gambler Mehmet Hassan to his death. Granger befriended Hassan, a 56-year-old playboy, after spotting him at a London casino. She then left his flat unlocked, allowing her boyfriend, Kyrron Jackson, and an accomplice, Nicholas Chandler, to enter and fatally kick Hassan while ransacking his home for winnings. Jackson and Chandler were found guilty of murder and sentenced to life with a minimum of 36 years. The judge described the attack as "pitiless and wicked."

Cesc Fabregas, a Chelsea midfielder, is experiencing a decline in form in the latter half of the season, a trend previously noted by his former club Barcelona. Despite a strong start to the season where he was on track to break the Premier League assist record, his contributions have diminished, with only one assist in his last five games and four in fifteen appearances for club and country in 2015. This slump has impacted his performance in international matches, as seen in Spain's 2-0 defeat to Holland, where he captained the team but struggled to make an impact. While Chelsea has already secured a Capital One Cup win and is likely to win the Premier League title, questions remain about Fabregas' durability and his ability to maintain his performance throughout an intense campaign. Manager Jose Mourinho will be looking for a resurgence from his deep-lying playmaker in the remaining games to help secure the title.

West Ham are in discussions to sign Jamaican forward Deshane Beckford, a 17-year-old from Montego Bay United, after he impressed during a two-week trial with their academy. Beckford, considered a top prospect from the Caribbean, also has offers from Belgian clubs. Separately, West Ham has announced that season tickets at the Olympic Stadium for the 2016-17 season will start at £289, making them the cheapest in the Barclays Premier League as they aim to fill the 54,000-capacity venue.

Wiltshire police have dropped an investigation into an assault on huntsman Mike Lane, who was beaten by protesters armed with iron bars on ropes. Lane, who suffered concussion and broken teeth, provided police with video evidence and a dossier of information, including names and car registration numbers of suspected attackers. Despite this, police stated they were unable to move the inquiry further forward due to insufficient evidence, a decision that has been condemned by Lane and other hunt supporters. The Countryside Alliance is campaigning to ban saboteurs from wearing face coverings to aid in bringing criminals to justice.

Adam Gadahn, also known as Azzam the American, a 36-year-old American citizen and prominent al-Qaeda propagandist, was killed in a U.S. government counterterrorism operation in January. Gadahn, born in 1978, converted to Islam in 1995 and left for Pakistan three years later, eventually becoming al-Qaeda's chief English-language propagandist. He appeared in numerous videos threatening attacks and urging Muslims to target American, Western, and Jewish interests. He was indicted in 2006 for treason and material support to al-Qaeda and was among the FBI's "most wanted terrorists." In separate videos, he criticized U.S. presidents, addressed his Jewish ancestry, and encouraged lone-wolf attacks in the United States. His final video in September 2014 called for the overthrow of governments in Saudi Arabia and Pakistan. Warren Weinstein, a U.S. citizen abducted by al-Qaeda in 2011, died along with another hostage in an operation that also killed Ahmed Farouq, another U.S. citizen and al-Qaeda operative.

A five-year-old boy named Mai Zizhuo is gaining attention in China for his exceptional basketball skills, as shown in a viral video where he demonstrates impressive dribbling and shooting abilities, even handling two basketballs simultaneously. His talent has garnered him many fans and admiration from netizens, with some expressing disbelief and others feeling self-conscious about their own skills in comparison.

Tom O'Carroll, a leading member of the Paedophile Information Exchange (PIE), which campaigned to legalize child sex in the 1970s and 80s, has joined the supporters of the media pressure group Hacked Off. O'Carroll, a former Open University information officer and PIE activist, attended a Hacked Off rally in the Houses of Parliament on February 25 to lobby MPs for state involvement in media regulation. Hacked Off, established after the phone-hacking scandal, opposes the Independent Press Standards Organisation and advocates for a statutory body to regulate the press, as suggested by the Leveson inquiry. O'Carroll's support for Hacked Off is considered an embarrassment to the group. PIE was founded in 1974 to advocate for the legalization of sex with children and allied with the National Council for Civil Liberties (NCCL), which lobbied for a reduced age of sexual consent and the legalization of incest. O'Carroll was part of the NCCL's gay rights sub-committee and was jailed in 1981 for "corrupting public morals." He confirmed his attendance at the rally, which was chaired by John Cleese, in a blog post. A Hacked Off spokesperson stated the meeting was open to all members of the public.

Bondi's Icebergs Club pool was drained on Thursday to serve as a unique catwalk for the ten pieces presentation during Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week Australia. The fashion label, headed by Maurice Terzini and Lucy Hinckfuss, showcased a capsule collection of ten monochrome, unisex clothing pieces designed to be worn in 20 different ways, suitable for day to night wear. Models paraded through the empty pool and along the break wall against the backdrop of the ocean, with guests enjoying refreshments and the unseasonably warm weather.

Bolton-born boxer Amir Khan, accompanied by his wife Faryal Makhdoom Khan and daughter Lamysa, visited a safari park in northern California. During the trip, Khan interacted with a white tiger, giraffes, and sea lions. Earlier in the week, Khan announced his upcoming fight against former light-welterweight world champion Chris Algieri on May 30, ending speculation about his next opponent, which had included British rival Kell Brook.

Mohammed Abu Khdeir's name will be removed from an Israeli memorial wall after his family and the organization Almagor complained about his inclusion. Abu Khdeir, a 16-year-old Palestinian, was beaten and burned alive by three Israelis in July. His father objected to his son's name being listed among soldiers of the occupation, and Almagor stated that Abu Khdeir was not a terror victim but was murdered in a brutal individual action. The National Insurance Institute of Israel will remove his name from the memorial site.

A California-based YouTube user, Lionel Hutz, filmed his young son attempting to use the family cat's belly as a pillow in the garden. The boy repeatedly tried to rest on the cat, but the feline would move to a new spot each time. Eventually, the cat wandered off indoors, seemingly tired of the situation. A later video showed the boy and cat making up, with the boy feeding the cat treats.

In a Philadelphia police corruption trial, witness Robert Kushner lost his coaching job at Jack M. Barrack Hebrew Academy after testifying about his past marijuana sales and alleging that undercover officers stole $81,000 and 7 pounds of marijuana from him during a 2007 arrest. Kushner's history, including a 2011 arrest and a 2008 DUI, was unknown to the school when he was hired in 2010, though his 2007 charges were expunged. He expressed remorse and a desire for the best for the children, and he is also described as an excellent coach in a summer league. The defense in the trial, which involves six former drug squad officers accused of racketeering, claims the government's case relies on unreliable witnesses.

An explosion at a controversial chemical plant in Zhangzhou city, Fujian province, China, which produces paraxylene (px), injured six people and sparked a large fire. The blast occurred at an oil storage facility after an oil leak, and while five people were injured by broken glass, no toxic chemical spill has been reported. Over 600 firefighters brought the blaze under control, and residents near the plant reported hearing the explosion and feeling tremors. This plant was previously slated for Xiamen but was relocated due to pollution concerns and public protests in 2007, and it experienced another explosion in July 2013.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager and Ireland under-21 international, intends to continue wearing his socks low, just above his shinpads, due to superstition, despite referees' requests to pull them up. He uses children's size shinpads and has not yet sustained a shin injury. Grealish recently made his first Premier League start for Villa in a 3-3 draw against QPR, a game he found tough but was pleased to have started, hoping for more opportunities.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has global and irreversible brain damage and remains unresponsive, according to her grandmother, Cissy Houston. Despite her father, Bobby Brown, stating she is awake and watching him, a source with knowledge of her condition confirmed she has not improved neurologically for nearly three months and has a tracheostomy. An attorney for the family stated that while doctors indicate she will have a long life, the quality of that life is unknown as she embarks on a rehabilitation process.

Russia is on the verge of reaching the Fed Cup final with a 2-0 lead against Germany, following Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova's victory over Sabine Lisicki. Pavlyuchenkova saved a match point in her 4-6, 7-6 (4), 6-3 win, after Svetlana Kuznetsova had defeated Julia Goerges in straight sets. Pavlyuchenkova noted Lisicki's power, while Lisicki attributed her loss to a poor tiebreaker and Pavlyuchenkova playing a good point on her match point. Despite Pavlyuchenkova's 13 double faults, Lisicki's 63 unforced errors were decisive. Russia now needs one more win from Sunday's matches to secure a place in the final and potentially win their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales are being warned of more floods and damage as another storm is predicted to hit later this week, potentially bringing heavy rain from Thursday through Saturday. Meteorologists indicate an east coast low, similar to the system that caused damage last week, could impact the region, with the heaviest rain likely in the far northern parts of the state and coastal areas in the northeast. The State Emergency Service (SES) is concerned that further storms will hinder ongoing clean-up efforts, as over 4,000 jobs from the previous event are still to be completed. The SES is particularly worried about the Hunter region, which was severely affected by the last storm, and is urging the community to prepare for potential further devastation.

Nina Moric, a model who appeared in Ricky Martin's "La Vida Loca" video, has denied reports that she attempted suicide, stating she collapsed due to low blood pressure after a domestic accident. She posted photos of bruising on her arms on Instagram to show her injuries and reassured fans she was recovering at home. Italian media had reported that she tried to take her own life and was found by her mother, with her boyfriend Luigi Mario Favoloso initially confirming the suicide attempt but suggesting she was a victim of others. Moric clarified that her boyfriend was in Naples at the time of the incident and that the newspaper reports were not entirely correct. Italian media also claimed she had attempted suicide in 2009 due to an overdose. Moric was previously married to paparazzi Fabrizio Corona, with whom she has a son, Carlos Maria. Corona was jailed for blackmailing celebrities with compromising photographs.

A YouGov poll for the Sunday Times revealed that Diana is the favorite name for a potential royal baby girl, with 12% of respondents favoring it in honor of William's mother, Princess Diana. Alice and Charlotte were the next most popular choices for a girl, each receiving 9% of the vote. For a boy, James was the preferred name with 13% of the vote, followed by Alexander. The poll also indicated that a quarter of the 2,200 people surveyed hoped for a baby girl, and 68% supported William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber detonated explosives near protesters in eastern Afghanistan on Thursday, killing 17 people and wounding dozens more, including an Afghan lawmaker. The attack occurred in the city of Khost as protesters were heading to a larger rally. The Taliban has denied responsibility, and no other group has claimed the attack.

Dani Alves is set to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. His representative, Dinorah Santana, confirmed that the Brazilian right-back rejected a three-year extension contingent on playing 60% of matches. Alves has spent seven successful years at Barcelona, winning four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice.

Pablo Osvaldo, currently on loan at Boca Juniors from Southampton and having scored three goals in six games, has encouraged Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at the Argentinian club. Osvaldo believes Pirlo and Totti possess a South American style and would be a perfect fit for Boca, with their abilities likely to be adored by the fans at La Bombonera.

Amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson, an 18-year-old, experienced a spectacular double somersault fall from his horse Merrion Square at Wincanton, which has gained significant online attention. Despite the fall, Ferguson sustained only a cut on his nose and was back riding out, undeterred. He described the event as a blur and expressed gratitude for his luck, noting that other jockeys watched the replay with horror. Ferguson has also gained social media followers and humorously suggested a gymnastics career after racing.

James Haskell, captain of the London Wasps and England flanker, posted a photo on Instagram dressed as Iron Man to celebrate the release of the Avengers: Age of Ultron movie. Haskell, who has played for clubs in France, Japan, and New Zealand, returned to the London Wasps in 2012 and has since surpassed 100 appearances for the club and earned 57 caps for England.

The wide-leg trouser is a prominent trend for SS15, offering an effortless alternative to skinny jeans, which have dominated for years. This style, which has seen comebacks since the seventies, can be intimidating, but the key to wearing it successfully lies in the shoes, with high heels recommended to elongate the leg. Proportion is also crucial; pairing wide-leg trousers with a simple knit, shirt, or tee can keep the look current. Denim is considered the easiest way to embrace the trend, with brands like Gucci and Topshop offering versions. For dressier occasions, Celine and Stella McCartney showcased elegant wide-leg pants, with Finery London offering a more affordable alternative. The wide-leg trouser is a versatile trend that can update a wardrobe regardless of the weather.

The University of Michigan will screen "American Sniper" as part of its UMich social events series, reversing an earlier decision to cancel the showing due to student objections. Over 200 students had signed a petition against the film, citing concerns about its depiction of the Iraq War and its negative reflection on the Middle East and its people, particularly given the large Arab-American population in Michigan's Detroit metropolitan area. However, a counter-petition led to a reconsideration, with Vice President for Student Life E. Royster Harper stating that the initial cancellation was a mistake and inconsistent with the university's commitment to freedom of expression. For those who prefer not to watch "American Sniper," a screening of "Paddington" will also be offered.

Two French tourists, aged 18 and 24, allegedly set a quokka alight on Rottnest Island off Perth, Western Australia, on April 3 by igniting an aerosol spray with a lighter. The quokka, described as the size of a domestic cat, survived the incident but was singed. Detectives questioned the men, seized video evidence, and evicted them from the island. Both have been charged with animal cruelty and are due to appear in Fremantle Magistrates Court on April 17.

102-year-old Alice Barker, a former dancer who performed in New York nightspots like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar in the 1930s and 1940s alongside figures such as Bill "Bojangles" Robinson and Frank Sinatra, was shown a video compilation of "soundies" (early music videos) created by Mark Cantor of jazz-on-film.com and volunteers. Barker had never seen any motion pictures of herself dancing, and her photographs and memorabilia had been lost over time, making this viewing a significant event for her, which she described as "fabulous."

New figures indicate that washing one's own car is becoming less common in Britain, with a third of men admitting they've never done it and three-quarters of women never washing their cars, preferring to use car washes instead. Factors contributing to this decline include changing Sunday routines, the availability of hand car washes, and the increasing size of vehicles. Despite this trend, car washing by owners is more likely during holidays, and certain cities and car brands see more owner-initiated washes.

Martin Skrtel has praised Steven Gerrard's impact on him since his arrival at Anfield in 2008, highlighting Gerrard's helpfulness in his settling-in period. Skrtel considers Gerrard, who is set to leave Liverpool for LA Galaxy after the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, to still be one of the best players in the world and synonymous with the club. Despite acknowledging that Liverpool will be different without Gerrard, Skrtel believes the team has players who can replace him, provided they receive the necessary support. Both Gerrard and Skrtel are eligible to play against Aston Villa after serving three-match bans.

Jack Nicklaus, at 75, achieved a hole-in-one on the fourth hole during the par-3 contest at Augusta National, a shot that spun back into the 130-yard hole. He was playing with Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. This was Nicklaus's first ace at Augusta, though his achievement was overshadowed by Camilo Villegas, who also had two holes-in-one that day. Villegas ultimately lost the contest to Kevin Streelman. The passage also mentions Nicklaus's history with the Masters, including becoming the youngest to wear a green jacket in 1963 and winning his sixth in 1986, and his status as one of five men to complete the career grand slam.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas on Wednesday night due to several storms, with a tornado reported northwest of Goddard and other sightings in southwestern Kansas near Aetna. Missouri also experienced storms, with a possible tornado touchdown in Potosi, leading to reports of wind damage, flooding, fallen trees, roof damage, and hail the size of baseballs in Farmington. More storms are anticipated on Thursday across the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Robert Bates, a reserve sheriff's deputy in Oklahoma, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter for fatally shooting Eric Harris, whom he claims he intended to subdue with a taser. Bates was granted permission to vacation in the Bahamas, a decision that drew criticism from Harris's family, who perceive it as a message of apathy. Bates' preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2. Bates, 73, claims the shooting was accidental, stating he mistakenly used his gun instead of a taser during Harris's arrest in a weapons sting operation. He and Sheriff Stanley Glanz have apologized to the Harris family. The family's lawyer alleges Bates received preferential treatment due to donations and his friendship with the sheriff, and that supervisors were asked to forge Bates' records. The Tulsa County Sheriff's Office denies these allegations, and one of Bates' lawyers released training documents to support his qualifications. Two deputies involved in Harris's arrest have been reassigned due to threats.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title fight against Jose Aldo on July 11 in Las Vegas, where Aldo will make his eighth defense of the belt. McGregor, who previously got a gorilla tattoo on his chest, has revealed a new tiger tattoo on his stomach, stating, "if you see the tiger, it's too late. You're food." McGregor believes he has greater motivation to win the title than Aldo has to defend it, citing Aldo's apparent desire to avoid him and the belt. Their relationship is described as fractious, highlighted by an incident in Dublin where McGregor took Aldo's belt during a promotional tour.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott has drawn criticism from anti-drinking campaigners for skolling a beer at an Australian rules function, with critics claiming he is glorifying binge drinking and associating masculinity with alcohol consumption. Cultural studies professor Julie Robert stated that it is problematic for the Prime Minister to showcase his masculinity by skolling a beer, suggesting it promotes a culture where drinking is about quantity and speed rather than socializing. While some, like Health Minister Sussan Ley, defended Abbott's actions, others, including opposition leader Bill Shorten, made light of the incident. Critics argue that Abbott should set an example against irresponsible drinking and the stereotype that heavy drinking makes one a "true blue Aussie bloke," especially given the current climate of concern over binge drinking.

Indiana is experiencing a significant increase in HIV cases, with 120 confirmed and 10 preliminary positive cases linked to Scott County, a rise from 106 the previous week. This outbreak, primarily among intravenous drug users of the painkiller Opana, has led to an epidemic declaration and a temporary 30-day needle exchange program approved by Governor Mike Pence. The program, which has provided 5,322 clean syringes to 86 participants, is under review for potential extension beyond April 25th, with a decision expected early next week. While the emergency exchange for Scott County is seen as a necessary reaction, there is uncertainty about extending such programs to other counties, particularly given Governor Pence's opposition to needle exchanges as an anti-drug policy and concerns about promoting drug use. Legislation allowing needle-exchange programs in 23 Indiana counties with high Hepatitis C rates, a key indicator of potential HIV outbreaks, is also being considered, though federal funding for such programs has been banned since 1989.

An obsessive Arsenal fan made his girlfriend, Saskia, take a test about his favorite football club, which she passed with a score of 43.5 out of 50, or 87 percent. The test included multiple-choice questions, tables, and essay sections, with instructions like "read every question at least twice" and "calculators may be used." Saskia struggled with player positions and identifying the starting 11, but received praise for creative answers, including a humorous explanation of why Alexis Sanchez is better than Eden Hazard. Her boyfriend, impressed with her performance, decided not to break up with her, and the incident garnered attention on Twitter, with some hailing the boyfriend as a "legend" and Saskia as "proper gf material," while others felt the boyfriend had gone too far.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former informant for the DEA who worked undercover for 27 years after fleeing Colombia due to threats from his former Medellin Cartel bosses, is facing deportation from the United States. Toro provided crucial information that aided in the prosecution of figures like Carlos Lehder and Manuel Noriega, but despite being promised US citizenship in exchange for his service, he has not received it. His retirement due to declining health has left him in legal limbo, with his temporary visa expired, and he fears for his life if deported back to Colombia. A former DEA handler believes Toro deserves to live in the US after his service, and a former colleague provided him with funds for an operation when the DEA declined to help.

A 14-year-old girl in India set herself on fire with kerosene after allegedly being gang-raped by five men from her village, resulting in 70% burns and her current fight for life in a Delhi hospital. Her family reportedly advised her to remain silent about the attack. The accused men have been arrested. This incident occurs amidst heightened sensitivity in India regarding sexual assault, following the ban of a documentary about the gang rape and murder of Jyoti Singh, which sparked protests and discussions about women's safety and vigilante justice.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal is dreaming of beating rivals City in the derby at Old Trafford, but will be without Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw, who are not considered fit enough to play. Van Gaal wants his team to secure a victory to improve their league position, potentially reaching second or third place and avoiding Champions League qualifying fixtures. He acknowledged City will be a tough opponent and reflected on learning from their previous loss to them, emphasizing the need to control aggression. Van Gaal also expressed his admiration for the Manchester United fans' support and is looking forward to experiencing the derby atmosphere at Old Trafford with home advantage.

Arsenal and Liverpool fans protested against ticket prices at the Emirates Stadium by leaving seats empty for the first 10 minutes of their match. Supporters from both clubs expressed disgust at the rising cost of tickets, with the cheapest seats priced at £64. This protest occurred after the announcement of the Premier League's £5.14 billion TV rights deal, and banners displayed inside and outside the stadium highlighted the disparity between the revenue and ticket prices. Fan groups organized the event, calling the prices "extortionate" and emphasizing that football is losing its soul and neglecting match-going fans. Protesters are demanding tangible reductions in ticket prices to align with what working-class people earn, fearing a loss of future generations of fans if the authorities do not act.

A newborn baby named Star Reader, diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition, was saved by a liver transplant from her mother's twin sister, Shanell Reader. Star's parents noticed her skin turning yellow, a symptom of the condition where bile ducts are blocked or absent, which can lead to liver failure if untreated. Neither of Star's parents were suitable matches for a transplant, but Shanell volunteered and gave part of her liver. Star underwent the operation in November and has since recovered well, requiring ongoing medical tests and medication.

Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake participated in Audi's football challenge, competing against Loic Remy and Willian. In the first round, Hazard and Ake won 5-3 by shooting balls into a car's boot. A subsequent challenge involved sinking balls into convertibles from long range, which Hazard and Ake also won, giving them a 6-0 lead. The final game, where players shot from long range aiming for the top of a convertible Audi, was won by Remy and Willian. During this final challenge, Willian accidentally smashed a wing mirror off one of the Audis.

Robert Dellinger, a former Fortune 500 executive, stated during his sentencing that he was not suicidal when he caused a highway crash in December 2013 that killed Amanda Murphy, who was eight months pregnant, and her fiancé Jason Timmons. Dellinger, who pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and assault, faces 12 to 24 years in prison. His attorneys claim he was suffering from ambien withdrawal, a drug overdose, and multiple sclerosis symptoms, while prosecutors allege he was depressed and intentionally drove into oncoming traffic. Dellinger's wife described him as a man of ethics and integrity, and the couple's families are devastated by the loss.

Lacey Spears of Scottsville, Kentucky, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for the second-degree murder of her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, by poisoning him with salt. The boy's father, Chris Hill, expressed his anger and hope that Spears would die in prison. Prosecutors argued that Spears made her son ill for attention, while her lawyer claimed she was innocent and blamed the hospital for negligence. Spears's social media posts about her son's supposed medical problems were used as evidence against her.

An improved influenza vaccination, including protection against influenza A strain H3N2 and influenza B strain B/Phuket, is arriving in Australia a month later than expected due to a spike in flu-related deaths in Europe and the United States caused by a mismatch in the previous vaccine. High-risk groups, including the very young, very old, and most indigenous Australians, can access free government-funded flu shots from April 20. Experts consider the modified vaccine worth the wait, and Dr. Alan Hampson advises everyone to get vaccinated, as the vaccine also protects against influenza A strain H1N1. The modified vaccine is expected to be a good match for circulating global strains, and people are encouraged to book their flu shots promptly.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are facing criticism from National Geographic magazine and potential budget cuts that could impact its management, coinciding with the 150th anniversary of Lincoln's assassination. Illinois, facing a financial crisis, is considering eliminating the state historic preservation agency that manages the tomb, with Governor Bruce Rauner proposing to roll the agency into another department. National Geographic described the tomb as having "all the historical character of an office lobby" and being a "disappointment" reconstructed in an "incongruous art deco style." Funding cuts last year have already reduced the tomb's operating hours and staff. Despite these challenges, supporters argue the magazine's portrayal is unfair, and the tomb has undergone significant repairs and renovations totaling over $2.5 million, leaving it in "excellent physical condition." The tomb, designed by Larkin Mead and dedicated in 1874, has been reconstructed twice and features interior marble and bronze, with Lincoln buried in the family burial chamber.

Nineties and noughties fashion trends are making a comeback, including bucket hats, camouflage print, extreme styling, Ugg boots, daisy dukes, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outerwear, and harem trousers, with celebrities like Rihanna, Beyoncé, Kylie Jenner, Paris Hilton, Jessica Simpson, Britney Spears, and Selena Gomez being noted for their participation in these trends.

This week's trending stories include four rainbows appearing in the New York area after heavy rain, the practice of hiring exotic dancers at wakes being banned in rural China, Robert Downey Jr. becoming agitated during an interview about his private life, the #kyliejennerchallenge involving lip plumping, 102-year-old Alice Barker returning to filmmaking, a school rejecting a prom-posal referencing bombs leading to accusations of racism, Ewan McGregor being cast as Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast', Johnny Depp's unrecognizable appearance in the 'Black Mass' trailer, a pregnancy announcement referencing 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air', and a military dad photobombing his son.

Serena Williams reached the semi-finals of the Miami Open by defeating Sabine Lisicki in three sets, marking her 700th career victory. This achievement was celebrated with a giant cake, following Andy Murray's recent 500th win, which also received a cake. Williams will face Simona Halep in the semi-finals after Halep defeated Sloane Stephens.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani activist and cafe owner, was shot and killed in Karachi after hosting a discussion on human rights and women's entrepreneurship. Her cafe, known as the second floor or t2f, was a space for open dialogue on technology, human rights, and women's entrepreneurship, and she was a vocal advocate for free speech in Pakistan. Mahmud had previously received death threats for her work, particularly for her efforts to facilitate discussions on sensitive topics like the situation in Baluchistan, which authorities had attempted to shut down. Her death has been met with widespread grief and tributes, with many remembering her as a courageous figure who championed humanism, love, and tolerance.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu healer, fled to Indian Kashmir 70 years ago during the partition of India and has since been denied citizenship rights, including the ability to own property or vote in state elections, leaving him and thousands of other West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) in poverty.
