This denial of rights is attributed to fears of upsetting the demographic balance in India's only Muslim-majority state, with successive governments hesitant to grant full rights. However, the recent success of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist party, the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), in the state has brought renewed hope for the WPRs, as the BJP is expected to champion their cause and normalize their status, though activists warn of potential unrest if their hopes are dashed.

FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto is still considering a summer move to Chelsea, who have reportedly made a £4 million offer for the Japan international. While Chelsea would likely loan Muto to Vitesse Arnhem, the 22-year-old desires a club where he can play regularly and develop his potential. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is aware of Muto, and the club's recent sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber suggests commercial interests may influence transfer policy, though Mourinho emphasizes that any signing must be a good player or prospect. Muto's former coach, Ranko Popovic, believes Muto is an intelligent, speedy, and confident player with great potential.

Australia has wisely abandoned its policy of not selecting players based on their overseas playing location, a move that highlights England's outdated approach. England's coach, Stuart Lancaster, should be empowered to select the best players regardless of where they play, similar to how Roy Hodgson would pick star footballers playing abroad. Players like Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell are performing exceptionally well for Toulon, and their exclusion from the England squad would be detrimental. Steffon Armitage and Nick Abendanon have also seen significant improvements in their game since moving to France, demonstrating that overseas environments can foster better performance. Jonny Wilkinson's success in France further supports the argument for selecting players based on merit, not location. For England to succeed in the World Cup, especially as the home team, selecting the strongest possible squad, including talented overseas players, is paramount. The current policy prevents England from fielding its best team, potentially leading to regret and missed opportunities.

The firechat app allows users to chat without a web or mobile signal by creating wireless mesh networks using Apple's multipeer connectivity framework (MCF) or a similar Android feature. These networks connect phones within a range of about 30 feet, with each phone acting as a node to pass data. The greenstone, an egg-shaped device developed by Open Garden, acts as a booster to strengthen these off-the-grid networks and extend message range, which is limited to around 200 feet for the app alone. Greenstone can store up to 1,000 recent messages and has a one-year battery life, with Open Garden partnering with manufacturers for its future sale.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer from New Jersey, is challenging the negative connotations of the word "fat" by embracing it as an honest self-descriptor, similar to how she uses "short" and "wife." She argues that "fat" does not have to be synonymous with "ugly" and highlights that size discrimination in the workplace has increased significantly. Bustle believes that exposure to body diversity leads to greater tolerance and acceptance, which is why she performs burlesque to present a "fat" body in a positive and glamorous light. She finds burlesque empowering and body-positive, and she encourages others to find a "courage reference" from past moments of bravery to combat insecurity. Her TED talk, posted recently, has garnered many positive responses, including a letter from a teenage girl who reevaluated her body image after watching it.

Theo Walcott and six of his Arsenal teammates, including Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, and Mesut Ozil, participated in a photoshoot for Lanvin, Paris' oldest fashion house and the club's official tailor since 2013. Walcott, who has frequently been on the bench this season, having been a substitute in 17 of 33 Premier League games, was pictured with runway model Olga Sherer and his teammates for this official portrait. The Arsenal first team will wear similar attire for their FA Cup final against Aston Villa on May 30.

An auction will be held on May 29th at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on propstore.com, featuring a collection of props and puppets from legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker's Cinovation Studio. The collection, estimated to be worth $746,100, includes items from blockbusters like *Men in Black*, *Batman Forever*, and *How the Grinch Stole Christmas*, with individual pieces expected to fetch significant amounts. Notable items include the alien Edgar Bug from *Men in Black* (estimated $40,000), the Two-Face mask from *Batman Forever* ($1,500), and the Grinch costume from *How the Grinch Stole Christmas* ($8,000). The auction will offer over 400 items from more than 50 productions spanning Baker's 30-year career, providing an opportunity for collectors and fans to acquire pieces from his acclaimed work.

Seven-year-old Carwyn Scott-Howell died after falling 164ft in the French Alps while skiing with his family. He became separated from his mother and headed into dense woodland, where footprints in the snow eventually led police to his body. Carwyn was described as a daring, outgoing, and determined youngster who was a competent skier and snowboarder. His family expressed their devastation, stating that his death has left a "vast void in their hearts."

Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia due to pressures to be a "size zero," leading her to survive on as little as one piece of fruit a day and hide food. Her obsession with weight loss caused her body to shut down, resulting in a collapse and a week on a heart machine in intensive care. After her recovery, supported by eating disorder organizations, Laura has improved her body image and reached the semi-finals of Miss Teen GB, a competition that promotes positive experiences away from size zero stereotypes.

Liverpool supporters made it clear they expect Raheem Sterling to stay at the club while he was unveiling the new home kit at Anfield, which is the first from new supplier New Balance. Sterling, along with teammates Daniel Sturridge, Martin Skrtel, and Simon Mignolet, presented the new gingham-design kit to fans. This event occurred shortly after Sterling's interview where he rejected a new contract and expressed interest in other clubs, casting doubt on his future. Despite this, Liverpool is adamant that the 20-year-old will not leave this summer. The players also expressed their excitement for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley.

University of Manchester researchers have produced the largest single high-definition map of dark matter, covering 0.4% of the sky, with the goal of mapping 12.5% over five years to create a 3D view. This map, created using data from the Dark Energy Camera and the Victor M. Blanco Telescope in Chile, allows astronomers to study galaxy formation by observing the gravitational effects of dark matter, which is thought to constitute at least 80% of the universe's matter. The map was released at the April meeting of the American Physical Society in Baltimore, Maryland, and the project is part of the five-year Dark Energy Survey (DES).

Manchester United has officially approached PSV Eindhoven for Memphis Depay, a 21-year-old Dutch international. Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal, who previously included Depay in the Netherlands' World Cup squad, is eager to make him one of his first summer signings. Depay has had a prolific season for PSV, scoring 20 goals in 26 league games and helping them win the Dutch championship. He is described as pacy, with good dribbling skills and a powerful shot, though he can sometimes make poor passes or hold onto the ball too long. Some believe he has the potential to match Arjen Robben and even surpass Cristiano Ronaldo at the same age.

Chelsea secured a 3-1 victory over Manchester City's youth team, with Tammy Abraham scoring twice and Dominic Solanke adding a late goal. Sportsmail provided an analysis of the players, highlighting Abraham's volleys and Solanke's powerful performance for Chelsea, while for Manchester City, Isaac Buckley-Ricketts scored their lone goal, and Brandon Barker created chances. Other notable Chelsea players included Fikayo Tomori, Jake Clarke-Salter, and Charlie Colkett, while Manchester City's Tosin Adarabioyo and Cameron Humphreys-Grant were also mentioned.

Marco Rubio believes people are born with a sexual preference but insists that state legislators, not courts, should decide on gay marriage, stating that the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman. He also mentioned that he would attend a same-sex wedding of someone he cared for, despite his personal beliefs. Rubio, who is running for president, has received significant monetary commitments from donors.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde are a couple who quit their restaurant jobs to cycle around the world, aiming to discover different parts of the planet. After 356 days, they have covered nearly 7,000 miles through 16 countries, living on less than three euros each per day by relying on free accommodation, such as camping or hosting websites, and minimizing food expenses. Their journey began in London, taking them through Europe and into Turkey, with plans to continue into Asia and cycle the length of the American continent.

A Texas couple who married in 2012 is suing Premiere Photos, owned by James Evans, because they claim a racial slur was printed on their photo booth snapshots. The couple, who wishes to remain anonymous, hired attorney Cathy Hale. The bride's sister informed the couple of the incident months after the wedding, as she did not want to spoil the event. The groom contacted Evans, who allegedly told him to "sue me" and did not apologize. The couple is suing under the Texas deceptive trade practices act for negligence and breach of contract. Evans denies the allegations, stating there is no evidence linking his company to the caption and that the couple showed no mental anguish. Mediation is scheduled, with a trial set for July if no agreement is reached. The couple's lawyer stated that an apology is the minimum they seek.

Mike Brown, an England full-back, is adopting a cautious approach to recovering from his latest concussion setback and is unsure when he will return to action for Harlequins. He experienced symptoms after a game against France and is prioritizing his health to avoid a prolonged absence, citing examples like Johnny Sexton and George North, who has been advised not to play this season after multiple concussions. Brown's decision to withdraw from a match against Ireland was influenced by increased awareness of concussion symptoms from World Rugby online modules, highlighting the importance of honesty and understanding the short and long-term dangers of the injury. He emphasizes that pushing through symptoms is not worth the risk and advocates for players to be honest about their condition.

Smartphone use may be contributing to a decline in monthly sexual activity for couples, with a typical heterosexual couple now having sex three times a month, down from four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. Professor David Spiegelhalter suggests that increased technological connectivity has blurred the lines between public and private lives, leading to less "quiet empty time" and a busier schedule that squeezes out time for partners. Other potential factors include more people living alone, and with competing demands on time, sex has become a lower priority, with late-night work emails leaving individuals too connected to focus on their partners.

Tibetan Mastiffs, once commanding prices up to £1.2 million, are now unpopular in China and being sent to slaughterhouses for their meat and skin. This decline is partly attributed to the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown, which has reduced their use as gifts, and bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several cities. Animal welfare workers have found groups of these dogs, which can weigh up to 80 kg and were traditionally used for herding, in cruel conditions during transport to abattoirs. Ruthless gangs are stealing them, and unscrupulous breeders are selling off "imperfect" specimens, leading to a glut of poor-quality dogs due to excessive cross-breeding driven by profit. Additionally, rapid urbanization has made people realize the breed is not suited for city living.

A poll of 600 women in Paris revealed that every woman surveyed had experienced some form of sexual harassment on public transport, with half being assaulted before the age of 18. Harassment can range from insults to sex attacks, leading six out of ten women to fear being attacked, compared to three out of ten men. These attacks, often unreported and invisible, force women to alter their daily lives to avoid confrontation, effectively excluding them from public spaces. The findings have prompted calls for a campaign to address sexist or threatening behavior on public transport, with experts emphasizing that such actions are punishable and that women need to be educated that what they experience is not normal.

Leeds-based Direct Line is running a competition called #everydayfix, where groups designed products to address common problems identified in a survey of 2,000 people, with the top emergency being not being able to sleep. Three prototype products have been shortlisted: "Snooze," an alarm clock designed to silence phone notifications for better sleep; "Forget Me Lock," a device that indicates if a door is locked; and "Nipper," a small mobile phone charger that uses household batteries. The public can vote for their favorite on Twitter, and the winning product will be developed and funded through a Kickstarter campaign.

Vera Baird, the police and crime commissioner for Northumbria, is under investigation by the Ministry of Justice for awarding over £500,000 of public money to Victims First Northumbria, a charity she directs alongside Northumbria's Chief Constable, Sue Sim. Critics have called this an inappropriate conflict of interest, with Keith Vaz stating that a PCC should not use public money for organizations they have an interest in. Baird maintains that all Ministry of Justice procedures were followed and is confident in the decision. Sim, who previously faced an investigation spearheaded by Baird for alleged bullying, is retiring from the force in June. The Ministry of Justice will investigate to determine if any conflict of interest rules were broken.

Corry "Corey" Campbell, the ringleader of the "tattoo terrorists," was sentenced to 20 years in state prison for his role in a horrific assault on Greg Valecce, a 53-year-old man who was beaten, tied to a chair, and covered in offensive tattoos. Campbell believed Valecce had hurt his cat, Pebbles. The assault, which lasted about 42 hours, involved Campbell, his girlfriend Sandra Ng, and Carl Halin, who also received a 20-year sentence. Ng was sentenced to 23 months in state prison. Two other individuals, David Thomas and Jennifer Pratt, are awaiting sentencing and trial, respectively. Valecce suffered severe injuries and has experienced lasting psychological trauma from the incident.

Manchester United has officially approached PSV Eindhoven for Memphis Depay, a 21-year-old Dutch international. Manager Louis van Gaal, who previously included Depay in the World Cup squad, is keen to make him a summer signing. Tottenham had a £15 million bid rejected last summer, but PSV's technical director confirms contact with Manchester United and Paris Saint-Germain for larger sums. Depay has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, helping PSV win the Dutch championship. He is described as pacy with good dribbling skills and a powerful shot, though he can sometimes make poor passes. Some believe he has the potential to match Arjen Robben and even surpass a young Cristiano Ronaldo.

Sportsmail provided an analysis of the players' performances, highlighting Abraham's volleys and Solanke's decisive third goal for Chelsea, while for City, Isaac Buckley-Ricketts scored their lone goal, and Brandon Barker created chances but was sometimes guilty of trying to do too much. Other notable Chelsea players included Fikayo Tomori, Jake Clarke-Salter, and Charlie Colkett, while Manchester City's Tosin Adarabioyo and Cameron Humphreys-Grant were noted for their defensive efforts.
